item.title: How to shop for Health Products?
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded:
Searching for a health supplement that is both safe and effective can be somewhat of a minefield. Unfortunately, the vitamins and minerals in many modern day supplements are often from artificial sources, or they contain additional ingredients that are unsafe or untested for human consumption. When you’re shopping for supplements, it’s important to look out for the following:

Synthetic Nutrients

One of the biggest problems with supplements is the source from which the vitamins and minerals are taken. Many of these vitamins and minerals are created in a laboratory – not taken from natural sources. The fact is, the chemical structure of a laboratory made vitamin is completely different to that of a vitamin derived from food sources, meaning the body just cannot process it in the way it can a vitamin sourced from one’s diet. Check the ingredients list on your supplement, as synthetic nutrients are fairly easy to spot. Synthetic nutrients are almost always listed as their chemical name – for instance, pantothenic acid (vitamin B5), Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and Folic Acid (vitamin B9). ‘Folate,’ on the other hand, is vitamin B9 taken from a food source. For more information read 'why wholefood supplements?'

Isolated Nutrients

Much like synthetic nutrients, taking a certain nutrient in isolation can be problematic. Whole foods provide nutrition for the body by offering a vitamin complex – a structure of vitamins, minerals and enzymes that function synergistically. By isolating one particular nutrient, you are removing this synergy and can therefore not expect it to be used in the same way by the body. By taking one nutrient in isolation, you are also in danger of creating problematic nutrient imbalances. To avoid taking isolated nutrients, look for a supplement that is taken from a whole food source and therefore contains a range of supporting nutrients.

Nutrient Load

Given that certain nutrients are toxic in high doses, such as calcium, iron and vitamin A, it is possible to ‘overdose’ on these nutrients by taking them in the form of a highly concentrated supplement. Where this usually happens is when someone looks towards a supplement as their only source of a particular nutrient, discounting all other dietary sources that they may be consuming on a daily basis. An example being Calcium, which has an RDA in the UK of 700MG – a number that is easily reached with a balanced diet, even without dairy consumption. By taking a calcium supplement of around 500mg on top of adequate dietary intake from food sources, one could be approaching a level of calcium that can be problematic – around 1500mg. Given that calcium should be balanced with an appropriate intake of magnesium, taking high amounts of isolated calcium in the form of a supplement could cause an imbalance in the body and actually cause adverse effects on bone health. Again, this takes us back to the point about isolating nutrients. GMOs, Fillers, Binders and Artificial Ingredients Once again, it’s vitally important you check the ingredients list of your supplement, keeping an eye out for any questionable ingredients that may be included. If you see the likes of maltodextrin, dextrose or soybean oil, it’s very likely but not in all cases that these are taken from genetically modified organisms (GMOs). If you have allergies, keep an eye out for any ingredients such as lactose or gluten containing ingredients. It is also worth checking for artificial colours and preservatives – methyl paraben and propyl paraben are commonly used. During the manufacturing process, companies will often include fillers and binders to decrease waste and therefore increase profitability. However, these ingredients have been proven to inhibit nutrient absorption by up to 65%. Anti-adherents, such as magnesium stearate, are used to protect the product from sticking to machinery during manufacturing – but have also been shown to create a ‘film’ like substance in the intestines, interfering with nutrient absorption.

Research and development

One final thing worth bearing in mind when choosing a supplement, is ensuring that it is made by a company that is both trusted and reputable. A supplement should always be supported by extensive research and clinical trials, and created by a brand that is well respected and trustworthy. If a supplement is ‘new’ – exercise particular caution. Has this product been researched enough, in both the short and the long term, to be considered safe and viable?

So what do I look for?

It may sound like a lot to watch out for, but in reality, common sense should prevail when choosing a health supplement. Supplements should be as close as possible to their natural form – ideally taken from whole food sources. Avoid synthetic and isolated nutrients, artificial additives and problematic bulking agents. Choose research backed supplements from trustworthy companies, and exercise caution with products that are new on the market. Humans have been surviving on nutrients taken solely from dietary sources for thousands of years, so it is important that a healthy, nutrient dense diet remains your number one focus. [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What to Look Out for In Health Supplements - Vivo Life
Health supplements can vary wildly in quality, so follow these guidelines to make sure you're buying the right products.

item.title: Why choose Whole Food Supplements?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
As the health of the Western World deteriorates due to inadequate nutrition and poor lifestyle habits such as a lack of exercise and quality sleep, more and more people are turning to supplements in an attempt to regain their vitality. In fact, the UK supplement industry made approximately £385 million last year alone, and has seen increased revenues year upon year since they first became ‘mainstream.’

However, many people who choose to take supplements may not actually be benefitting their health at all – in fact, they could be doing the exact opposite.

SUPPLEMENTS - WHAT'S THE PROBLEM?

Humans (and creatures in general) are designed to eat real, unprocessed, whole foods. In these foods, nutrients exist in a unison that is no co-incidence. The vitamins, minerals, trace elements, antioxidants, enzymes and phytonutrients they contain work together in ratios that our bodies know exactly how to deal with. They work synergistically, complementing each other as they carry out different tasks within the body.

However, when we start isolating these nutrients into single forms, we remove this synergy, making the nutrients less recognisable to the body and start to create imbalances in the body that can have serious effects on our health.

And there lies the problem. Anyone attempting to supplement their way out of a nutrient poor diet is on a crash course to poor health. Their bodies will be riddled with copious amounts of synthetic nutrients that they have no idea what to do with. The consequences? Chronic inflammation, compromised immunity and hormonal imbalances, to name just three.

As with most things, nature knows best. Take Vitamin A as an example. Whilst critical to human life – and essential for bone support and immunity – Vitamin A can be toxic in extremely high doses, especially when it acts as an isolated nutrient. However, Vitamin A is more effectively utilised by the body in the presence of supporting nutrients; the two most important being Zinc and Vitamin D.

It should come as no surprise then, that real, unprocessed foods that are naturally abundant in Vitamin A – for example liver and egg yolks – also come conveniently packaged with Zinc and Vitamin D. These nutrients work together in unison to serve the needs of our bodies, the way nature intended.

Vitamin E is another example. A fat soluble vitamin found in plant foods like nuts, seeds and avocado, Vitamin E helps protect polyunsaturated fats (such as omega 6, most commonly found in plant foods) from oxidative damage. Therefore, the more polyunsaturated fats we eat, the more Vitamin E we need – but, conveniently, Mother Nature has yet again got our backs by providing the perfect amounts in natural foods. If you’re eating real, unprocessed whole foods, whilst avoiding industrially processed oils and trans fats, you’ll have all the Vitamin E you could ever need – no pills required.

THE ROLE OF WHOLE FOOD SUPPLEMENTS

Ideally, we’d all be getting every last nutrient we need from a diet rich in natural, wholesome foods. However, due to our busy lives and often demanding exercise programmes, there are many of us who could benefit from a little extra support. This is where Whole Food supplements come in.

The clue is in the name. By using the ‘whole food,’ Whole Food supplements maintain an appropriate nutrient balance and vitamin complex. These nutrients can then be utilised more effectively by the body, without becoming toxic and creating any sort of imbalance. Whole Food supplements allow us to efficiently boost our intake of life giving vitamins, minerals and antioxidants in sensible amounts that our bodies can deal with.

WHEN BUYING A SUPPLEMENT You should ensure that it is as close as possible to its natural form. If possible, enquire into the manufacturing process of the supplement – ideally, it would have been faced with as little processing as possible and will not contain any fillers, binders or flow agents!

If there are questionable ingredients in a product, the chances are they are acting as a cheap filler or binding agent. And remember - a nutrient in isolation is not the same as the same nutrient found in it's natural 'whole food' form!

Products from recognised, trustworthy brands such as Terranova, Wild Nutrition, Creative Nature, and Inspiral naturally support our lifestyles, as they are built from real, wholesome ingredients.

Choose your supplements wisely, and you’ll be much further down the path to greater health. Choose wrongly, and you’d be better off not taking them at all.

WHERE TO SHOP FOR HEALTH PRODUCTS?

At Vivo Life we’re passionate about sourcing the highest quality, most effective products that are as minimally processed and as close to their natural state as possible.

We don’t see the need for artificial additives, preservatives and sweeteners, and we steer as far clear from GMOs as we possibly can. We don’t believe in fillers, binders or bulking agents, as they vastly compromise the quality and interfere with absorption.

At Vivo we've done the hard part for you, so you no longer need to spend hours scouring the internet for health supplements you can trust - simply head straight to the Vivo Store and browse our selection of over 50 premium brands from around the world and over 600 high quality products.

Remember - Whole Food supplements should be used AS PART OF, and not in place of, a healthy diet and lifestyle.

Have any questions? Feel free to comment below, or contact us directly by using our contact us form. If you enjoyed this article please share it with a friend.

item.title: Why Choose Raw Protein Powder?
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded:
Not all protein powders are created equal.

The key to choosing the right protein powder for you comes with experimentation and measuring your results - but there are a few things worth thinking about before you make your purchase.

One of the most important things to consider is whether or not your protein has been heat treated. The vast majority of protein powders on the market are heat treated, as this is the most cost-effective form of processing. A raw protein, on the other hand, may not be as cheap to make - but it is certainly the most effective choice for your body and general health.

WHY CHOOSE RAW PROTEIN?

To be considered a 'raw' protein, a product cannot be exposed to heat above 42C / 107F at any time during processing. Maintaining low temperatures throughout the manufacturing process locks in all the valuable nutrients and enzymes that allow us to efficiently digest the protein - meaning that your product gets to work exactly where it is needed.

Although a heat-treated protein powder may seem cheaper, if you're absorbing less of the nutrients, you're not getting the same value for money as you would with a raw protein.

For example: Lysine and Tryptophan, two essential amino acids, are denatured by heat above 110F, reducing their effectiveness and availability to the body. Lysine and Tryptophan are especially volatile in whey protein; which is why we only supply an organic, cold pressed whey protein in our online store.

When a protein powder is raw, you can almost guarantee that the ingredients will be healthy and wholesome. Proteins will be sourced from nutrient dense food sources, such as hemp protein, pea protein, chlorella and spirulina – as opposed to problematic, heat treated proteins commonly whey protein and soy.

Raw proteins are easier to digest, richer in nutrients, and free from the questionable ingredients that rear their ugly heads in many heat-processed protein powders, including aspartame, sucralose, carboxymethylcellulose, emulsifying agents and artificial flavourings. Even vegan proteins often contain fillers and bulking agents, such as maltodextrin.

Be careful, one of the most common vegan protein sources is soy protein – but this comes with a great deal of controversy. Soy contains anti-nutrients and goitrogens, and has also been proven to have oestrogenic effects on the body. More details about the potential damage soy can cause to your health are available at WWW.WESTONAPRICE.ORG. Raw proteins, especially those that are sprouted, have minimal anti-nutrients, are non-toxic, and do not interfere with your hormonal balance in any way.

MORE THAN JUST PROTEIN

Put simply, a high quality raw protein supplement is much more than just protein. For example, Garden of Life Raw Protein is rich in Vitamins A, D, E and K, as well as being an excellent source of soluble fibre. This is often the case with raw protein supplements, as they are made with real, wholesome ingredients.

What’s more, in comparison with other vegan proteins, a high quality raw protein will often contain a superior amino acid profile. Take Pulsin Raw Hemp protein for example – it contains all the essential amino acids, as well as high levels of non essential (yet highly beneficial) amino acids such as Arginine and Glutamine. Often, vegan proteins can be incomplete, meaning they are lacking in one or more of the essential amino acids needed for growth and development.

One of our newest products, Revolution Foods' Raw Plant Protein, is one of the most complete protein products we have seen. Hemp and pea proteins combine to give an excellent amino acid profile, complimented by nutrient dense greens moringa and chlorella, both of which are an excellent source of protein, antioxidants, and phytonutrients. This protein powder is further enhanced with the addition of digestive enzymes, allowing you to fully absorb all the goodness in your protein powder.

WHAT TO LOOK FOR IN A PROTEIN SUPPLEMENT

When choosing your protein, always read the label. Check the ingredients list, and make sure there are:

  • No fillers, bulking agents, or any questionable additives
  • Check to see if it has been cold processed (not heated above 42C)
  • Protein should be sourced from nutrient dense whole foods, and should include the full amino acid spectrum for effective recovery
  • If the protein is grain or legume based, make sure they are sprouted, as this will further increase the bioavailability and remove any anti-nutrients that could be present.
  • Ideally, look for a product that also contains probiotics and / or digestive enzymes, in order to improve the digestibility of the product.

When buying a high quality raw protein supplement, you are buying a product that is nutrient dense, easy to assimilate, and free from toxic and artificial ingredients. Choose wisely, and you’ll have a highly nutritious product that supports an active lifestyle and helps you to achieve your performance goals.

WHERE TO LOOK FOR RAW PROTEIN POWDERS?

At Vivo Life, we are a health-conscious bunch specialising in the online retail of natural health and fitness products. The aim of Vivo Life is to cut through the masses of health products and provide a select range of only the finest products from trustworthy and reliable brands. Every item we stock is completely junk-free – so no fillers, binders, allergens, por artificial ingredients. Just wholesome, natural health products that REALLY work. We have done the hard work for you.. We have searched high and low for the best raw protein powders on the market, to see the full list visit our protein category by clicking here. We believe in the benefits of raw, low temperature processed protein powders so much that we have created icons in our store to make it easier to find them.    

If you have any questions then simply comment below, if you like this article then please share it with a friend.

item.title: Vivo Health Products Checklist
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded:
Here at Vivo, we’re passionate about sourcing the highest quality, most effective products that are as minimally processed and as close to their natural state as possible. We don’t see the need for artificial additives, preservatives and sweeteners, and we steer as far clear from GMOs as we possibly can. We don’t believe in fillers, binders or bulking agents, as they vastly compromise the quality and interfere with absorption. In short, only the highest quality health products make it into our online store. If we wouldn't use them ourselves, we won't sell them to you. Here's what we look for when choosing our products:

When shopping for food products or food based supplements, i.e protein powders, snack bars, superfoods, oils etc:

  • Are the ingredients raw, or as close to raw as possible? We like our ingredients to be as close to the form nature intended as possible in order for them to retain maximum bio availability and to be efficiently absorbed.
  • Has the product been exposed to heat? Excessive heat can denature proteins and oxidise fats – so we choose products that have been low temperature processed to maintain the delicate balance of nutrients.
  • Is the product all natural? If it contains artificial or GMO ingredients, fillers or bulking agents, we won’t supply it.
  • Source of ingredients? The quality of the ingredients is equally important, we look for unpolluted sustainable sources with no herbicides, pesticides, and choose certified organic wherever we can.
When shopping for health supplements:
  • How bioavailable is the product? In order to be as effective as possible, vitamins and minerals need to be easy to absorb. Generally when they are as close to their natural state as possible then your body can understand them and process them effectively.
  • Does the product contain isolates or synthetics? Vitamins and minerals exist in nature surrounded by a complex package of synergistic co-nutrients. Isolated nutrients do not act in the way that they should as they do not have the natural synergy that allows for effective absorption and utilisation. The same goes for synthetic nutrients where in its concentrated form can easily create imbalances in the body.
  • Does the product contain fillers, binders or flow agents? Again, if there are questionable ingredients in a product, the chances are they are acting as a cheap filler or binding agent. We like our vitamins and minerals with an ingredients list that we can pronounce.

When shopping for cosmetics and personal care products:

    • Is the product non-toxic? If we wouldn’t put chemicals into our bodies, why should we put them on our bodies? Our skin is our biggest tool for absorbing nutrients, but it absorbs toxins too. We avoid products with any parabens, harsh chemicals or artificial fragrances, instead choosing personal care products with real ingredients. Click here for a full list of the ingredients we avoid in personal care products, and why we do so.
    • Is the product effective? No matter how natural a product may be, if it doesn’t provide effective results, why would you want to use it? We only choose products that deliver on their promises and provide exceptional results.
    • Is the product safe for long term use? Far too many products deliver short term benefits, but are too harsh for long term use without upsetting our skin. We don’t believe in sacrificing our long term health for short term gain; so rest assured, every product in the Vivo range will be nothing but beneficial, no matter how long you use it for.

Company values and manufacturing checks:

When researching potential products and product manufacturers, we look out for the following:
  • Product Quality Certifications – i.e Certfied Organic, Vegan Certified, Vegetarian Society Approved, Certified Gluten Free, Cruelty Free, Non GMO Project Verified, Informed-Choice.Org Trusted by Sports
  • Manufacturing Quality Certifications – i.e EU Compliant, GMP Certified, NGS Registered, ISO 17025
  • Packaging – is the packaging recyclable, sustainable, and if applicable BPA free?
  • Manufacturing Process – are the company taking active measures to reduce their environmental impact?
  • Company Integrity – How long has the company been trading? What are their values, do they trade ethically and sustainably? What are their policies on environmental and animal welfare?
  • Product Reviews – Have other users had good experience with the product? If the product is new, do the ingredients make sense?
We research all of our products comprehensively before purchase, to make sure they are of the highest quality and integrity. For us, this is one of the most important things that we do, and empowers the consumer to make wise and confident decisions when purchasing products from us. Happy Shopping! The Vivo Team
