item.title: The Importance of Correct Storage
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded:
‘Store in a cool, dry place, away from sunlight.’

You’ve probably read it on labels hundreds of times in your lifetime; chances are, you’ve obeyed the rules too without giving them much thought. These universally recognised storage rules are found on all sorts of household products: oils, vinegars, herbs, spices, nuts, seeds, and countless other everyday products all carry a message to that effect. But just why are they there anyway? These basic rules of storage are put in place to maintain the quality and freshness of any particular product. The reason being that, when a food product is exposed to heat, light, or humidity, certain changes begin to take place. Depending on the temperature or the brightness of the light, nutrients begin to be destroyed and ingredients turn rancid. Excess humidity causes the growth of mould and other harmful bacteria. Of course, if you’re following the basic storage principles and consuming your product by the ‘use by’ date, you have nothing to worry about. Or do you? What if your supplier was not storing the products you purchased in the correct conditions in the first place?

Why it matters

Storage is especially important when it comes to particular ingredients, many of which are common place in health foods and sports nutrition products. When certain products are stored in inappropriate conditions and exposed to heat or light, the quality becomes compromised before they even reach the customer! Some of the most volatile products are:

Oils and Essential Fatty Acids

When exposed to heat and light, certain fats become rancid quite quickly. Some fats are more delicate than others, with plant based fats generally being most prone to oxidative damage. The most delicate of all are polyunsaturated fats, also known as Omega 3, Omega 6, and Omega 9. When exposed to heat, these once healthy fatty acids begin to rapidly deteriorate, quickly becoming toxic as the fat molecules oxidise. We’d normally be put off consuming rancid oils by the smell or appearance – but when these oils are consumed in the form of capsules, it becomes very difficult to determine an oxidised omega 3 supplement from a perfectly healthy one. If a manufacturer goes to great lengths to ensure that the oils are extracted using a cutting edge, heat free process, what sense does it make to store these fats in inappropriate conditions? With things like coconut oil, it isn’t as important, as the saturated fatty acids are naturally much more stable. That being said, our coconut oil is kept in the same cool, dark conditions as the rest of our oils, in order to maintain it’s delicate flavour and full nutritional value.

Proteins

Protein powders are the biggest selling health supplement on the market today, but with so many of these products being stored in inadequate conditions, what sort of product are we actually receiving? Although they are not as delicate as fats, when protein powders are exposed to heat, light or moisture, the quality begins to deteriorate. This reduces the shelf life of the product, as well as compromising the taste and mixability. You wouldn’t leave your protein powder exposed to direct sunlight in the home, so why should someone else compromise it’s quality before it even reaches you?

Raw Foods

We’re  big believers in the nutritional value of raw food and the depth of nutrients, phytonutrients and enzymes it contains. As soon as a raw food is exposed to heat, the enzymes and phytonutrients begin to break down, the antioxidant content diminishes, and in some cases, ingredients can even become denatured. If you’re going out of your way to consume raw foods, you’re making an excellent choice for your health – so why contradict all of your effort for your product to be degraded thanks to bad storage practice? Inadequate attention to proper storage can mean that you could easily receive denatured proteins, rancid oils, pointless probiotics, or even ‘cooked’ raw food products. Unfortunately, poor storage conditions are becoming all too commonplace as more and more retailers expand into the online market, with no visible ‘shop window’ to show just how their products are being stored.

What makes us different

As part of our commitment to providing the most trustworthy health and fitness marketplace in the UK, we take the storage of all of our products very seriously. Every product is stored in optimal conditions; cold, dark and dry. It doesn’t sound like much fun for us humans, but trust us – food products LOVE it. We consistently monitor the temperature and humidity level at our storage facility to ensure it is always up to the remarkably high standards we set ourselves. By keeping our products batched in the order that they reached us, we maintain a consistent flow of products and ensure that nothing is sent out that has been sitting on the shelves for an unnecessary amount of time. Even more attention is paid to the more volatile products such as essential fatty acids, oils, proteins and raw food products. If we feel the storage environment for a certain product is not optimal from supplier to consumer then we simply do not sell it, so rest assured, you’ll be receiving your products in the high quality state the manufacturer intended.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Importance of Correct Storage - Vivo Life
We carefully maintain optimal storage conditions for our products. This is especially important for health and fitness products. Here's why!

item.title: Why Switch to Non Dairy Milk?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
During recent years, dairy free milk replacements have gone from being tucked away in the corners of specialist health food shops to the forefront of modern consumerism, taking centre stage on the ever expanding ‘free from’ sections in nearly all supermarkets. If you’d have asked for almond milk in your coffee ten years ago, you’d probably have been laughed out of the building – nowadays, some cafes even make their own. Where soy milk was once the reserved choice for strict vegans and those with medically diagnosed allergies, a growing awareness of the benefits of moving away from cow’s milk has seen coconut, hemp, rice, oat and hazelnut varieties all become available. Nowadays, milk alternatives aren’t just for people who can’t have dairy – there are a large (and still growing) number of people that now won’t have dairy, born from a personal choice usually based on health, ethics, or religion. Cow’s milk sales are at their lowest since the 1970s – but just why are so many people making the switch?

Dairy – what’s the problem?

Let’s take it right back to the beginning. When dairy first started to enter the human diet, it’s fair to say it would have been quite a discovery. Initially, animal milk would have provided a calorie rich form of sustenance that was readily available and could be survived on in times of scarcity. Rich in vitamins A and D, calcium, amino acids, and beneficial enzymes and microbes, dairy would undoubtedly have provided a large amount of energy and nutrition to ancient civilisations. So just what went wrong? Unfortunately, the milk that now sits on our supermarket shelves is completely different from the milk that would have provided such sustenance thousands of years ago. Extracted by mechanical processes from unhealthy animals kept in crowded, unsanitary conditions, fed on a diet of GMOs and antibiotics, generally modern milk is as biologically unstable as it is cruel and inhumane. If that wasn’t enough, the milk then undergoes a homogenisation process, which oxidises fats and denatures proteins. Skimming removes fat soluble vitamins A and D, before pasteurisation kills beneficial enzymes and microbes. Indeed, the extreme rise of the dairy industry has managed to warp a once nutritious food product into an allergenic, nutrient depleted disaster. The horrific state of modern milk production has been proven to be the predominant cause of so many issues of dairy ‘intolerance’ we see in modern day society, and, unsurprisingly, studies have shown that civilisations who have consumed properly produced dairy from infancy show no signs of dairy intolerance. The consumption of the damaged milk that we find on our supermarkets today is what is largely responsible for the developments of dairy intolerance, as our bodies then treat it as an offending food and begin to malfunction when it enters our digestive system. Dairy intolerance then manifests itself into a number of symptoms, including:
  • bloating,
  • constipation,
  • diarrhoea,
  • skin conditions,
  • headaches,
  • loss of focus,
  • lethargy, 
and many more besides. This doesn’t apply to all of us by any means, but if you suffer from any of these symptoms, it may be worth eliminating dairy for 30 days and seeing if they improve. Of course, there are exceptions. If you can tolerate dairy with no issues, then full fat, unpasteurised dairy products from a local, organic farm, becomes once again a perfectly nutritious product. If, on the other hand, you can’t – what are your options?

Soy Milk

We’ve put soy milk first on this list as it allows us to categorically rule it out as the safe, healthy milk alternative that it is claimed to be! There will be more on soy and the dangers it brings in a future post, so without going into much detail, the vast majority of soy used in Western food products is genetically modified and aggressively treated with herbicides and pesticides. It also contains large amounts of toxins and ‘anti-nutrients’ such as phytates, saponins and oxalates, which bind to nutrients in our digestive system and interfere with absorption. Studies have also shown that soy disrupts thyroid function and interferes with hormones, displaying potentially estrogenic effects in both men and women. Soy was once touted as being a healthy alternative to pretty much anything; but growing research in proving this not to be the case.

Hemp Milk

Hemp milk is a drink made from hemp seeds, which are soaked and then ground to create a milky substance that has a delicious, nutty flavour. Usually providing a good source of Omegas 3 and 6, GLA, iron and magnesium, hemp milk is one of the most nutritious dairy free milks on the market and one that we would highly advocate. It’s hypoallergenic too, making it a great choice for those with a delicate digestive system. When buying hemp milk, try and look for one that has been made with raw hemp and not roasted hemp.

Nut Milk

Various nut milks are now available in both supermarkets and health food shops, with almond and hazelnut being the most popular varieties. Both are made by blending soaked nuts with water, before straining to create a milk like substance. However, some manufacturers tend to include emulsifiers or thickening agents in certain nut milks (more on this below), so when purchasing them, try and buy one with as few ingredients as possible. Nut milks don’t generally have a great deal of nutritional prowess, although they do sometimes have certain vitamins and minerals added by the manufacturer. That being said, nut milks are widely available, low cost and tasty, making them another suitable alternative to cow’s milk.

Coconut Milk

Not to be confused with actual coconut milk which is very thick and often used as a base for curries, coconut milk as a milk alternative is a fairly new product but one that is increasing in popularity. Coconut ‘milk,’ in inverted commas only to differentiate it from coconut milk (confusing, right!?) is a blend of pulverised coconut flesh and water, making it a lot thinner and much more like cow’s milk. A good quality coconut ‘milk’ will provide a source of medium chain triglycerides, the fatty acids that make coconut such a well-loved health food.

Rice and Oat Milk

Rice and oat milks are both relatively benign, nutrient sparse milk alternatives – but they are generally easy to digest, and milder tasting than other milk alternatives. If you suffer from gluten intolerance and opt for oat milk, make sure it is made with certified gluten free oats. When it comes to rice milk, choose organic if possible, as conventionally grown rice sometimes contain traces of arsenic and other heavy metals.

What to look out for?

As the ‘dairy free’ market has expanded in recent years and more milk alternatives have become available, there is more choice now than ever before when it comes to finding a dairy free milk alternative. Unfortunately, dairy free milks sometimes contain unpleasant additives, flavourings, thickeners and stabilisers, which pretty much defeat the object of switching to a dairy free milk in the first place. Here are a few ingredients to look out for: Carrageenan: The safety of carrageenan has been the subject of much debate by health experts. Common in non-dairy milks, carrageenan is an indigestible polysaccharide extracted from red algae, and used as a thickener or stabiliser. A study of this ingredient on animals has shown an alarming correlation between the consumption of carrageenan and the formation of cancerous lesions and ulcerations in the colon. However, further studies have since indicated that symptoms vary from species to species, suggesting that in humans, small doses may have no effect at all. That being said, as of yet there have been no recognised human trials on a large enough scale to gather any significant research – which is why, at this time, it is still considered safe for human consumption. Whilst this may well be the case, we would advocate serious caution with an ingredient that has not been used for a long enough time to determine if it is safe – at least, until such point that research tells us otherwise. Sugar: Surprisingly, a large majority of non-dairy milks add a substantial amount of sugar to try and appeal to a nation with an incredibly sweet tooth. Ideally, look to buy an unsweetened version – and then if situations arise where you require a sweeter milk, you can add a teaspoon of raw honey or another natural sweetener. You’ll find that the majority of time you don’t need a sweet milk anyway, especially if you are using it mainly as a base for smoothies or in tea / coffee. If you can’t find an unsweetened version, shoot for a variety with 3g or less of sugar per 100ml. Vegetable oils: Vegetable oils are often included in dairy free milks in an attempt to more closely replicate the fatty acid structure in cow’s milk. Although the word ‘vegetable’ may sound natural, vegetable oils are created using high heat pressure and toxic solvents, which creates an oil that is oxidised and overflowing with free radicals. If your milk contains vegetable oil, stay well away! Colours: If it’s not ‘real’ milk, the chances are that it won’t be the same colour as cow’s milk. Expect a slightly darker hue, perhaps even a greenish tinge in certain hemp milks. If, however, you are drinking a dairy free milk that is shimmering white – check the ingredients. It probably contains some kind of colouring that your body doesn’t need. Vitamin D2: Natural Vitamin D, the kind that we absorb from the sun and found in trace amounts in certain food products (ironically, one of these being full fat cow’s milk) comes in the form of Vitamin D3. Vitamin D2, on the other hand, is a synthetic and isolated form of Vitamin D that studies have shown is extremely poorly absorbed. Some leading health experts have also found that D2 can actually desensitize the D3 receptors, making us more prone to deficiency. You’ll find that many milk alternatives have certain vitamins and minerals added; but where possible, stay away from D2.

Making the switch

If you decide to make the switch to a milk alternative, the most important thing is to choose the right milk substitute for you. This will come down to personal preferences – what tastes best? What is easiest on my digestion? What is available in my local area and within my budget? As long as you make wise choices when it comes to the manufacturer, by switching to a dairy free milk you will almost certainly be making the right choice for your body and your environment. Even better, why not try making your own? If you're avoiding dairy, you can shop with confidence at Vivo Life by browsing our dedicated 'dairy free' section! [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Why Switch to Non Dairy Milk? - Vivo Life
Dairy free milk is increasingly popular, but there are numerous options to consider. We run through the possibilities and explain the pros and cons!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Interesting stuff - whenever possible, I buy raw, organic, full fat milk from my local farm. However when this isn't available, I buy almond or hazelnut milk.

item.title: Coconut Oil – In a capsule?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: In recent years, the health benefits of coconut oil have rocketed into the mainstream media. You’re probably aware of it’s unique composition of fatty acids called medium chain triglycerides, and how they are easily converted to energy by the body, in turn improving your ability to burn stored fat for energy. You probably also know the benefits coconut oil brings to the digestive system and the brain, and even how certain studies have linked it to the prevention of diseases like Alzheimer’s and dementia. It’s true that raw, unprocessed, unrefined coconut oil is truly a miracle food. We can’t advocate it enough – cook with it, whizz it in smoothies, spread it, bake with it, even use it as a beauty product. However, in an attempt to jump on the coconut oil bandwagon, many companies have started to offer coconut oil in capsule form. In theory, this seems like it could be pretty good – especially for those who do not like the flavour of coconut oil. So, why don’t we stock coconut oil capsules? The first, and perhaps the main reason that we don’t believe in coconut oil capsules is just how impractical taking them would actually be. Coconut oil cannot be concentrated, and leading nutritionists and health professionals recommend a daily consumption of anywhere between one and three tablespoons each day. Given that the average capsule size is 500mg, and a flat tablespoon of coconut oil weighs in at approximately 20g – one would have to take 40 capsules daily just to get an effective dosage. We’re sure you’ll agree that this would get tedious pretty quickly, not to mention tough on the digestive system. Speaking of the digestive system, the vast majority of coconut oil capsules on the market are encased in artificially made, tough to break down capsules; some of which contain ingredients that can actually bind with nutrients and interfere with absorption. Whilst actually breaking down the capsules would place an unnecessary load on the digestive system in the first place, it would also be virtually impossible to assimilate all of the goodness present in the coconut oil itself. Assuming that you could assimilate approximately half of the coconut oil you are actually consuming, your RDA of coconut oil capsules now stand at 80 per day. Ouch. To further invalidate the supposed benefits of coconut oil capsules, some manufacturers have taken to using refined coconut oil in their products, presumably as a way to bring their own costs down and assuming that consumers are ignorant enough not to know the difference. It’s fairly easy to tell – at room temperature, coconut oil is a solid, if capsules contain coconut oil in liquid form, there’s something wrong; it would have had to undergo mechanical and chemical processing to make it a liquid at room temperature. This process would have involved high heats which destroy vitamins and phytonutrients and oxidise fat molecules, rendering the refined oil unfit for consumption. So, you’re now swallowing an oxidised, nutrient depleted capsule 80 times per day – sound like fun? For those left that are still considering buying coconut oil capsules, consider factoring in the cost of your investment. If you’re committed to consuming your 80-pills-per-day quota, you’ll need to find a jar (or should we say bucket) of 1600 capsules to get the equivalent to a 400g jar, which is generally priced at £7.99. Coconut oil is a food, not a supplement. It has powerful healing properties, but something so pure and tasty should be an enjoyable part of your diet, not a daily chore washed down with a pint of water. Why not combine some with some raw cacao and a little honey for some delicious, home-made raw chocolate? We think you’ll agree, that sounds a little more appealing. [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Coconut Oil – In a capsule? - Vivo Life
In an attempt to jump on the coconut oil bandwagon, numerous supplement companies have started offering coconut oil capsules. Should you use them?

item.title: A Sweet Dilemma
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
As humans, we are hard-wired to crave sweet things; from an evolutionary perspective, a sweet taste in food meant it was toxin free and safe to eat. Before the evolution of agriculture, when our ancestors came across something sweet such as fruit or honey they undoubtedly would have indulged on it until either it was all gone or they could eat no more, as they had no guarantee where their next ‘sugar hit’ would come from. Sweet food would have provided a rich and well deserved reward, and when discovered, would have been enjoyed with reckless abandon. However, our inbuilt desire to seek sweet foods has in recent years been transformed from a survival instinct into a potential health hazard, thanks in no small part to the ‘junk food’ industry. Sweetness is now everywhere you turn; soft drinks, fruit juices, breakfast cereals, sweets, chocolate, and energy bars scream at us from supermarket shelves. As a result, our threshold for sweetness has been extended, and as a nation on a collective blood sugar rollercoaster we are now consuming more added sugar than ever before. Nonetheless, a recent revolt against sugar has seen a dramatic increase in the consumption of sweeteners, sugar substitutes, and even ‘healthy’ sugar sources such as maple syrup and coconut sugar. Even these are coming up against fierce opposition, with a growing low carb and sugar free community claiming that all sugar should be avoided in our quest for optimum health. Are they correct? Or are sweeteners safe, or even healthy, in moderation? Let’s take a look at the main sugar sources in our diet and examine the evidence.

Fruit

We’re kicking things off with fruit, because although it is widely recognised as one of the healthiest things you can eat, the growing contingent of ‘sugar-shunners’ have voiced quite a strong opinion against it. The theory is that fructose, the main source of carbohydrate in fruit, is a toxin that can contribute to everything from weight gain to diabetes to cardiac failure. Whilst a number of studies do point to fructose being hazardous, these studies are looking at isolated fructose; the kind found in energy drinks and other over-processed creations of the junk food industry. There’s a notable difference between the two. Indeed, the fructose found in fruit comes packaged with fibre and water, which slows down the insulin response and increases satiety. Many people would find it rather difficult to consume 4 large Jonagold apples in one sitting, but it’s significantly easier to drink a can of coke. Studies have shown that the consumption of fruit is in no way unhealthy, whilst an increase in fruit consumption can actually decrease the risk of diabetes and obesity. Furthermore, the sugars in fruit also come hand in hand with a range of vitamins, minerals and antioxidants that are extremely beneficial to our health. Fruit has always been a nutritious part of the human diet, and there is no reason for it not to carry on that way.

White / Brown Sugar

Sugar, on the other hand, is quite rightfully demonised by virtually all nutritionists, doctors, and health professionals. Once touted as a ‘healthy, low calorie way to lose weight,’ we can now pretty much all agree that table sugar should be avoided wherever possible, given how it has virtually no nutritional value and skyrockets our blood sugar thanks to it’s high glycemic index (GI).   Both white and brown sugar come from the sugar cane, and whilst brown sugar retains some of the molasses, white sugar has these stripped away. Some people turn to brown sugar because they believe it to be healthier than its paler counterpart, but in reality there is very little nutritional difference given the high levels of processing both forms undergo. As we discussed earlier, when sugar is refined it makes it very difficult to measure a caloric response thanks to the ease of consumption. As such, we are now consuming far more sugar than would ever have been possible before agriculture, which is leading to a world riddled with blood sugar imbalances, obesity, diabetes and candida. Too much sugar of any kind can lead to health issues, but as white and brown sugar will give you the least nutritional value per calorie, it would be in your best interest to avoid added sugar wherever possible. But if that’s the case, what about natural sweeteners?

Honey, Maple Syrup, Coconut Sugar and Molasses

Honey, Maple Syrup, Coconut Sugar and Molasses are considered ‘more natural’ sweeteners as they are unrefined and, as such, come packaged with beneficial nutrients, phytonutrients and enzymes. Out of the four, honey has the longest history in the human diet, and would have provided a fantastic source of energy for hunter gatherer communities, providing they could get their hands on it. In fact, there are still tribes today where honey represents a significant component of their diet, such as the Hadza hunter-gatherers in Tanzania, who remain in remarkably good health despite a diet that could raise a few eyebrows due to it’s sugar content. Whilst honey is composed almost entirely from fructose, glucose and water, it does contain beneficial enzymes, phytonutrients and antioxidants. Studies have shown that these antioxidants help to reduce inflammation and decrease HDL (bad) cholesterol whilst increasing LDL (good) cholesterol. Raw honey also has naturally antibacterial and antiviral compounds, and can help reduce allergies. When choosing honey, be sure to source one that is raw, unpasteurised, and where possible, local, for maximum benefits. Molasses, the ‘leftover’ product of sugar production, contains all the vitamins and minerals found in the sugar cane. Whilst not a ‘nutrient dense’ product when compared to things like fruits or vegetables, molasses does provide a good source of minerals calcium, magnesium, iron and potassium. Maple syrup and coconut sugar also contain trace amounts of vitamins and minerals, and although they are not as beneficial as honey and molasses, they are both lower GI than table sugar, with coconut sugar having a GI value almost half that of table sugar. If you have a sweet tooth, it is without doubt that these four sweeteners make more sensible choices than table sugar. Simple changes such as swapping sugar in your tea for a teaspoon of molasses, or baking with coconut sugar, are excellent places to start. That said, it is still important to look on these sweeteners as ‘treats’ that are consumed every so often, rather than making them a part of your daily diet.

Agave Nectar

Whilst many people would group agave nectar in the ‘safe sweetener’ category, we’re not so sure. Taken from the sap of the blue agave plant native to Mexico, which also makes tequila, agave nectar can contain up to 90% fructose – and very little else. We discussed fructose earlier, and concluded that, whilst fine when naturally packaged in fruit, such high levels of fructose in isolation should be avoided. Whereas 100g of blueberries, for example, contain about 7.4g of fructose packaged with fibre, water and many beneficial nutrients, the same amount of agave contains up to a whopping 90g fructose. Unlike other sweeteners like maple syrup and honey, agave has it’s beneficial enzymes removed to stop it fermenting and turning into tequila in your cupboard. Metabolically and nutritionally speaking, therefore, agave nectar is very similar to high fructose corn syrup, considered one of the biggest offenders in the whole food industry. Whilst a little agave won’t hurt you, we’ve opted against including it in the ‘acceptable sweetener’ list.

Stevia

As we leave the territory of natural sweeteners, we come into a market that provides a source of much debate: natural sugar substitutes. Out of these, stevia is perhaps the most popular. Although only approved in the EU in 2011, stevia has rose to popularity for providing sweetness (said to be up to 300x sweeter than sugar) without any calories or carbohydrates. Many healthy recipes now call for a couple of drops of stevia rather than sugar, and even manufacturers of nutrition products like protein and greens blends have taken to using it to provide sweetness without additional calories. But is it safe? Unfortunately, given the fairly recent arrival of stevia in the EU and America, there are not a great deal of studies to allow us to form a concrete opinion either way. Until more research of the effects of stevia on humans comes to light, we’re sitting on the fence with this one! One potential issue that has been raised with stevia is how the sweet taste without the influx of sugar may confuse our insulin response; conversely, however, one study showed how stevia can actually help control blood sugar, whilst another showed how stevia improved insulin sensitivity in rats. Because of this, the early indications are that stevia may be a particularly good choice for those with diabetes, low insulin tolerances, or issues digesting sugar. From our point of view, we prefer to use a sweetener such as raw honey or maple syrup simply because stevia is really, really sweet – it’s very easy to overdo it when not following a recipe! The key here is balance – if you like the taste of stevia, and you notice no ill effects from consuming it, then keep doing what you’re doing. Just be sure to keep an eye out for new studies as they come out, as we’re still learning about stevia and as such should be open to new research.

Xylitol

Much like stevia, xylitol is an all-natural sweetener (this time derived from tree bark) that contains very few calories and almost zero sugar, and is treated by the body as an indigestible carbohydrate, similar to fibre. Xylitol doesn’t raise blood glucose after consumptionand is actually recommended by dentists due to the benefits it offers for oral health. Xylitol has been shown to increase tooth whiteness and decrease the risk of cavities. Furthermore, xylitol can not be used as a food source for common plaque forming oral bacteria as sugar can – instead, it actively inhibits the growth of these bacteria. Excessive consumption of xylitol can produce laxative effects, so use with caution. Natural sweeteners like xylitol are an excellent step to take to decrease your sugar intake, but that doesn’t mean you should consume the same amount!

Artificial Sweeteners

As we delve deeper into the world of sweeteners, the water gets a little murkier. Artificial sweeteners such as aspartame and sucralose are also free from sugar and calories, but evidence suggests we would be best to avoid them wherever possible. Aspartame, the most studied artificial sweetener, has come up against a lot of opposition ever since it was first synthesised in 1965, but research hasn’t been significant enough to warrant a ban – yet. One studyin the 1980s linked aspartame consumption in rats with the formation of brain tumours; however, this has since been challenged a number of times. Another study reported a slight increase in the risk of Hodgkin lymphoma and multiple myeloma in males but not in females; but again, this has since faced vocal opposition. Sucralose has been the subject of less research, although a study has linked it to a decrease in red blood cells. A recent study has also indicated that artificial sweeteners could actually impair glucose tolerance. The study indicates that they do so by changing the composition and function of our gut bacteria, leaving us with an impaired ability to digest and utilise glucose. Another study supports this argument, which showed that rats who are fed with artificial sweeteners gained weight faster than rats who were fed with glucose or sucrose. Human studies have also been shown to correlate; when used in liquid form, artificial sweeteners are so sweet that they can mess with our bodies’ metabolic signals. Our brains expect such sweetness to equal caloric density, so when these calories aren’t provided, our bodies aim to compensate and actually begin to crave more calories. Whilst one would think that consumption of calorie free sweeteners would lead to an overall reduction in calories due to the sugar that they replace, studies have shown this not to be the case; rather, participants who consumed calorie free sweeteners in place of sugar actually consumed more calories in total. When it comes to artificial sweeteners, we think that the alarming number of studies linking them to adverse health effects provide ample reason to avoid them. They have not been in the human diet long enough to be subject of long term research, but if anything, this uncertainty should provide even more reason to exercise extreme caution. If you’re anything like us, the word ‘artificial’ should be enough to put you off on it’s own.

What to do?

Unlike thousands of years ago, sweet doesn’t necessarily mean ‘safe’ these days. On the other hand, unlike sugar free activists would have you believe, sweet doesn’t mean ‘toxic’ either. As with everything, the key is balance. Avoiding anything sweet would be soul crushingly boring – can you imagine life without the joys of fresh fruit, sweet potatoes or raw chocolate? In moderation, sweetness is perfectly healthy – whilst many people should probably consume less sweet things, there is absolutely no reason to shun them from our diets completely unless we are facing a metabolic condition that dictates we do so. Fruit can (and arguably, should) be eaten regularly. Honey and molasses offer a range of health benefits, whilst maple syrup and coconut sugar are perfectly safe. Stevia and xylitol are great choices for diabetics and those with impaired insulin sensitivity. By avoiding the artificial and highly processed stuff, we can all enjoy a little sweetness in moderation and be completely healthy whilst doing so. [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Are all forms of sugar created equal? Does sweetness have a place in a healthy diet? And should you use honey, agave, or maple syrup? Let's find out.

item.title: Raw Macadamia, Maca and Cacao Protein Balls
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
If I had to pick a favourite nut, it would have to be the macadamia. Whilst I love the versatility of the almond, the smokiness of the pecan and the creaminess of the cashew, there is just something about the macadamia that ticks all of the boxes. It’s delightfully buttery; when you bite through the exterior, it practically melts in your mouth. It has a subtle yet indulgent flavour, meaning it pairs well with just about anything sweet – blueberries, coconut, and chocolate. Especially chocolate. Given the high fat content of the macadamia, it is extremely easy to whizz into nut butter. No need for toasting – simply throw raw macadamias into just about any food processor, whiz for 5 – 6 minutes, and bingo: one of the most indulgent nut butters imaginable, packed full of vitamins, minerals and healthy fat. After whipping up another batch of macadamia butter, I decided it would make the perfect base to a recipe that I have been perfecting for a while – raw cacao and maca protein balls. I’ve been looking for ways to get more maca in my diet, as it’s a nutritional powerhouse, rich in B vitamins, zinc, iron, magnesium and phosphorus. Whilst it has quite a distinct flavour on it’s own, it pairs incredibly well with raw chocolate, giving an almost caramel like flavour. Throw in the creamy, indulgent texture of macadamia butter, and I just knew this recipe would be a winner. The protein in these balls comes from one of my favourite protein powders, Sunwarrior Warrior Blend. I chose this because it has a complete amino acid profile and a very neutral taste, which meant that it was able to bump up the protein content without compromising the flavour whatsoever. Just about any protein powder would work here however, providing it’s unflavoured. Whilst these little snacks looked incredibly healthy and delicious on paper, did they work out as well as I had hoped? You bet they did. They are a mixture of creamy and chocolaty texture, with a caramel like finish and melt in your mouth. They’re perfect as travel companions, as a snack between meals, or even enjoyed as a healthy dessert. Here’s how they’re made:

Raw Macadamia, Maca and Cacao Protein Balls Makes 12 - 14

  • 1 cup macadamia nuts
  • ¼ cup unsweetened desiccated coconut (plus another ¼ cup for rolling)
  • ¼ cup raw maca powder
  • 1 tbsp coconut oil
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior Warrior Blend
  • 2 tbsp cacao powder
  • 1 tsp raw honey (or maple syrup to make vegan)
  • ½ tsp vanilla extract
  • ½ tsp cinnamon
  • ¼ tsp nutmeg
  • Pinch Himalayan Rock Salt

1. In a food processor, whizz your macadamias for 5 to 6 minutes until they turn to a velvety butter like consistency. You may need to get a spatula and scrape the sides every so often if they stick. Pour the contents into a large mixing bowl.

2. Add all remaining ingredients to the bowl with the macadamia butter, except the additional ¼ cup shredded coconut. Lay this out in a separate bowl, ready for coating the balls in.

3. Use your hands to mix well. When all ingredients are combined, roll into balls.

4. Before coating in the desiccated coconut to finish. Transfer the balls to a plate, and store in the refrigerator. Enjoy!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Raw Macadamia, Maca and Cacao Protein Balls - Vivo Life
These delicious, high protein truffles have a melt in the mouth texture, with a rich chocolate flavour and a caramel finish

item.title: Keep Away from BPA
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
Bisphenol A, more commonly known as BPA, is a chemical found in many hard plastics and is used to make epoxy resin, which lines many food and drink products. But the use of BPA doesn’t end here; it is regularly used in medical and safety equipment, cars and other forms of transportation, and electronics such as TVs and smart phones. BPA is probably something you’ve heard of, as in recent years it has been the subject of much controversy and media scrutiny – but just why should you be avoiding it? There are many things that divide opinion amongst the health community: grains, dairy, sunlight exposure, saturated fat; but BPA, or indeed the avoidance of it, is a subject that almost all experts seem to be able to agree on. Although it has been used since the 1950s, it is only in recent years and thanks to a number of clinical studies that the serious dangers associated with the chemical have started to be uncovered. Research is still ongoing, but up to this point, the following information has come to light:
  • BPA is an endocrine disruptor – meaning it interferes with the production and utilisation of our body’s natural hormones. BPA has been shown to imitate our own body’s hormones, causing reproductive disorders such as impaired fertility in women1 and erectile dysfunction in men2. BPA also interferes with the function of the thyroid and adrenal glands, which can affect metabolism and cause weight gain3. On a laboratory test in mice, relatively small amounts of BPA reduced insulin sensitivity and accelerated the formation of fat cells – the combination of insulin and BPA showed a staggering 1300% increase in fat levels, compared with a 150% increase with insulin alone. Bad news for the ‘soft drinks’ industry.
  • BPA raises the risk of heart disease and diabetes4
  • BPA has been linked to potential problems with memory, learning and brain function. In a study conducted on primates, researchers linked BPA exposure to loss of connections between brain cells5, whilst it has also been connected with depression and behavioural difficulties in humans when exposed at an early age.6
  • Babies, infants, and young children are thought to be especially sensitive to BPA, which has seen the chemical banned in baby bottles in the EU and Canada. However, high BPA levels in pregnant women has alarmingly been associated with abnormalities in their infant.7
  • Studies have also linked BPA exposure to asthma and other respiratory problems8, as well as increasing the risk of breast cancer9.
If the mounting evidence against human BPA exposure wasn’t enough, BPA is also a damaging environmental toxin. Exposure to BPA has been shown to undermine the reproduction and development of all animal groups studied, whilst also being toxic to marine life and found to induce genetic abnormalities in amphibians and crustaceans. BPA is also a major soil pollutant, which can interfere with nitrogen fixation at the roots of plants. Indeed, the evidence is pretty conclusive against a chemical that public authorities consider to be safe in small doses. ‘Safe’ BPA levels have been set, but in the light of new studies, there are growing calls from leading health experts to have these reviewed. Until authorities start to take more serious action against companies that use the chemical, how do we go about minimising exposure?

What to do

Whether we like it or not, BPA is a part of modern life; with the use of electronics and cars for most people on a daily basis, it is almost impossible to avoid it entirely. That said, we can all take steps to reduce our exposure to BPA - especially when it comes to the BPA that we consume, as this is by far the most problematic form that we encounter. Perhaps the most simple strategy for avoiding BPA (whilst also optimising your health), is to avoid foods that come in a pack wherever possible. Focus on real, fresh, minimally processed foods; fruits, vegetables, meat, fish, eggs, nuts, seeds. A recent study showed the dramatic results this can have – when switching to a ‘fresh food’ diet, the 20 test subjects showed a staggering reduction in BPA levels: an average of 60% in just three days10. When purchasing foods with plastic packaging or in cans, choose certified BPA free wherever possible. A growing number of companies are now beginning to recognise the demand for BPA free products, which has seen a significant rise in the number of certified BPA free products available today. Whilst it is easier now than any time in the last 50 years to minimise BPA exposure, there will be times when it is still not possible – but simple steps in the right direction are enough to make a difference. On the occasions you do purchase plastic, a word of warning: BPA risks increase when the plastic is exposed to heat or radiation, so avoid microwaving plastics or leaving plastic bottles out in the heat. Simple changes like swapping plastic water bottles for glass, or plastic lunchboxes for stainless steel, can make a world of difference to your BPA levels, and consequently, your health. Hopefully, as research against BPA continues to mount, it will become less and less prevalent in our food industry. Until that point, be aware of the risks, make informed decisions based on your knowledge, and you won’t have much to worry about.   Sources: 1 http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/264158.php 2 http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/170540.php 3 http://www.jlr.org/content/43/5/676.full 4 http://www.oehha.org/Prop65/public_meetings/pdf/BPAcomment11h.pdf 5 http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/120264.php 6 http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0013935113001126 7 http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2011-05/sc-sfh051111.php 8 http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/releases/179318.php 9 http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/03/140306163359.htm 10 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/?term=10.1289/ehp.1003170 [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Keep Away from BPA - Vivo Life
What is BPA? And why should you avoid it? Find out all you need to know here.

item.title: 6 ways to boost your immunity
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
Let’s face it – unless you really hate your job, no one likes being ill. A stuffy nose and a pounding head is one thing, but it’s the social implications that really get us down. Winter, amongst all the riches and splendour that it brings, is the peak time for illness and infection. But why is this season so problematic for people with low immunity? Arguably, it is not down to the cold weather itself as our core body temperature remains pretty much the same even when the external temperature drops; rather it is the effects of the colder weather that see such an onset of colds and flu. Colder weather means more time indoors, which means lower vitamin D levels, and more time in an enclosed air system with others, increasing the chances of catching whatever nasties they may be carrying. Cold weather also causes dry mucosa (mucus glands) in the back of the throat and sinuses, an environment in which viruses such as the common cold are more likely to be able to take up residence and start growing. But fear not – there are steps we can take to boost our immunity and lower our risk of infection, no matter what time of year here are some of the most crucial things you can do to avoid falling ill this winter.

Sleep

Adequate sleep is essential for so many aspects of our health, with the function of our immune system being one of the most notable. Sleep is when our immune systems are most active; when human growth hormone (HGH) is released and our cells repair and regenerate. Ever had the flu and felt almost comatose throughout the day? This is our bodies’ way of telling us: ‘Go to sleep, I’ve got work to do.’ Arguably, the best thing you can do to boost your immunity is to make sure you are getting eight hours of solid sleep each night, as just a single night of impaired sleep increases systemic inflammation in the body, leaving us with an impaired ability to deal with stressors (for instance, an invading cold or flu virus) the next day1. In one test, 153 people were voluntarily infected with a common cold virus. Those who averaged seven hours of sleep or less each night were almost three times more likely to fall ill than those that slept eight hours or more.

Eat

Ever heard the saying ‘you have to feed a cold’? Whilst this may, in a sense, be true, it’s much more important to focus on the quality of the food you are consuming rather than the quantity. Moreover, we should pay attention to the nutrients we are consuming in times of health, in order to avoid falling sick in the first place. To keep your immune system bolstered, pay careful attention to the consumption of several important micronutrients: Vitamins A, C and D (you may wish to consider supplementing Vitamin D in winter), B Vitamins, Zinc and Selenium.
  • Consume plenty of brightly coloured fruits and vegetables for nutrients and antioxidants.
  • Fresh Ginger, Garlic, Lemon and Raw Manuka Honey are four highly beneficial, immune boosting additions to any diet, thanks to their natural anti-viral properties which fight off infections. Try drinking a hot lemon and manuka honey first thing in the morning, drinking fresh ginger tea throughout the day, or adding fresh garlic to meals.
  • Consuming a high quality source of Omega 3 such as salmon, sardines, or a fish oil / EPA + DHA supplement, will also help to lower inflammation and therefore increase our immune response.
  • Due to lack of sun in the winter consider taking a Vitamin D supplement between the months of October and April.
  • Should you unfortunately fall ill, then Echinacea, Propolis and Manuka honey will all help to relieve cold & flu symptoms.

Take a probiotic

We’re only just scratching the surface on the significant role that our gut bacteria have on our bodies, but one thing is for sure – when they are happy, healthy and nourished, so are we. Approximately 80% of our immune system is found in our gut, and our gut bacteria play a crucial role in maintaining our mucosal immune system that lines the digestive tract. They also aid in the production of antibodies which fight invading pathogens, making them less likely to multiply and spread disease. Furthermore, a healthy gut bacteria aids in the breakdown of food and the assimilation of nutrients, allowing your body to benefit more from the food we are eating. A high quality probiotic can help populate the gut with healthy bacteria, re-establishing a homeostatic terrain that forms the foundation to good health. Probiotics are especially important if you have ever taken antibiotics, or suffer from digestive issues such as bloating, cramping, constipation or diarrhoea.

Exercise sensibly

Exercise and immunity are unquestionably linked, but their relationship is an interesting one. Regular exercise is key to staying healthy – it increases circulation and the production of white blood cells, improving the rate at which we produce antibodies to fight illness causing pathogens. Sweating, a direct result of exercise, helps to excrete toxins from the body, whilst excess fatty deposits (which exercise helps to combat) have been shown to affect cellular immune function2. However, balance is key when it comes to exercise. Train too hard, and your production of the stress hormone cortisol will rocket, which will in turn supress your immune response. It’s also important that, if you do fall ill, to avoid rigorous exercise rather than attempt to ‘push through’ the fatigue – you’ll only impair your body’s ability to recover, thus leaving you ill for longer.

Wash your hands

To many, it’s common sense – but simply washing your hands regularly is enough to reduce your likeliness of falling ill. By washing your hands regularly, you are less likely to transfer viruses on things that you may touch to your nose and mouth.

Go easy on the alcohol

With the holiday season fast approaching, it’s all too easy to fall into the trap of ‘just one more drink’ with friends, family and work colleagues at various get-togethers you have lined up. Whilst no one expects you to abstain completely (it is Christmas after all!), taking it easy on the alcohol is a sure fire way to lower your risk of illness this winter. Alcohol, like other stressors that enter the body, stimulates a neuroendocrine network known as the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, which stimulates the production of the stress hormone cortisol. This stress hormone is then transmitted throughout the body in the blood, where it suppresses our inflammatory and immune response3. When alcohol itself is absorbed into the bloodstream, it lowers the concentration of white blood cells, responsible for defending the body against unwanted infections (i.e disease). What’s more, alcohol interferes with our natural circadian rhythm and sleep quality (the importance of which we discussed earlier) and dehydrates our cells, thus weakening our immune response even further. We understand that the majority of people won’t be tee-total throughout the winter, but moderating your alcohol intake to a sensible level, and taking adequate steps to rehydrate and recover when you do drink, will help you avoid getting sick. After all, who wants to spend Christmas Day in bed with the flu? There are many, many factors that affect the delicate balance of our immune system, and there is certainly no short cut to unwavering immunity against all diseases. In general, our immune system is a pretty clear indicator of our overall health – that is, the more unhealthy our lifestyle, the more likely we are to fall ill. There’s no hidden secret: eat well, sleep soundly, care for your body, and your immune system will thank you. Sources 1)         http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3548567/ 2)         http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/208/8/1194.full 3)         http://pubs.niaaa.nih.gov/publications/arh26-4/257-263.htm [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sore head? Runny nose? Here are 6 easy ways to boost your immunity this winter.

item.title: Ten reasons to drink more water
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: Stop for a minute and think – how would you feel if you hadn’t had anything to drink, all day? The chances are you have never let yourself feel this way; we are incredibly lucky to have a readily available source of clean, safe water to drink just about anywhere we go, meaning that thirst (for most people, thankfully) has never become a life or death situation. Nonetheless, a surprising majority of us spend much of our day in a state of semi-dehydration; and whilst this may not manifest itself in life threatening situations, it is undoubtedly affecting the way our bodies look, feel, and perform. Here are ten reasons you should drink more water, starting today: 1) You’ll think better: When you are dehydrated, your brain is the first thing that suffers. In fact, the brain is made up of approximately 90% water, so it’s not a surprise that when water supply is limited, your brain will not function at full capacity. Staying hydrated will mean more mental clarity, faster decision making, and a better mood. This study by the University of East London shows how water consumption improved exam grades in their students! 2) Your skin will glow: Our skin is the largest organ in our body, so if we’re dehydrated, our skin will be the first to let us know. By providing it with the water it needs, our skin is much more able to repair and regenerate on a cellular level – meaning clearer skin, less dryness, and fewer wrinkles. 3) Your digestion will thank you: Drinking an appropriate amount of water is imperative for good digestion. Water is absorbed into the digestive tract, adding moisture to the stool and making it easier to pass. If you’re having uncomfortable trips to the bathroom, you may well benefit from a couple more glasses of water each day. Studies have shown how staying hydrated can lower our risk of colon cancer by up to 45%. 4) You’ll have healthier kidneys: Our kidneys help to filter waste from our blood and excrete it in our urine. Without an appropriate level of fluids, our kidneys function suffers – leading to a build-up of waste and toxins in the bloodstream. 5) You’ll be more alert: Fatigue and tiredness are one of the most common symptoms of dehydration – so to be more energetic, try drinking more water! 6) You’ll perform better: Our muscle tissues are composed of approximately 75% water, meaning that dehydration will significantly impair your performance levels when training or competing. Water helps to oxygenate the blood and aids the transportation of nutrients to muscle cells, so it’s crucial to anyone with athletic or performance goals. When you’re properly hydrated, your muscles will also appear fuller – great news for those with tickets to the gun show. 7) You’ll get injured less: Water benefits the joints by softening and hydrating cartilage, meaning less chance of spraining or straining delicate parts of the body like the knees, shoulders and elbows. Drinking water will also help to alleviate joint pain and muscle soreness after a workout. 8) You’ll get sick less often: Drinking water boosts the immune system by helping to flush out toxins and transport nutrients around the bloodstream. It will also speed the body’s natural healing process, meaning when you do fall ill, you’ll bounce back more quickly. 9) Your sugar cravings will subside: By improving your digestive system and detoxification pathways, your gut will be carrying less bad bacteria – meaning fewer cravings for sugar. By keeping hydrated, you’ll also feel fuller for longer, meaning less sugary snacks in between meals. Good news for your waistline. 10) You’ll save money! By swapping soft drinks, tea and coffee for a good old glass of water, you’ll save a surprising amount of money each week. If you were spending £2 on a coffee twice per day, switching to water will save you a staggering £1,460 each year! How to make water more appealing Despite water’s incomparable health benefits, a culture of tea, coffee, soft drinks and fruit juice has meant many people find water ‘bland’ or ‘boring’– so if you’re struggling to drink enough water on it’s own, consider making it more appealing by using one of the following methods: - Add a wedge of lemon or lime: A small addition of a little citrus to your glass of water can make a world of difference. Not only does it add a zesty taste, you’ll also get a boost of vitamin C from the juice and a dose of essential oils from the skin of the fruit. - Add cucumber, sliced pear, mint, ginger – or all of the above! Thinly sliced fruits and herbs added to a glass of water significantly improve the flavour, whilst also adding their own unique health benefits. Ginger, for example, helps stimulate the production of digestive juices, whilst cucumber is naturally detoxifying and helps purify your skin. For best results, fill a large jug of water with your favourite fruits and herbs, cover and leave overnight, before enjoying it the next day. - Drink herbal tea: Whilst ‘regular’ tea and coffee should be limited as the caffeine content can dehydrate you further, herbal tea is a fantastic way to enjoy warm, deliciously flavoured beverages and hydrate yourself at the same time. You can also make your own herbal iced tea – simply brew for twice as long as normal before chilling in the fridge and serving over crushed ice! Unsure of how much water you should be drinking each day? Check out our FREE Daily Water Calculator! [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ten reasons to drink more water - Vivo Life
Here are ten reasons you should drink more water, starting today!

item.title: Prebiotics and Probiotics – What Are They?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
Probiotics and prebiotics. With both words set apart by just a single differing letter, it’s no surprise that they are so commonly confused. As you may know, they both relate very closely to the health of our guts; which, in turn, relate very closely to our overall health. But what are they? Where do you find them? And how can they help you improve your gut health? Let’s take a look at them side by side.

Probiotics

Out of the two, probiotics probably receive more attention by the mainstream health media. Put simply, a probiotic containing food or supplement is something that contains live bacteria that are beneficial for our gut health. Most people now associate probiotics with little bottles of drinking yoghurt and expensive supplements; however, right the way throughout our evolution, almost every traditional society has unwittingly consumed probiotics through fermented foods. It turns out, these fermented foods may well be the missing link in our diets today. And, as such, this missing link is the reason that so many of us are now taking probiotic supplements to maintain a healthy digestive system. The human race have evolved eating fermented foods; before the days that pineapples could be shipped in from Costa Rica throughout the year, traditional societies preserved their seasonal produce using methods of fermentation. Not only did this method mean that they could enjoy seasonal vegetables such as cabbage, beets and carrots year round, it actually enhanced the nutritional profile of the food, with the content of certain vitamins (particularly B vitamins) proven to be much higher in fermented foods than their fresh equivalent. Fermenting foods also saw the production of digestive enzymes, which when eaten as part of a meal, assisted in the breakdown of the other foods that it was eaten with. And of course, most notably, probiotics were formed; the beneficial live bacteria that ensure our digestive system is able to properly break down and absorb the food that we eat. Unfortunately, as we have evolved and fresh produce is now available year round, our need for fermentation has all but vanished. Our digestive system’s need, however, has remained the same – one of the most notable reasons that so many of us are lacking in good bacteria. More about fermented foods Recent awareness of the benefits (and amazing taste!) of fermented foods has seen a rapid growth in their availability. Delicious sauerkrauts and kimchis are popping up in the refrigerators of health food shops, whilst probiotic rich beverages such as kombucha and kefir are becoming the latest ‘superdrinks’ loved by nutritionists and celebrities alike. When buying fermented foods like sauerkraut, make sure you are doing so from the refrigerator section, and that it says ‘unpasteurised’ or ‘raw’ on the jar. You can find long life pickles and sauerkrauts on the shelves, but these have been pasteurised, meaning all of the beneficial bacteria have been lost. Even better, why not make your own? They are incredibly simple and cheap to do; all you need is some vegetables, some water, some salt and an air tight jar to get started. Fermented beverages are a little more difficult and require a ‘started culture’ to get going – but if you have the time and patience, there are plenty of recipes out there! If time, lack of availability or a dislike of the taste mean that you can’t get on board with fermented foods, then taking a high quality probiotic is highly advisable, especially if you suffer from any kind of digestive complaints. Look for one with multiple strains of bacteria, as this will help ensure that you have a diverse gut population that more accurately replicates one of our ancestors. And, if by now you haven’t already heard of some of the amazing benefits that a healthy gut bacteria offer, we’ll list our favourites:
  • Improved digestion
  • Better mood (less mood swings and irritability)
  • More balanced blood sugar
  • Greater metabolic conditioning
  • Clearer skin
  • More mental clarity
  • A stronger immune system
  • Greater energy
  • Reduced (or completely removed) symptoms of IBS
In fact, our gut bacteria support virtually all aspects of our health. Without them, we couldn’t survive – it’s that simple. Now we know what the gut bacteria do for us, let’s examine what we can do for them. Enter, prebiotics.

Prebiotics

So you’ve loaded up on sauerkraut and kombucha, you’re eating Greek yoghurt (or dairy free equivalent) regularly, and you’ve added a high quality probiotic to your daily diet. You’ve got a wide range of good bacteria making their way into your colon; but in order for them to thrive, they’re going to need feeding. Think of it as having your own little farm; if you want your livestock to thrive, you’ll need to give them the best food that you can. This food is commonly referred to as a ‘prebiotic.’ Prebiotics are the fuel that allow our beneficial gut bacteria to thrive. Thankfully, prebiotics are found packaged in some very delicious foods, and if you eat your fair share of fruits and vegetables, you’ll probably be eating them without knowing it. Soluble fibre is an excellent prebiotic; think potatoes, sweet potatoes, squash, yams, bananas, or most other starchy fruits and vegetables. Then there’s inulin and oligofructose, found in onions, garlic, leeks, chicory, Jerusalem artichoke and asparagus. And finally, resistant starch, found in cooked and cooled potatoes, beans and other legumes, and green bananas. Whilst highly nutritious to humans, all of these foods have a very small portion that our own digestive systems do not break down; our gut bacteria feed on it instead. This provides them with the energy that they need to carry out their everyday functions, from regulating our immune system to helping us absorb nutrients from food. Good news for them, and as we discussed earlier, good news for us, too. Besides eating prebiotic containing foods (which you should be doing anyway), other things we can do to support our gut bacteria include regular exercise and managing our stress levels. Turns out, they’re very sensitive creatures, and when we get stressed out, they do too. Ever felt ‘butterflies’ in your stomach when nervous? This just shows how closely linked our guts and our brains are, with many doctors and nutritionists often referring to the ‘gut-brain’ axis when treating patients with mental illnesses such as depression, autism or schizophrenia.

What to do?

A healthy gut is the gateway to a healthy body. And a healthy population of gut bacteria is the gateway to a healthy gut. Want a healthy population of gut bacteria? Consume probiotics regularly; either in the form of fermented foods, or as a probiotic supplement. Ideally, do both, as greater variety leads to a more diverse microbiome and greater digestive capacity. And to support them, eat plenty of prebiotic containing foods like sweet potato, squash, bananas, onions, garlic, beans and peas. Want a little morale boost in your quest for healthy gut flora? Dark chocolate is a prebiotic too.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Prebiotics and Probiotics – What Are They? - Vivo Life
Prebiotics and probiotics. What are they, and why do we need them?

item.title: Why Natural Beauty Products?
item.dc:creator: Immacolata
item.content:encoded:
Powered by Nature - Proven by Science

Gone are the days when ‘natural beauty’ meant smothering your face in a sticky mess of avocado and porridge oats. Today’s natural beauty products are as high tech and luxurious as their chemically laden counterparts.

Once considered somewhat of a niche industry, natural cosmetics have in recent years taken the world of beauty by storm. The reasons why are simple – they really work. By using ingredients that work with, and not against our skin, people around the world are seeing significant, long term results by switching to more natural skincare solutions. And a growing awareness of the benefits have seen young, dynamic cosmetics brands combine pure, natural ingredients with the latest scientific innovations, creating a whole new range of products that deliver outstanding results while truly caring for our skin.

Our philosophy

We launched Vivo Life to provide an online market place for premium quality, natural health products. We believe that the quality of what goes into your system directly correlates with the results you achieve, whether it’s in sporting performance or general health. We use natural beauty products ourselves and more and more of our customers were asking for recommendations. So, we’ve carefully handpicked a select range of brands that share our ethos and deliver top quality results. Just as with our health supplements, we believe that beauty products should deliver on their promises. The brands we’re working with don’t shy away from cutting edge technology or clinical trials. These names have won some of the top beauty awards in the business; they’re pushing the boundaries of what natural ingredients can achieve.

What do we mean by natural?

The word ‘natural’ has become a bit of a buzzword in the cosmetics industry. Favoured by marketing teams, ‘natural’ is actually a pretty hard word to define. Given that most beauty products’ main ingredient is water, it’s quite easy to make a product that is, for example, ‘80% natural. But on most occasions, these natural ingredients are thrown together with no real consideration, only to be combined with the usual mix of irritating chemicals. So we go beyond the word natural and choose with brands that have gone a long way to source some of nature’s most potent ingredients and blend them together in effective combinations that really work.

Top 3 ingredients that you should avoid

Let’s face it; ingredients lists can be pretty baffling. If you’re shopping with us, you can be assured that we’ve done the hard work for you. But, if you’re browsing the high street, here are a few ingredients you might want to steer clear of: Sodium Lauryl Sulphate (SLS) This is used in everything from toothpaste to shampoo, mainly because it’s cheap and gives you a lovely lather, but it’s also a known irritant. SLS can really aggravate skin conditions such as eczema and psoriasis and it doesn’t take much to do it. Just washing shampoo out of your hair can cause a flare up for some people. Those who don’t have skin conditions may also be wise to steer clear of SLS. It is very drying, stripping the oils from your skin and hair, along with the dirt, so can make skin dry, tight and prone to sensitivity. Also look out for the related Sodium Lauryl Ether Sulfate, or Sodium Laureth Sulfate. Phthalates Phthalates soften plastics, making them more pliable. They’re found in everything from cheap loom bands to food packaging. They’re also sometimes used in cosmetics and beauty products, to ‘hold’ colour and scent. Some types of phthalates are known endocrine-disrupters and have been linked to a host of issues, including cancer and the early onset of puberty. The worst types of phthalates have now been banned for use in cosmetics, and although there are some that are still considered ‘safe’ in small doses, we choose to avoid them in our skincare products. Parabens Parabens are preservatives included in products to keep them fresh and free from bacteria. Most beauty brands use a synthetic version of natural parabens found in fruits and vegetables. The debate still rages about the safety of parabens. In some trials, certain types of parabens have been found to mimic oestrogen, leading to fears that they could increase the risk of breast cancer. Parabens have been found in breast tissue when tumours are present, but also in control groups. In short, the link has yet to be scientifically proven, but some people prefer to err on the side of caution, leading to many natural brands avoiding them. Simplicite, for example, don’t use synthetic parabens in their products, stating, “There are so many better alternatives available now that there is rarely a need to use them.” Other brands dismiss the concerns about parabens as groundless and state that it’s more dangerous not to use them. Liz Earle, for example, have been very outspoken in their reasons for continuing to use parabens, declaring, “Parabens have a long established history of safety and are highly effective, which is why they are so widely used in the food, pharmaceutical and beauty industries.” So the jury is still out. Although the link is yet to be scientifically proven, we prefer ingredients that we can be 100% sure of their long term safety. There are now many alternatives to parabens, meaning there is very rarely a need to use them in our cosmetics. If you do choose to avoid parabens, , look for a product that is labelled as ‘paraben free’ – but if you’re unsure, parabens usually show up as a ‘butyl’ ‘methyl’ or ‘ethyl’ on an ingredients list, also make sure you check what, if anything, has been used instead. Some brands use alcohol, for example, which can be very drying. For a full list of ingredients to look out for in your cosmetics, click here.

What about if the chemicals are in low dosages?

The chemicals found in most skin care products are admittedly in pretty low doses. However, we often end up bombarding our skin with a cocktail of chemicals. It’s been said that the skin of an average woman has to cope with more than 500 chemicals a day. That seems a lot, until you consider the long ingredients lists of your face cream, shower gel, body cream, make-up, laundry detergent and household cleaning products, not to mention airborne pollutants such as exhaust fumes. While the jury is still out on whether this cocktail can cause serious health complications, it’s probably not giving your skin the TLC it needs. While we don’t want to wrap ourselves in bubble wrap, avoiding harsh chemicals in our beauty products seems a bit of a no-brainer. And, thankfully, these days it’s not a case of choosing between natural and scientific. Many of the most exciting, cutting edge brands around today have chosen to go the natural route. You no longer have to opt for short-term results over long-term gain – you really can have it all.

Ready to get started?

At Vivo Life we have carefully hand-picked a select range of natural beauty options that deliver outstanding, long term results without any unwanted side effects. No longer should you have to choose between looking great and feeling great – shop with us, and you really can have the best of both worlds. Shop by Category: Shop easily by your chosen category and discover the right products for you! Accessories - Hand & Body Care - Make Up - Sun Protection - Dental Care - Hair Care - Personal Hygiene Shop by Concern: Whatever your skin concern, we're here to help. Acne/Spot Prone Skin - Anti Ageing / Firming - Damaged Hair - Dry Hair/Scalp - Dry Skin - Eczema / Psoriasis - Oily Skin - Rosacea - Skin Brightening - Sensitive Skin - Skin Balancing

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Why should you choose natural beauty products over their synthetic alternatives?
Why Natural Beauty Products? - Vivo Life

item.title: A Fresh Approach
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded:
We get it - shopping for health products can be a real minefield. You see, we've been there ourselves. There are thousands of different supplements on the market today all claiming to make you stronger, leaner, faster, healthier and more beautiful than ever before. And as a result, it’s become harder than ever to make the right decisions. In today’s climate where sexy marketing buzzwords glide through EU labelling loopholes with ease, just about anyone can refer to their product as being ‘healthy,’ even when the reality is quite the opposite. So how do we know who to trust? That’s where we come in. We founded Vivo Life to cut through the masses of health products and provide like-minded folk with a carefully selected range that they can truly trust. Every single one of the items we stock is wholesome, effective, sustainable and junk-free. More importantly, they all actually do what they say on the packaging.
  Our guiding motto is simple. If we wouldn’t use it ourselves, we certainly won’t sell it to you"
Our aim is to provide a one-stop-shop for high quality, natural, organic products made by only the most trustworthy companies. No longer should you have to spend hours scouring the internet for natural health and beauty products that match up to your values – at Vivo Life, we’ve done the hard work for you.

Cutting to the chase

As a way of making the Vivo store as transparent as possible, we have created a unique set of icons to enable our customers to make empowered decisions without worrying about having to do the research yourself. Whenever you click on a product in our online store, you’ll find a clear set of icons telling you it’s unique characteristics, allowing you to make the right choice for your health and lifestyle. Avoiding gluten? Look for the Gluten Free icon. Want to build muscle? Keep an eye out for the High Protein icon.

Certifications

Many of our products are certified by leading international health and wellness organisations as a testament of their quality and integrity. Whether they are approved by the Vegan Society or certified organic by the Soil Association; to achieve these certifications, products have to undergo rigorous testing and meet strict selection criteria. We think it's only fair to display them loud and clear on our product pages. About our brands There are thousands of health and fitness brands out there today, but very few that deliver on their promises. All of the brands we support are tried, trusted and highly respected, and share our company values for quality, integrity and sustainability. To allow you to get to know the people behind your favourite products, we’ve created personalised brand bios for every single brand featured in the Vivo store. Here’s an example of how this information is displayed: No matter how big or small, if a brand doesn’t meet our strict quality and integrity standards, we won’t sell their products to you. For a full list of all the brands we support, click here. Nutritional information The most important part of a product are the things that go in it. For this reason, we have chosen to display clear nutritional information on each and every product we sell, allowing you to make the right choices for your health and wellbeing. Ingredients and nutritional information is displayed in an easy to read format enabling you to decide if a product is right for you:

Trust us

We understand that with so much choice out there it can be hard to choose the right products for you. We believe in our products so much that we offer a 30 day money back guarantee on everything we sell. If our products don't meet your expectations, you can return them for store credit. No questions asked.

Get rewarded

We never take our customers for granted. Which is precisely why we created Vivo Rewards, to enable you to earn money back every time you shop with us. As a member of Vivo Rewards, you can benefit from the following perks:
  • For every purchase at Vivo Life we give you 5% back
  • When you sign up to Vivo Life we give you 100 points (£1.00)
  • When you refer a friend we give you 500 points (£5.00) 
If you are not already a Vivo member, then simply sign up at checkout by ticking the 'sign me up' button or click here to sign up now.

What else is there?

We’ve also created additional resources such as the VBlog and our free user guides, along with fantastic tools such as the Daily Macronutrient Calculator and the Daily Water Calculator. Like Vivo itself, these were created with a clear objective in mind: helping you to achieve your true health potential. Trust us – there’s nothing more fulfilling in the world.

Meet us

To find out more about the people behind Vivo Life, view the Vivo Team page!

HOW TO GET STARTED

Sign up to our newsletter now to get started. You’ll be the first to know about the our best tips, recipes, product reviews, special offers at Vivo HQ. Shop by your Values: Whether you’re gluten free, dairy free, vegan or paleo, we’ve got the right products to suit your diet and lifestyle. Cut out the junk and go straight to the good stuff! Click any of the icons below to get started!
