item.title: Top 10 beauty Ingredients to AVOID!
item.dc:creator: Britanie
item.content:encoded:
Your skin is the largest and the thinnest organ.  Only 1/10th of an inch separates you from all kinds of toxins and chemicals. Your skin is highly permeable, allowing what you apply to your skin access to your bloodstream and the rest of your body.

Here are my top 10 ingredients to avoid - so before you purchase anything, you might want to check the label for the following ingredients:

  • Parabens. One of the main culprits in conventional skincare are parabens that can be found in many mainstream deodorant, shampoos, facial cleansers, as well as makeup. Used as a preservative to maintain shelf life of a product, oestrogen-mimicking compounds in these chemicals have been alarmingly linked to a number of health conditions, including breast cancer and infertility. Ideally, look for a product that is labelled as ‘paraben free’ – but if you’re unsure, parabens usually show up as a ‘butyl’ ‘methyl’ or ‘ethyl’ on an ingredients list. Although the link is yet to be scientifically proven, we prefer ingredients that we can be 100% sure of their long term safety. There are now many alternatives to parabens, meaning there is very rarely a need to use them in our cosmetics.
  • Fragrance. I am not referring to naturally based essential oils! the ingredient word listed ‘fragrances’ can be found in perfume, cologne, shampoo and conditioner, moisturisers and body washes. The word, ‘fragrance’ was created in the personal care industry to protect a company’s ‘special formula.’ But this term can contain between 10- 300 different chemicals, many of which have never been tested for safety, which leaves the term wide-open to unsuspecting consumer slathering or spraying hundreds of chemicals that are absorbed into the bloodstream and respiratory tract. And they are known to be hazardous to health, according to the Environmental Working Group (EWG) Skin Deep Database, fragrance mixes have been associated with allergies, dermatitis, respiratory distress, and potential effects on the reproductive system. (If THAT’S not enough to make you look twice into the safety of a purchase!)
  • Triclosan. This widely used antimicrobial chemical is a known endocrine (especially thyroid and reproductive hormone) disruptor. Some studies show that it is also a skin irritant. Triclosan can be found in toothpaste, antibacterial soaps, and many deodorants.
  • Formaldehyde. This preservative is used in many cosmetic products to help prevent bacteria growth, but has been declared as a human carcinogen by the IARC, (The International Agency for Research on Carcinogens). It has been known to cause allergic skin reactions and has been linked to occupational related cancers such as nasal and nasopharyngeal. It can be found in nail polish, shampoo and conditioners, body washes and eye makeup. Formaldehyde is also indentified on label as: Cormalin, Formic aldehyde, Methanol, Methyl aldehyde, Formalin, Urea, Diazolidinyl urea, Imidazolidinyl urea, DMDM hydantoin, Quaternium-15, 2-bromo-2-nitropropane-1,3-diol, and Sodium hydroxylmethylglycinate
  • SLS, SLES ( Sodium lauryl sulfate and Sodium laureth sulfate) These surfactants, used to create a ‘foam’ or ‘lather,’ are found in up to 90 percent of personal care and cleaning products. SLS’s are associated with some skin, lung and eye irritations. Another concern is the potential of interaction with other chemicals to form various carcinogens. These can be found in mascara, acne treatments, shampoo and body washes.
  • Synthetic colours. Derived from coal tar sources or petroleum. If you notice on your product label, FD&C blue1(etc.) or D&C Red 27 (etc), this means artificial colours. Synthetic colours have been suspected to be a human carcinogen and a skin irritant. The European Classification and Labeling considers synthetic colors a human carcinogen.
  • Phthalates These are a group of chemicals used to increase the flexibility and softness of plastic, and are often found in deodorants, perfumes, moisturisers and colognes. The main phthalates in cosmetics and personal care are dibutyl phthalate in nail polish and dimethyl phthalate in hairspray. These are endocrine disruptors and linked to the developments of breast cancer and reproductive birth defects in both males and females. Often these chemicals are not disclosed on a product and/or hidden under the umbrella of ‘fragrance’ that I discussed above! Can be indentified on label as: Benzylbutyl phthalate (BzBP), Di-n-butyl phthalate or Dibutyl phthalate (DBP), Diethyl phthalate (DEP), and sometimes Fragrance
  • Propylene glycol. Propylene glycol is a small organic alcohol used in many products as a skin conditioning agent. It is classified as a skin irritant and penetrator, and has been known to cause dermatitis and hives. Propylene Glycol can be found in various make-ups, hairsprays, shampoos and moisturisers.
  • Sunscreen formula chemicals. Common names are PABA and Benzophenone. Found in sunscreen formulas, these chemicals act as a sunscreen agent to absorb ultraviolet light. However, they are also endocrine disruptors and are believed to be easily absorbed into the bloodstream, where they have been shown to cause cellular damage. Can also be found on labels as: 4-Methyl-Benzylidencamphor (4-MBC), Oxybenzone Benzophenone-3, Octyl-methoyl-cinnamates (OMC), Octyl-Dimethyl-Para-Amino-Benzoic Acid (OD-PABA), Homosalate(HMS)
  • Toluene. Or also listed as benzene, toluol, methylbenzene or phenylmethane. A very potent solvent able to dissolve paint. Can cause nausea and skin irritation. Expectant Mothers should avoid vapours of these chemicals because it may cause development damage in the fetus. Also been linked to immune system toxicity. Can be found in nail polish, hair color and bleaching sunscreen products.
If you doubt that your skin is so absorbent, try rubbing the cut side of a clove of garlic on the sole of your foot and within seconds you will TASTE the garlic….NOT just smell it. That should tell us all something about how easily our bodies are absorbing what we put on it.

item.title: Pre & Post Workout Food and Supplements Guide
item.dc:creator: Salv
item.content:encoded:
At VIVO LIFE We strongly believe that the quality of what goes in your system directly correlates with the results you achieve. When it comes to pre and post workout nutrition, evidence suggests that meal timings do matter. 

PRE-WORKOUT 

Before you work out, it’s important to have amino acids in your bloodstream for your body to convert into muscle tissue. These amino acids can either be consumed in the form of a light meal 2 – 3 hours before training (to allow enough time for the meal to effectively digest), in a protein shake (or equivalent) around an hour and a half beforehand, or from an amino acid formula around 30 minutes before. A protein shake requires less energy to digest than a real food meal, whilst an amino acid formula requires even less than that, as it cuts out the need for our body to convert the protein into the amino acids. Depending on the type of activity you are partaking in, you may wish to consider combining the protein with some carbohydrates to top up your glycogen stores and provide you with energy before training. The type of carbohydrate you consume will depend on the timing of your meal; choose a fast digesting carbohydrate such as fruit or coconut water if you are training within an hour and a half, or a slower digesting carbohydrate such as a sweet potato if you are training within 2 – 3 hours. Here are some examples of pre workout meals, and when they should be consumed to optimise your training.

2-3 HOURS BEFORE WORKOUT:

Solid Food Meal:  125g chicken breast, 200g sweet potato, Steamed broccoli OR Vegan solid food meal 100g quinoa, 150g lentils, 150g sweet potato

OR 1.5 HOURS BEFORE WORKOUT:

Pre-workout shake: 1 scoop of protein powder (such as Organic whey protein, Ezyprotein or Sunwarrior) blended with some fruit (such as a banana, blueberries or pineapple) and coconut water / filtered water  

OR 1.5 HOURS BEFORE WORKOUT:

Amino Acid Formula (BCAA) powder drink or capsules    MCT Oil - can be consumed with juice, water or coffee shortly before your workout for an energy boost Performance boosters – can be taken shortly before a workout to maximise energy levels and endurance’.

POST-WORKOUT  The post workout window is the optimum time to kick-start the recovery process, repair your muscles and replenish your glycogen stores. This window lasts for approximately an hour after your workout, so it is important to take in either a solid food meal or for convenience and ease of digestion, a shake, during this period. Your post workout meal should consist of between 20-40g protein to repair muscles, and approximately double this amount in carbohydrates to replenish glycogen stores and assist in the absorption of amino acids. In your post workout meal, you may wish to consider limiting fat, as this slows digestion and the rate at which the nutrients can reach your muscle cells. Here are some examples of post workout meals:

WITHIN 1 HOUR AFTER TRAINING:

Post workout shake: Favourite protein powder/Amino Acids and Vega Recovery Accelerator blended with a banana and coconut water / filtered water OR your favourite protien powder with banana/dates and coconut water / filtered Post workout solid meal: 125g tuna, 200g rice, broccoli Vegan post workout meal: 125g quinoa, 125g lentils and 150g sweet potatoes   Consume both protein and carbs in the post workout window to repair muscle tissue and replenish glycogen stores  

POWER UP YOUR PERFORMANCE:

Consume a variety of healthy fats throughout the day to maximise energy levels and improve performance. Leading up to your workout, coconut oil / MCT oil provide excellent sources of energy, burning faster and more efficiently than other fats. Adding a teaspoon of coconut oil to your pre workout smoothie, or some MCT oil to your amino acid formula, are both excellent ways to generate an energy boost before training. Also, taking a daily high quality fish oil / omega 3 supplement is a great way to improve recovery and reduce muscle soreness following a workout. This can be taken at any time of day, although ideally not in the pre and post workout windows. WANT TO FIND OUT MORE ABOUT FITNESS NUTRITION? Download out FREE fitness nutrition guide by clicking here. 19 pages of fresh content that will put you ahead of the game. DO YOU LIKE ANY OF THE PRODUCTS YOU SEE? At Vivo Life, we are a small, health-conscious bunch specialising in the online retail of natural products for health & fitness. The aim of Vivo Life is to cut through the masses of health products and provide a select range of only the finest products from trustworthy and reliable brands. Every item we stock is completely junk-free – so no fillers, binders, allergens, parabens, SLS or artificial ingredients. Just wholesome, natural health and beauty products that REALLY work. Click on any of the pictures above and you will be able to purchase them from vivolife.co.uk. Or visit our fitness nutrition section by clicking here, or any of the links below: Muscle Building products Pre-workout Products Endurance Products Recover & Repair Hydrate Products [icegram campaigns="7536"]

item.title: The Vivo Guide to Chocolate
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
The word ‘chocolate’ carries too many negative connotations in modern society. Closely associated with sugar, dairy, and artificial flavourings, there’s no wonder it has a bit of a bad reputation.

But don’t be put off by the stereotypes. In reality, chocolate in it’s raw, unprocessed form, is an extremely nutritious health food, and one that should be enjoyed liberally as a treat for body and soul alike. Raw Chocolate is full of amazing antioxidants, vitamins and minerals, and has been shown to offer a wide range of health benefits. It is also a powerful mood booster – which goes without saying to most chocolate lovers out there! It’s time to put an end to the anti-chocolate brigade, and start to acknowledge this superfood for the nutritional powerhouse it really is. But before we start, let’s take a look at what we mean by ‘raw’ chocolate.

What is chocolate?

‘Chocolate’ as we know it is made using the fruit of the Theobroma Cacao (which literally translates to “Cacao: The food of the gods”), otherwise known simply as the Cacao tree. Twice a year, the rugby ball sized pods are harvested from the Cacao tree, before being split open and the ‘pulp’ removed.   The cacao beans are then separated from the pulp, before being gently pressed to extract the cacao butter. Once the cacao butter is set aside, the beans are then milled into a fine cacao powder, a superfood bursting with antioxidants and minerals such as magnesium, iron and zinc. Raw cacao is recognised as one of the most antioxidant rich foods in the world, with approximately 14 times the antioxidants of blueberries and 27 times the antioxidants of cherries, as determined using the ORAC (oxygen radical absorbance capacity) scale developed by the National Institute of Health in Baltimore, USA. The resulting cacao powder and butter can then be combined, usually with a little sweetener such as coconut palm sugar or agave nectar, to make raw chocolate. Most of the time, however, the cacao undergoes further treatment to turn it into ‘cocoa.’ The cacao powder is heated to high temperatures and undergoes an alkalising process which increases the PH and mellows the flavour. In doing so, however, it loses some of the antioxidants and minerals that make cacao so special. Cocoa certainly isn’t bad for you, but cacao is most definitely better. Cacao generally has a richer flavour than cocoa too, making a noticeable difference to raw chocolate bars and other goodies. Find a high quality, single estate cacao, and you’ll find yourself on a shortcut to chocolate heaven.

The health benefits

You don’t need us to tell you how tasty chocolate is. You already know that nothing compares to the mouthwatering intensity, the heavenly creaminess and the silky smooth finish of a top quality dark chocolate. But you may be surprised to know just how healthy it really is too!
  • It’s an antioxidant powerhouse: Raw Cacao has an ORAC rating of approximately 95,500, making it one of the most antioxidant rich foods on the planet. Antioxidants are our primary defence against cellular aging and disease, crucial for keeping us looking and feeling young and healthy.
  • It’s rich in many important minerals: Most notably magnesium, iron and zinc. These minerals are crucial to maintaining healthy energy levels, immune function, hormonal balance, healthy bones, skin and teeth. Cacao is also an excellent source of sulphur, crucial for healthy hair, skin and nails.
  • It promotes cardiovascular function and heart health: Rich in antioxidant flavonoids and oleic acid, raw chocolate has been shown to lower blood pressure1, improve blood flow2 and reduce LDL cholesterol in the blood3.
  • It benefits digestion: Cacao is an excellent source of soluble fibre, which acts as a prebiotic that feeds our gut bacteria. It has also been shown to stimulate the production of digestive enzymes, said to be the reason it is traditionally enjoyed shortly after a meal.
  • It improves our mood: Whilst this isn’t exactly breaking news to chocolate lovers, it has actually been scientifically proven to have mood boosting properties. It contains a compound called phenylethylamine (PEA), which is a mood enhancer, anandamide, a substance that induces euphoria, and also triggers the release of endorphins (feel good hormones) in the brain.

How to incorporate raw chocolate into your diet?

With the amazing taste and all the health benefits that raw chocolate offers, you’d be foolish not to make it a regular component of your diet. Cacao comes in many forms; powder, butter, nibs and paste, making it an extremely versatile superfood that can be enjoyed in a number of ways:
  • Blend raw cacao powder into smoothies and shakes
  • Make your own delicious hot chocolate using raw cacao powder, coconut sugar, vanilla and non-dairy milk. Or, for an incredibly delicious, ready-made raw hot chocolate, give this a try!
  • Add to non-dairy milk for a home-made chocolate milkshake
  • Add cacao powder to cereal or yoghurt
  • Sprinkle cacao nibs over fruit salads, desserts, or add to trail mix
Perhaps the easiest (and certainly one of the tastiest) ways of upping your consumption of raw chocolate, however, is the humble raw chocolate bar.

What to look for in a chocolate bar?

The number one thing to look for in a chocolate bar is the ingredients list. The vast majority of modern day chocolates are combined with sugar, dairy and artificial flavourings, leaving them almost unrecognisable from the cacao fruit from which they originate. And it is these creations that have undoubtedly created the ‘unhealthy’ stigma associated with chocolate, processed so heavily that they loose virtually all nutritional value. So when it comes to ingredients on the back of your chocolate bar, the simpler the better. The next thing to look for is the cocoa (or cacao) content. This is the good stuff, so the higher the percentage, the better. Ideally, shoot for 70% or upwards, packing more nutrients (and less sugar) into each bite. Last but not least, decide whether you want a raw chocolate or not. Raw chocolate is often more expensive, but in terms of gram for gram nutrients, it actually works out a lot cheaper, and you can get away with a much lower cacao content thanks to the absence of cheap ‘filler’ ingredients such as sugar and dairy. It’s much more full flavoured and intense too, so you’ll often find yourself eating less. If you’re unsure whether your chocolate is raw or not, look for the word ‘cacao’ rather than ‘cocoa’ on the ingredients label. As a guilt free treat for your body and soul, we’d always recommend raw chocolate wherever possible.   As self-confessed raw chocolate fanatics, we’ve assembled a wonderful collection of some of the finest raw chocolate bars on the planet. Check out our range here and get your chocolate fix!

How to make your own raw chocolate

Want to have a crack at making your own raw chocolate? It’s surprisingly simple, needing just a few ingredients and minimal preparation time! Here’s how you do it:
  • Gently melt 70g raw cacao butter and 1 tbsp coconut oil in a glass bowl over a pan of water on a low heat.
  • Once melted, remove from the heat and add 50g raw cacao powder, 2 – 3 tbsp of maple syrup or your favourite liquid sweetener, and ½ tsp vanilla extract.
  • Whisk all ingredients together using a hand whisk and pour into ice cube trays or mini baking cups. Transfer to the refrigerator and leave to set for 2 – 3 hours.
  • Your raw chocolates are now ready!
Want to personalise your chocolate bar? Why not try adding some coarsely chopped nuts and/or dried fruit for a healthy twist on the classic ‘fruit and nut’ chocolate bar, or a few drops of peppermint oil for a delicious mint chocolate. The possibilities really are endless – so get creative and have some fun with it! So there you have it! If you needed an excuse to eat more chocolate, then please consider this article all the permission you need. But put down your Galaxy bars and grab yourself some of the good stuff. Chocolate is well and truly back on the menu.   Sources:
  • http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/81/3/611.full
  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21807659
  • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21559039
[icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Don't be put off by the stereotypes. Raw chocolate is packed with antioxidants, vitamins and minerals, and is a fantastic treat for body and soul alike.

item.title: Cod Liver Oil – The Original Superfood
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
As countless ‘superfoods’ have drifted in and out of the media spotlight, one humble offering has stood the test of time. Whilst not the most glamorous of foods, fish liver oils have been consumed amongst traditional cultures for thousands of years – the two most common being cod and skate liver oils. The ancient wisdom of these cultures has been passed down from generation to generation, with fish liver oils providing a consistent source of nourishment long before science was around to prove the unquestionable health benefits. But just what is it that makes fish liver oil so special?

Fish Liver Oil VS Fish Oil

Nowadays, fish oil is one of the most popular health supplements in the country, with people of all shapes and sizes taking it regularly to support the health of their brains, joints, hearts, blood and skin. The therapeutic anti-inflammatory health benefits of Omega 3 are amongst the most conclusively studied out there, and a high quality fish oil can make an excellent addition to any diet, regardless whether you already consume fish or not. Taking a fish liver oil supplement, however, can offer even further health benefits above and beyond a ‘regular’ fish oil. Fish liver oil has been shown to boost:
  • immunity,
  • fertility,
  • eyesight,
  • digestion,
  • bone and skin health,
  • heart health,
  • joint health
  • brain health.
Before modern advancements in medicine, it’s no surprise that cod liver oil was prescribed for virtually all ailments. Fish liver oil contains a unique balance of nutrients, antioxidants, enzymes and essential fatty acids that have been proven to be highly beneficial to human health. In addition to Omega 3 EPA and DHA, fish liver oil contains the fat soluble vitamins A and D. These nutrients are highly synergistic, which is why they are often found together in food sources such as egg yolks, liver, and sardines. Notably, however, these two vitamins (A & D) are amongst the most common nutrients lacking in our diets today – and deficiencies have risen as consumption of fish liver oil has fallen. Vitamin D, in particular, is hard to source through our diet, with the vast majority of our intake coming from sunlight. This makes Vitamin D deficiency in the winter incredibly common; thus, consuming Vitamin D rich foods such as fish liver oil is an excellent way to stay healthy in the colder months. Vitamin A, in it’s pure form, is also tricky to source; it is often confused with beta-carotene, a precursor of Vitamin A that is found in abundance in many brightly coloured plants but doesn’t replicate the Vitamin A found in animal foods such as liver and egg yolks. If you’re not eating these foods regularly, then cod liver oil again is a fantastic way to increase your intake. When fish liver oil is fermented, it has also been found to contain the Vitamin K2. Often referred to as the ‘missing nutrient’ given it’s fairly recent discovery, Vitamin K2 helps support heart health, prevents blood clotting, builds strong bones and promotes healthy brain function. The recent discovery of Vitamin K2 in fermented fish oil is a prime example of how we still have a lot to learn when it comes to nutrition, but it is equally clear that our ancestors knew a true ‘superfood’ when they saw one.

Fermented Fish Liver Oil

Fish liver oil was traditionally processed by fermentation, as a way of preserving the product long before heat, pressure and chemical extraction methods were invented. Processing by fermentation retains all the powerful nutrients, antioxidants, enzymes and essential fatty acids found in fish liver oil, whilst also making the product more bio-available. Heat extraction, on the other hand, can damage the fragile fatty acids found in the fish oils, causing them to go rancid, whilst degrading the nutritional value and impairing the bio-availability. The process of fermenting fish oil takes 6 months to a year, perhaps the main reason why it is so rarely made in modern society. Through hours of searching, we have found only one brand who continues to process fish liver oil in the traditional way. Step forward, Green Pasture.

Where to buy fermented Fish Liver Oils?

Where the vast majority of ‘health food’ manufacturers continue to prioritise profit margins over quality, Green Pasture’s fermented ‘Blue Ice’ Cod and Skate Liver Oils provide a breath of fresh air. These nutritious oils are made using a traditional fermentation process, just as they would have been made before the industrial food revolution and how traditional cultures would have consumed them for optimum nutritional value. The fish used are wild caught in the Arctic Ocean, where they are the most sustainable and least contaminated with toxins and heavy metals. Green Pasture are the only company that we can find who make traditionally fermented fish liver oils, which is why they are the only brand of fish liver oil we supply. After all, why should we supply cod liver oil that has been highly refined and taken from fish of questionable origin, when there is a much healthier, safer, and more sustainable alternative?

You can purchase both Green Pasture Cod and Skate Liver Oils in three delicious flavours, along with the ‘X Factor’ Infused Coconut Oil here Or, click here for our full list of healthy oils, including high strength omega 3, coconut oil and MCT oil! [[icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Cod Liver Oil – The Original Superfood - Vivo Life
Is cod liver oil the superfood that time forgot?

item.title: Best sources for protein, fats and carbs
item.dc:creator: Salv
item.content:encoded:
It’s time to go right back to basics. We know that we need a healthy balance of carbohydrates and fats to provide energy for our workouts, and that protein is crucial for recovery and building new muscle tissue. We’ve calculated how much of each we need with our daily macronutrient calculator and our daily protein calculator. The next step is to look at the best sources of each nutrient, so we can be sure that we are fueling our bodies as efficiently as possible. Remember, if you eat before you train, be sure to allow at least 2 – 3 hours for meals to digest before you leave. When you’ve finished your workout, eat a balanced meal containing at least 20g protein to kickstart the recovery process.

PROTEIN

Protein provides the building blocks for muscle tissue, and is therefore extremely important for recovery and performance. Organic Meats:
  • Grass fed beef and lamb
  • Free range poultry
  • Outdoor reared pork
  • Wild Game
Free Range, Organic Eggs Wild Caught Seafood:
  • Salmon
  • Sardines
  • Cod
  • Mackerel
  • Haddock
  • Lemon Sole
  • Sea Bass
Easy to Digest Plant Proteins: Note: When relying on plants as your main protein source, make sure that you are combining foods effectively to achieve a complete amino acid profile at each meal
  • Pulses such as lentils and chick peas (ideally soaked and sprouted)
  • Protein rich seeds such as hemp, chia and flaxseed
  • Protein rich algaes such as chlorella and spirulina
Protein Powder A high quality protein powder is an excellent way to fuel your training. They are faster digesting than real food, which accelerates protein synthesis, and they’re also much more convenient to consume straight after a workout.
  • Whey Protein: taken from milk, so only use this if you are tolerant to dairy. Choose cold processed whey protein from grass fed cows.
  • Vegan Protein: Rice, Pea, Hemp or a blend. These are easier to digest for most. Choose organic and cold processed wherever possible.
  • Vivo Favourites: Sunwarrior Warrior Blend, Organic Whey Protein, Ezy Raw Organic Protein, Vega Performance Protein, Revolution Foods - Raw Plant Protein
Amino Acids You can take a BCAA formula approximately 30 minutes before your workout to maximise protein synthesis and prolong your endurance, and after training to boost recovery. Many amino acid supplements are synthetically made, so we choose Ajipure and M.A.P which are derived from a raw vegetable origin.  

CARBOHYDRATES

Carbohydrates provide an efficient energy source and keep our muscle glycogen levels topped up. Starchy Vegetables: Starchy vegetables should always be your go to carbohydrate source. They provide the most nutrition, are easy to digest and provide an excellent source of energy. Examples include:
  • Potatoes
  • Sweet Potatoes
  • Yams
  • Plantains
  • Squash
Fruits: Fruits are also an excellent carbohydrate source, providing faster burning energy than starchy vegetables and ideal for an energy boost before your workouts.
  • Vivo Favourite: Bananas – an excellent carbohydrate source and high in potassium to help prevent muscle soreness. They’re extremely portable too, ideal for popping in the gym bag!
  • Berries: Blueberries, Strawberries, Raspberries, Blackberries
  • Orchard fruits: Apples, pears, plums
  • Tropical fruits: Pineapples, kiwis, mangos, papaya
Properly Prepared, Gluten Free Grains If you choose to eat grains, choose gluten free ones for easy digestion, and prepare them properly by soaking and sprouting before consumption. White rice does not require soaking or sprouting as it is very easy to digest, but don’t rely on it as a regular carbohydrate source as it does not contain any nutritional value!
  • White rice OR Soaked and sprouted brown rice
  • Quinoa
  • Amaranth
  • Buckwheat
Supplements It’s a little difficult to find a good source of carbohydrate supplements as many of them are highly processed and full of junk. A banana is just as portable as supplements, cheaper and just as effective! There are, however, a couple of safe, effective options should you wish to use a carbohydrate supplement:
  • Vega Sport Pre Workout Energiser: Made predominantly from brown rice syrup and coconut nectar, providing a safe energy boost before a workout
  • Coco Hydro Sports: Coconut water powder, a great source of electrolytes and will provide you with 15g carbohydrates per serving.
  • Coconut Water: Not technically a ‘supplement’ but extremely portable and easy to take to the gym!

 

FATS

Fats are a very efficient energy source, and also support hormonal balance and recovery. Saturated Fats: An excellent energy source and crucial for performance and hormonal balance. Good sources include:
  • Vivo Favourite: MCTs – a highly efficient energy source with no highs or lows. Excellent sources include coconut (flesh and oil) and MCT Oil.
  • Grass fed beef and lamb
  • Eggs
Monounsaturated Fats: A great energy source and inflammation buster.
  • Avocados
  • Extra Virgin Olive Oil
  • Macadamia nuts
Omega 3s: Crucial for recovery, joint health and overall performance.
  • Oily fish: sardines, salmon, mackerel
  • Flax seed
  • Chia seed
  • Omega 3 supplement (fish oil or vegan source)
  Want to find out more about fitness nutrition? Download our FREE fitness nutrition guide by clicking here. 19 pages of fresh content that will put you ahead of the game.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What are the best sources of protein, carbohydrates, and fats to fuel your training and sporting performance?

item.title: WHAT SKIN TYPE ARE YOU?
item.dc:creator: Immacolata
item.content:encoded:
Generally speaking, your skin can be placed into 5 skin types; Normal, Dry, Oily, Sensitive and Combination, however these categories do not address the many elements that can change the health and beauty of your skin. If you have a skin disorder such as eczema, psoriasis, acne, and rosacea and so on, these 5 skin types may not strictly apply. What’s more, your skin can change with almost everything from the environment to your stress levels. It is also important to understand that your skin may be more than one skin type, e.g. dry and sensitive. That’s why we are going to discuss and recognise all these factors that can affect your skin type, so you can understand your skin and ensure you match it with the ideal skincare regime that suits your particular needs; working towards healthy, bright and fresh looking skin for a life time. WHAT DETERMINES YOUR SKIN TYPE? As mentioned above, almost everything can influence the look and feel of your skin. Below we’ve listed some of the main components to help you evaluate your skin type, because with this knowledge, it becomes much easier to work out what’s going on with your skin and how you can bring it back into balance.
  • Environment – pollution, climate, prolonged/unprotected sun exposure
  • Stress levels
  • Nutrition
  • Hydration
  • Hormonal changes – pregnancy, menopause, hormone imbalance
  • Medication
  • Skin disorders
  • Skin care products that may not be suited to your skin type
Think back over the past few weeks and consider if any of the above factors could apply to you. Perhaps you have been faced with a particularly stressful period at work, or your nutrition hasn’t been up to its usual standard. Once we have determined what is causing the problem, it becomes much easier to find a solution. ARE YOUR SKINCARE PRODUCTS MAKING YOUR SKIN WORSE? The products you are using may contain ingredients that can be worsening or even causing the very skin change that you are trying to treat. For example many products for oily skin contain alcohol which effectively dries out the skin, however your skin will compensate by creating more oil to moisturise the dryness and irritation that the alcohol has caused! Using these products with problem creating ingredients can make it even more difficult in finding your true skin type; therefore with the aim of understanding the behaviour of your skin, you must work out whether the products you are using are to blame. HERE ARE SOME OF THE MAIN INGREDIENTS THAT CAN CAUSE CHANGES IN SKIN TYPE:
  • Alcohol, Isopropyl (SD-40) – Irritating and drying
  • DMDM Hydantion & Urea (Imidazolidinyl) – Skin reactions and allergies
  • FD&C Color Pigments – Skin irritation and sensitivity
  • Fragrances - allergic rashes, skin discoloration and skin irritation
  • Mineral Oil – premature aging and pore clogging; encouraging acne and other skin disorders.
  • Polyethylene Glycol (PEG) – can change and reduce the skin’s natural moisture mechanisms.
  • Sodium Lauryl Sulfate (SLS) & Sodium Laureth Sulfate (SLES) – Severe skin irritation
TEST YOUR SKIN TYPE Now that we have discussed the controllable elements and the problematic products, you can rule these out in order to get closer in defining your true skin type. Before you look in the mirror, wash your face with a gentle cleanser, making sure that all make up and dirt traces have been removed. Now wait an hour; this time allows your skin to return to its natural state, with its characteristics that reveal your skin type. During this time it is important to not touch your face. When the time is up, pat your face with a tissue, especially over your T-zone; the area on your forehead, nose and chin. Now take a look at the table below: When you have discovered what skin type(s) you really are, you can now make healthier decisions about your skincare regime. To make it even easier for you to choose the right products, we have grouped all products on our website in order of skin type; so you can easily build a collection of the perfect products for you! Read more about your skin type(s) below and see our top tips to help you work in harmony with your skin and leave it visibly healthier than ever before. NORMAL SKIN If you have normal skin it is the ideal balanced skin type, meaning you won’t be prone to regular breakouts, dryness or oiliness. You should find that your skin doesn't naturally suffer too many problems, apart from the occasional issue that arises from controllable elements. Top Tips for normal skin: Although you have the least challenging skin type, it still requires a good skincare regime to clean, protect and moisturise. Sunscreen and anti-aging products will be beneficial. Avoid the problem ingredients in products and heavy creams to maintain balance. Be sure to eat plenty of antioxidants from brightly coloured fruits and vegetables to enhance your natural glow. DRY SKIN Dry skin can sometimes be uncomfortable and frustrating for those who suffer from it; it can be greatly affected by our hormones and is often inherited. It can become worse with age and environmental factors, as well as products that dry out the skin, but it can be greatly improved on with the right skin care. Top tips for dry skin: Avoid very hot baths and showers and try to limit exposure to indoor heating, which can be very drying on our skin. Clean your face with gentle cleansing milks that won’t cause dryness, and use natural moisturising products that contain rich hydrators such as shea butter or extra virgin coconut oil. Exfoliate once or twice weekly to remove dead skin cells. A night cream is also beneficial, as this is the time when our skin is best able to take in moisture. The right nutrition can work wonders for dry skin; try consuming more healthy fats from sources such as avocados, nuts and coconut oil. Be sure to consume regular amounts of omega 3, either from oily fish or from a high quality supplement. OILY SKIN If you have Oily skin, the sebaceous glands are producing more oil than is needed, often leading to enlarged pores that become blocked with blemishes and blackheads. The skin is shiny and things like wearing make-up can often be tricky due to the oily texture of the skin. Top tips for oily skin: Wash your face 2-3 times daily with a natural, non-drying or irritating cleanser. Use an oil balancing skin toner to prevent excess oil production and break outs and finish with a lightweight moisturiser. Remember, don’t dry out your skin, as it will only compensate by producing more oil! We also recommend using a face mask twice a week, with naturally purifying ingredients such as kaolin clay or manuka honey. Acne and breakouts can result from a number of issues, including hormonal fluctuations, stress, environment and nutrition. If you suffer from regular breakouts, we suggest limiting your intake of sugars and processed foods and eating an anti-inflammatory diet featuring a wide variety of fruits and veggies. If symptoms persist, you may wish to consult a naturopath or nutritionist to get to the root of your problem. COMBINATION SKIN Combination skin is the skin type that is most commonly mistaken, as the skin can often be both dry and oily. Most people who have combination skin suffer from oiliness in specific areas such as the t-zone - nose and chin, and dryness in other areas. Top tips for combination skin: Keep a close eye on your skin and look daily to see what areas are oily and where is dry as this can change, you may find you need a few different products to look after the different areas in your skin. Tailoring your skincare to listen to your skin’s needs goes a long way to improving the problematic areas of combination skin. Pay attention to your lifestyle and nutrition, and monitor how your skin changes based on these factors. You may well find that there is something that is contributing to the changes, and can bring this back into balance naturally. SENSITIVE SKIN If you have sensitive skin, you have a weakened skin barrier that allows irritating elements to get through to the nerve endings resulting in the skin cells reacting; and it is these reactions that can cause redness, itching, stinging, burning, breakouts and peeling skin. Top tips for Sensitive skin: Avoid those problem ingredients in products and always do a 24 hour test patch when starting a new product, to see if it affects your skin. Keep pores clear and wash away surface dirt with a natural sensitive cleanser. Be gentle to the skin; do not rub or over exfoliate. Moisturise twice daily to protect the skin from drying and preserve a healthy barrier from external irritation. Use a natural sun protection. Drink plenty of water and consume a nutritious diet rich in essential fatty acids, fruits and vegetables. SHOPPING AT VIVO LIFE Once you have found your true skin type, shopping for products becomes a lot easier. To help you make the right choices, we have grouped products together to match your specific concern. Click any of the concerns below to find the perfect product for your skin type! SHOP BY CONCERN > Acne/Spot Prone Skin > Anti Ageing and Firming > Dry Skin > Eczema / Psoriasis > Oily Skin > Rosacea > Sensitive Skin > Skin Balancing > Skin Brightening BEGINNERS GUIDE TO FACE CARE FOR WOMEN If you want to find out more about natural face care then download Britanie Faith's FREE easy to follow guide  here!

item.title: Why you should activate your nuts before eating
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
Nuts – aren’t they wonderful? Whether it’s a bag of lightly salted pistachios accompanying you on a long car journey; walnuts whizzed with some basil, garlic and olive oil to make a pesto; or simply a few macadamia nuts crumbled on top of your breakfast, nuts are incredibly versatile and enjoyed by almost everyone. They are saviours in gluten free baking; cashews can be used to make a delicious dairy free cheesecake, and almond flour can be found in just about any cookie / cake recipe. And if you’ve never had almond, cashew, or macadamia nut butter, then you’re seriously missing out. Nuts are also rich in healthy fats, protein and fibre, and are a good source of many different minerals. Indeed, on first inspection, nuts are somewhat of a superfood – or are they? Phytic acid – a nut’s defence Nuts, like animals and many other plants, don’t want to be eaten. And just as a chameleon changes colour to blend in to the background, and pufferfish blow themselves up like a balloon to look as unappetising as possible, nuts also have an in built defence mechanism. It’s called phytic acid, and it’s a compound found in all nuts, grains and seeds to some degree. Phytic acid binds to minerals like magnesium, iron, zinc and calcium in the digestive tract, interfering with their absorption and making them almost impossible to break down. Not only does the phytic acid in the nut bind to the minerals within said nut, it also interferes with the absorption of other minerals in the digestive tract – which means a diet high in phytic acid poses a substantial risk of mineral deficiencies. Along with binding to minerals, phytic acid also interferes with the enzymes that break down our food, which is why nuts and grains are particularly problematic to people with troublesome digestion. It’s true, phytic acid isn’t much fun for humans; but to a plant, it’s their own personal bodyguard. Nonetheless, humans are generally a pretty smart species. Whilst phytic acid may have been largely ignored in recent years, our ancestors have been taking steps to avoid it for centuries – and the ancient practice of soaking and sprouting nuts deactivates virtually all of the phytic acid. Also known as ‘activating’ nuts, this practice is thought to go as far back as Roman times, and is used to make nuts more digestible and the minerals more available to our bodies. It’s not complicated either – meaning you can do it yourself at home! How to activate nuts

1) Fill a glass jar or bowl with filtered water and 1 tsp sea salt. Pour in the nuts, and cover with a lid or tea towel. Leave to soak in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight.

2) The time it takes your nuts to soak will depend on the type of nut you are activating. For hazelnuts, pecans and walnuts, soak for approximately 8 hours. Cashews and macadamia nuts need a little less time (approximately 6 hours) whereas pistachios, almonds and brazil nuts need at least 12. With soaking times over 8 hours, change the water halfway through.

3) Drain and rinse the nuts, then thoroughly dry them using a clean tea towel. Line some parchment out on a baking sheet, before evenly spreading the nuts on top. Now it’s time to dehydrate them. Ideally, you would use a dehydrator for this, but if you don’t have one, your oven is fine to use on it’s lowest setting. If using your oven, gently dehydrate the nuts at between 50 and 65C for between 12 and 20 hours, depending on soaking time (longer soaking times require longer dehydration).

4) Enjoy! Your newly activated nuts will be good for between ten days and two weeks.

Soaked nuts have a noticeably ‘crispier’ texture, and a sweeter, less bitter taste. You’ll notice the difference after you’ve eaten them too, as they’ll feel much lighter in your tummy than raw or roasted nuts. It’s also worth noting that a little phytic acid in an otherwise healthy diet isn’t going to cause much of a problem. Soaking and sprouting your nuts before eating them is desirable, but it’s not essential, so don’t panic if you’re faced with a handful of nuts that haven’t been activated. Soak and sprout your own nuts wherever possible, but please don’t become that crazy person who refuses to leave their home for fear of coming into contact with a raw brazil nut – that’s not going to help anyone. To save you the hard work, check out our range of Activated Nuts by Raw Ecstacy
item.category: why should you soak and sprout your nuts?

item.title: 13 quick, easy and healthy breakfast ideas!
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
Once heralded as ‘the most important meal of the day,’ our busy, modern lives have relegated breakfast to little more than a stale granola bar on the train to work, or a rushed piece of toast as you pile the kids into the car for school. In recent years, breakfast has transformed from a morning essential into a lacklustre afterthought, with many of us now not making any time for breakfast at all! But why should it be this way? Done correctly, a good breakfast is one of life’s real luxuries. It doesn’t have to be fancy or time consuming, and simple tricks like preparing it the night before can work wonders if you’re up against the clock. All of the recipes below are delicious, extremely satisfying, and importantly, can be rustled up in less than ten minutes. So put down the bland, sawdust resembling cereal – it’s something that we wouldn’t wish on our worst enemy. A healthy breakfast should be a pleasure to eat, not a chore. Here are 13 delicious recipes to set you up for the day ahead! To help you choose the right breakfast for you, we’ve put the following labels next to each breakfast idea: GF – Gluten Free DF – Dairy Free V – Vegan P – Paleo NF – Nut Free LC – Low Carb   Eggs Eggs are just perfect for breakfast! Packed with protein and healthy fats, they provide a great source of energy and keep you satisfied well into lunchtime. They’re super versatile too, and pair with just about anything! #1 – Scrambled eggs, avocado and grilled tomatoes (GF, DF, P, NF, LC): Cook the eggs in coconut oil over a low heat so the eggs don’t dry out. Serve with avocado slices, grilled tomatoes, and a dusting of pink Himalayan salt. #2 – Spinach, red onion and mushroom frittata (GF, DF, P, NF, LC): Make a big batch one evening and keep it in the fridge for delicious breakfasts for the next few days. Finely chop one red onion and a handful of mushrooms, and gently sauté them in a large pan for 3 – 4 minutes. Meanwhile, whisk 6 eggs in a large bowl with 200ml full fat coconut milk and your favourite herbs and spices. Add a generous handful of spinach to the pan, stir until slightly reduced in size, then pour in the egg mixture. Cook the eggs fully until it resembles a large omelette, then leave to cool for 5 minutes before transferring to a plate. A quick and easy breakfast option to have in the fridge during the week! #3 – Sunny side eggs and fried plantain (GF, DF, P, NF): Plantains are a starchier, less sweet member of the banana family; and if you can get your hands on them, they make a great breakfast. Chop into 2cm rounds, and fry in coconut oil for 2 minutes each side with a pinch of cinnamon. Transfer to a plate as you crack your eggs into the pan. Fry these for 30 seconds, sunny side up, before serving alongside the plantains. Serve with a side salad if you wish. Delicious!   Pancakes Pancakes don’t have to be unhealthy! Made with the right ingredients, pancakes can be delicious and nutritious. #4 – Banana pancakes (GF, DF, P, NF): Mash one ripe banana with two eggs. Add a little protein powder if desired. Heat some coconut oil in a pan, then pour in the pancake mixture to create three individual pancakes. Cook for two minutes each side, until golden. Serve with a sprinkle of cinnamon and a handful of fresh blueberries. #5 – Almond pancakes (GF, DF, P, LC): Not down with banana? No worries! Mix half a cup of almond flour with two eggs and a drop of vanilla extract. Cook in exactly the same way as the banana pancakes. Delicious topped with some organic maple syrup and a sprinkle of pumpkin seeds.   Hot Breakfasts You can’t beat a hot breakfast, especially when there’s a chill in the air outside. The following recipes are quick, easy, and super tasty. #6 – Sweet Potato Hash (GF, DF, V, P, NF): Finely chop one red onion, and shred half a sweet potato using a cheese grater. Lightly pan fry in some coconut oil for 7 or 8 minutes. Season with a pinch of paprika, cayenne, sea salt and pepper in the last minute of cooking. Top with a fried egg, some organic bacon, and / or a handful of pumpkin seeds. Great with a side of steamed broccoli! #7 – Grilled Salmon, Butternut Squash, Cranberries and Toasted Pecans (GF, DF, P): Simply chop your butternut squash into cubes, and steam for 8 – 10 minutes. Meanwhile, grill the salmon for the same amount of time, turning regularly. Finish with a generous sprinkle of toasted pecans and cranberries. Perfect!

Cold Breakfasts 

If cold breakfasts are more your thing, have no fear. The following are just as healthy and satisfying! #8 - Chia porridge (V, P, GF, DF, NF): It may sound unusual, but chia porridge is exceptionally tasty! Simply combine 4 tbsp chia seeds with 200ml almond milk, one mashed banana, a pinch of cinnamon and a drop of vanilla. Stir well, and leave to set in the fridge overnight. The chia seeds will absorb the moisture and turn the ‘porridge’ into a gelatinous consistency. Delicious topped with raw chocolate goji berries and a dollop of almond butter! #9 – Paleo Granola (GF, DF, V, P): The Paleo Foods Co’s range of granola is perhaps our favourite cereal in the world. Available in three delicious flavours: Berry and Almond, Honey and Pecan, and Cocoa and Hazelnut. Top with almond milk or coconut yoghurt, seasonal berries, and perhaps even a sprinkle of cacao nibs or maca powder! #10 - Apple and almond butter (GF, DF, V, P): If you’re in the mood for something light, you can’t beat some apple slices dipped into a generous serving of almond butter. For variety, try swapping the apple for a pear, or the almond butter for cashew butter!

Smoothies

Perfect for those days where you’re short on time or just not that hungry, smoothies deliver a hefty dose of nutrients in a convenient liquid package. The flavour combinations are endless – but here are a few of our favourites! #11 – Blend 200ml coconut water, ¼ pineapple, 4 – 5 strawberries and a handful of spinach. Add 1 scoop of Amazing Grass Green Superfood, 1 scoop of Sunwarrior Warrior Blend, and 1 tbsp raw coconut oil. Packed with vitamins, minerals, protein and healthy fats, this delicious smoothie will keep you energised all day! #12 – Blend 200ml maple water with 1 large handful blueberries, 1 large handful raspberries, 1 tablespoon of acai powder and 1 tablespoon of raw cacao. This tantalising combination of raw chocolate and berries packs a serious dose of antioxidants! #13 – Blend 200ml almond, hemp or coconut milk with 1 ripe banana and half a mango. Add 1 scoop of raw hemp protein, 1 tbsp maca powder, 1 tbsp chia seeds and 1tsp bee pollen. The resulting smoothie is smooth, creamy, and fully loaded with powerful superfoods.   The days of bland cereal and toast for breakfast are well and truly gone, so there really are no limits to what you can have in the morning. Whether you prefer sweet or savoury, hot or cold – taking the time each morning to prepare a healthy breakfast will set you up for a great day ahead. The recipes above are just some easy ideas to get you started, so don’t be afraid to get creative and experiment! What did you have for breakfast today? [icegram campaigns="5984"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 13 quick, easy and healthy breakfast ideas - Vivo Life
13 quick and healthy breakfast ideas. Gluten Free, Dairy Free, Vegan, Paleo, Nut Free and Low Carb options!

item.title: Mindful Eating - what is it, and why should I do it?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: As a nation, we love food. So just why don’t we dedicate enough time to eating it? For our ancestors, mealtimes were a ceremonious occasion – a chance to celebrate the splendour of the day’s hunt or harvest with friends and family, basking in the fragrant aromas and savouring the delicious flavours of every last bite we took. Having worked so hard all day to literally put the food on the table, the very least they could do was take time to enjoy it. After all, who knew when the next meal would arrive? Perhaps because food is so plentiful these days is the reason we have collectively become so disengaged with eating it. Now, instead of taking the time to relax and savour our food, we are finding ways to distract ourselves whilst eating it; reading the morning newspaper, watching a film, texting friends, or, worst of all, finishing that last bit of work. We’re eating our food faster than ever, with the average adult spending just 23 minutes in total each day on breakfast, lunch and dinner. With three generous sized meals each day (and often snacks as well!) being the norm, far too many of us see food as an afterthought; something to fit in around whatever else we are doing that day. But what impact is this having? By not eating mindfully and properly connecting with our food, we are throwing off our satiety signals, often causing us to over or under eat. It often means that we don’t chew our food properly too, putting extra stress on our digestive system – after all, our stomach doesn’t have teeth. It’s also interfering with our enjoyment of food; have you ever been eating a meal without really knowing it, and then before you know it, it’s all gone? Did you appreciate the delicate balance of flavours and textures on your plate? Probably not, and there you have a fine example of what we will now call ‘mindless’ eating. Mindful vs Mindless eating ‘Mindful eating’ means to eat with care and intention; to focus on the flavours, textures and aromas of your meal, to fill yourself with positive thoughts about how your food will benefit you, and to understand when you are satiated and should stop. Mindful eating is to thoroughly chew your food and to eliminate distraction – you came to the table to eat, not to text or complete level 42 of ‘Candy Crush.’ Mindless eating, on the other hand, is the norm for far too many of us. Whether you’re chomping on a banana whilst walking between meetings, chatting on the phone whilst eating lunch or taking dinner to your desk to catch up on overdue work, distraction at meal times can significantly impair the digestion of your food. Mindless eating – why you should relax at mealtimes When our mind is racing and thinking about our ‘to-do’ list for the day, or we’re shovelling food down in a rush to make our 1 o’clock meeting, we create a stressful environment in the body. And when we eat under stress, our ability to properly digest our food becomes compromised. This is an evolutionary response which dictates that, in times of stress, our body’s ‘fight or flight’ response kicks in, literally diverting energy away from the digestive system and prioritising it for other functions. If, for example, we were being chased by a predator, we wouldn’t exactly need to stop and eat along the way. Our immediate priority is escaping unharmed; so adrenaline is released, our breathing rate increases, and circulation is shunted away from the digestive tract and into the muscles and limbs to provide extra energy to get away. The same response happens when everyday stresses occur, no matter how small or trivial they may seem. Unfortunately, our body cannot distinguish a life threatening situation where we might actually need the ‘fight or flight’ response and our boss harassing us to hand in our essay on time. Because, in this state, our digestive systems are partially shut down, we secrete fewer digestive enzymes and less stomach acid; leading to an impaired ability to break down our food. Not only does this mean that we are missing out on valuable nutrients, it can cause some profound digestive discomfort. Ever eaten a meal in a rush and then felt like you had a rock sitting in your stomach for hours afterwards? Then you will know just how delicate our digestive systems are; and how it’s not just what you eat that affects your digestion, but how you eat it too. And whilst stress and distraction are seemingly two different entities, your body perceives them in largely the same way. In a 1987 study, participants were asked to drink two identical mineral drinks. The first one was consumed in a parasympaphetic (relaxed) state, whilst the other was consumed whilst the participants were involved in a conversation about space travel or financial planning. The research showed that more of the nutrients were absorbed in the parasympaphetic state, whilst the ‘distracted’ state showed a significant reduction in assimilation. A distracted environment, it seems, has the same impact on our digestion as a stressful one. So what to do? Mindful eating is a real challenge, and we’re not going to pretend otherwise. With so many things to squeeze into our days, it’s natural that we try and rush things and are already focusing on the next task before completing the current one. That said, taking small steps towards eating mindfully will see it gradually become second nature – and soon, mealtimes will feel like mealtimes again. If you’re worrying about the 6pm deadline you have to hit, instead of inhaling a sandwich at your desk at 5.30pm, focus on completing the task in hand before worrying about getting something to eat. The hunger you feel now most certainly isn’t life threatening, and your body will thank you for waiting just a little longer to be able to eat without stress and anxiety. When the work is done, relax – it’s now time to eat. See mealtimes as time that you dedicate to yourself and others at the table; time to replenish your energy levels and enjoy the wonderful flavours and textures present on your plate. Even if it is just temporarily, try to forget about everything else you have to do that day, and take time to be in the moment with your food. Eliminate distraction; keep your phone in your pocket, and turn the TV off in the background. Focus intensely on each bite – how does it taste? How does it make you feel? Chew thoroughly, and, in between mouthfuls, enjoy light conversation with your dining partners. If you’re at the table for an hour, even two, who cares? Right now, you’re here to eat, and there’s nothing to rush for. Taking time to eat mindfully can have a profound impact on your waistline, your digestive system, and your all round enjoyment of food. Yes, life gets in the way sometimes. Not every meal will be eaten in perfect serenity. But, challenge yourself to eat mindfully as much as possible, and see for yourself just how differently you feel. [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: As a nation, we love food. So just why don’t we dedicate enough time to eating it? Here's a quick guide to mindful eating.

item.title: Cutting the confusion
item.dc:creator: Salv
item.content:encoded: The UK health and fitness industry is growing every day. More people than ever before are beginning to realise that the things they put into their body directly correlate with how they look, feel, and perform. It’s incredibly exciting to see people of all ages, shapes and sizes begin to take control of their health – and it’s a movement that is only going to get bigger. But as the industry grows, more and more new products are finding their way on to the shelves. Unfortunately, however, not all of them are as healthy as they claim to be. With more brands and more products competing for your attention than ever before, it’s becoming incredibly difficult to find the right ones for you. I have been passionate about health and fitness for as long as I can remember, and have seen some quite extraordinary diet trends and ‘must have’ supplements emerge and disappear during this time. Genuinely healthy, reliable products were becoming fewer and further between; so I decided it was time to take action. In October 2014, Vivo Life was born - to cut through the masses of health products and provide like-minded folk with a carefully selected range that they can truly trust. Every single one of the items we stock is wholesome, effective, sustainable and junk-free. More importantly, they all actually do what they say on the packaging. Our guiding motto is simple. If we wouldn’t use it ourselves, we certainly won’t sell it to you. Our aim is to provide a one-stop-shop for high quality, natural, organic products made by only the most trustworthy companies. No longer should you have to spend hours scouring the internet for natural health and beauty products that match up to your values – at Vivo Life, we’ve done the hard work for you. Simply look out for the following product icons in our online store, and use them to shop with confidence for products that you can trust. LEARN: Our passion for health and fitness goes far beyond the products we sell, which is why we’re here to provide guidance in the form of articles, guides and tutorials on all things health, fitness and natural beauty. Our ultimate commitment is to inspire, educate, and provide all the tools you need to be the happiest, healthiest version of yourself. We’re regularly updating the blog with useful articles, and send out free guides to our members to help you stay on track. Some of our previous articles and free downloads may be of interest: - How to shop for health products - 6 steps to boost your immunity - 10 reasons to drink more water - 13 Quick Healthy Breakfast ideas - All you need to know about sugar - The Vivo Guide to Fitness Nutrition - The Vivo Guide to Smoothie Making ASK: If you’re unsure about whether a product is right for you, or need specific advice on using a product, just ask! Our small, friendly team are passionate about health and fitness, and are happy to advise you in any way we can. Reach out to us by phone, email, facebook and twitter! RECOMMEND: Do you have a favourite product that isn’t currently available at Vivo Life? Let us know! MEET US: To find out more about the people behind Vivo Life, view the Vivo Team page! JOIN: Sign up to our newsletter now to get started. You’ll receive 10% off your first order, and be the first to know about the latest articles, product review, promotions and special offers at Vivo HQ. HOW TO SHOP: Shop by Goal: Whatever your health goal, we’re here to help. Every item we stock is completely junk-free – so no fillers, binders, allergens, or artificial ingredients. Just wholesome, natural health products that REALLY work. Brain Food - Digestion - Detox - Energy - General Health - Immunity - Joint Health - Stress & Sleep - Weight Management Shop by Category: Our product range isn’t as big as many other retailers; but with everything personally tried, tested and approved by the Vivo Team, you can count on us for products that you can trust.  Accessories - Anti-inflammatory - Antioxidants - Bath Salts - Drinks - Electrolytes - Fibre - Greens  - Herbs - Meal Replacements - Oils & EFAs - Probiotics - Protein - Raw Chocolate - Snacks - Superfoods - Teas - Vitamins and Minerals Shop by your Values: Whether you’re gluten free, dairy free, vegan or paleo, we’ve got the right products to suit your diet and lifestyle. Cut out the junk and go straight to the good stuff!

item.title: The Vivo Guide to Smoothie Making
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: Who doesn’t love a good smoothie? Not only are they delicious, but smoothies are a wonderful way to ramp up your daily intake of vitamins, minerals, antioxidants and protein. They’re super convenient and easy to digest too – meaning they are regularly on the menu here at Vivo HQ! When smoothies turn out well, they’re amazing. There really isn’t much better than kicking back on a warm summer’s day with an ultra-smooth, super refreshing blend of your favourite fruits and superfoods. But for every great smoothie, there is another that’s just not quite right. There are those smoothies that are just too thick and sit like a rock in your stomach. There are others that are way too sweet, spiking your blood sugar and sending you crashing back down to earth before you’ve even rinsed the blender. And then there are the worst ones, those dreaded concoctions that should be called a lumpy, not a smoothie. But don’t give up just yet. We’re determined to put an end to sub-standard smoothies once and for all, which is why we have created this booklet. “The Vivo Guide to Smoothie Making” is a comprehensive guide to creating the perfect smoothie every time, with all the tips you need to make unbeatable smoothies, along with some easy to follow recipes to get you started. Click here to download your free guide today!

item.title: Coeliac awareness week: why are so many of us becoming gluten intolerant?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: All over the world, people are taking steps to reduce, or even eliminate, their consumption of gluten. In fact, in the UK alone, one in three adults is currently ‘avoiding or actively reducing’ their gluten intake. Whilst some are doing so in an attempt to follow the recent health ‘trend,’ many more are doing so to simply feel healthier. The proof, it seems, is in the gluten free pudding. Although many are not medically diagnosed with celiac disease, gluten avoiders tout a greater sense of physical, mental, and emotional wellbeing as their reason for doing so. With a wide range of symptoms ranging from gastrointestinal distress, mental disorders, skin complaints and allergies all being linked to gluten intolerance, people are removing gluten from their diets for a plethora of reasons. But just what is causing the rapid rise in gluten intolerance? Gluten in our diet Gluten is a protein found in common grains including wheat, barley, and rye. Wheat alone provides about 20% of the world’s calories, significantly more than any other food on the planet. It has been a staple food in our diets for thousands of years; so why, all of a sudden, has it become so threatening? As a coeliac myself, I know first-hand the problems that wheat can cause, but until now, have never put a great deal of thought into why. A common theory that is often put forward by mainstream media is that gluten intolerance is an illness of modern creation; in short, it doesn’t really exist at all. Many people think that they suffer from it, when really our collective fear is irrational and brought on by the modern day ‘agenda’ against wheat. But despite these claims, there is proof that gluten intolerance is on the rise. Indeed, a recent study using frozen blood samples taken from Air Force recruits 50 years ago has shown that the intolerance of wheat gluten has increased by 400% in this 50 year period. For more proof that gluten intolerance is indeed a physical complaint rather than a psychological one, we can take a look at a recent combined study by Monash University and the gastroenterology unit at Alfred Hospital, Melbourne. 34 people were recruited, all of which suffered from irritable bowel syndrome. In a double blind study, all patients were told that they would be embarking on a strict gluten free diet; whereas, in reality, half of the patients were given bread and muffins that contained gluten. Most of those who ate the gluten reported that the pain persisted, whilst most of the others claimed it went away. Although this study was undoubtedly small scale, it does suggest that the effects of gluten consumption go far beyond the psychological. Gluten intolerance vs coeliac disease Medical professionals are pointing to the relatively stable levels of diagnoses of coeliac disease, an autoimmune condition that results from the consumption of gluten, as evidence that gluten intolerance is not rising. Levels of coeliac diagnoses have remained fairly stable in the last 25 years, with approximately 0.7 – 1.0% of the world’s population affected by this condition. But here’s the key information; coeliac disease and gluten intolerance are not the same thing. Conventional testing for coeliac disease only screens for a reaction to two fractions of the wheat protein, alpha-gliadin and transglutaminase-2; yet, many people with gluten intolerance react to other fractions of the wheat protein, including beta, gamma and omega-gliadin, WGA, deamidated gliadin, and other types of transglutaminase, including type 3 and type 6. So, whilst you may not be ‘coeliac’ in the medical sense of the word, you may very well be gluten intolerant. If you react adversely to wheat, you don’t need a medical diagnosis to tell you whether you should eat it or not. What is causing the rise in gluten intolerance? There are many theories put forward as to why we are seeing such a rapid rise in wheat intolerance. One theory commonly proposed is the deteriorating quality of modern wheat, and how the rise of GMO farming is causing the wheat proteins to be more troublesome to digest; although, this has never been proven by any scientific studies. Another theory is that we are now consuming more gluten in our breads, cakes and muffins, as manufacturers actually add additional gluten to give their food a fluffier, bouncier texture. As the gluten concentration is higher, we are more likely to react. A third theory, and the most scientifically-based of them all, is that the rise of processed and refined foods in the modern diet is damaging our gut flora; making it harder for many of us to digest many different foods, gluten being one of them. How to find out if you are gluten intolerant Gluten intolerance can affect nearly every tissue in the body, including the digestive system, endocrine system, cardiovascular system, liver, skin and brain; meaning symptoms of gluten intolerance are so vast and wide ranging, in many cases, doctors don’t even consider gluten as a culprit. If you are suffering from any health issue that you think could be attributed to gluten, consider embarking on an elimination diet, during which you remove gluten from your diet for at least 28 days. Try to keep everything else consistent, and monitor your symptoms during this process. If your symptoms improve, you may well have your answer. Whether you’re coeliac or gluten intolerant, today’s society makes it easier than ever before to maintain your gluten free diet. Restaurant staff no longer scoff when you ask for a gluten free option – many even have dedicated menus to cater for your needs. Thanks to a growing awareness of cross contamination, diligent chefs will prepare all of their gluten free options in a separate area of their kitchen. Gluten free products are now widely available in supermarkets, and new EU packaging laws that came into place at the end of last year make it compulsory to emphasise gluten (and other common allergens) in bold on the ingredients list. Look out for the gluten free icon in the Vivo Life store – whenever you see this, it means the product is safe to use! 5 top tips for gluten free living: • Take a high quality probiotic. If you are intolerant to any food, it could be the sign of an underlying digestive issue. By taking a high quality probiotic, you can repopulate your gut with healthy bacteria and help improve digestive function. • Limit gluten free ‘substitutes’. Gluten free breads, pastas, and cakes are often disappointing, and in many cases are packed full of artificial ingredients and preservatives. Always prioritise real food wherever possible, but if you do get a craving for an old gluten-containing favourite, bake it yourself instead. Coconut flour, cassava flour and almond meal are excellent flour substitutes. • Always read the label. Even the most inconspicuous of products can have gluten hiding in them. Always read the label to avoid any unwanted gluten consumption. • Plan ahead. If you are going out for the day, research the area to look for restaurants that can cater for your needs. Consider calling them beforehand to let them know that you will be dining with them; often, they will make special preparations to ensure you are properly looked after. • Take control. By far the best way to avoid unwanted gluten consumption is to take control of your own cooking, preparing as many of your meals as possible from scratch. Not only will this help you to avoid gluten, but it’s much healthier too! To stay up to date with all the latest articles, news, and special offers at Vivo HQ, don’t forget to sign up to our newsletter! Sources 1) http://www.bmj.com/content/319/7204/236 2) http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/11/03/grain 3) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3448089/ [icegram messages="7123"]
