item.title: The Amazing Health Benefits of Your Spice Rack (part 1)
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: For thousands of years, spices have been valued as a prized commodity throughout the world. In times gone by, traders would sail for weeks across turbulent seas to faraway lands, offering up their prized possessions in return for vibrant flavours, fragrances and colours. Spices were much more than just a cooking ingredient; they were a currency of their own. The exotic flavours that spices brought to food were obvious for all to see – but it was for their many health benefits that they were so highly regarded. Without doubt, the spice rack was considered a gastronomic gem and a powerful medicine cabinet in equal measure. Nowadays, exotic spices from around the world are easy to take for granted as they line our supermarket shelves in alphabetical order. But just because they are readily available, doesn’t make them any less special. Not only do they have the power to turn even the blandest of foods into a culinary masterpiece, spices can have a seriously beneficial impact on our health. Over the next two articles, we’ll be examining the many health benefits of some common household spices, and take a look at how to use them in your own kitchen. Let’s get to it! Cardamom Origin: India and Sri Lanka Flavour: Warm, sweet, aromatic Pairs well with: Cinnamon, ginger, turmeric, mint, anise, citrus, lentils, lamb, dark chocolate, pears. The benefits: In Ayurveda, the ancient Indian practice of health and healing, Cardamom is often used to treat indigestion and stomach upset. Cardamom is also a natural diuretic, helping to eliminate waste from the liver, kidneys and bladder. It is also great for oral health, used to treat mouth ulcers, throat infections, and bad breath. How to use: To extract the cardamom seeds from their pods, gentle bash them in a mortar and pestle. Grind into a fine powder and use sparingly in both sweet and savoury dishes. To soothe an upset tummy, mix a little cardamom with some ginger and raw honey in a mug of warm almond milk. Cayenne Pepper Origin: Although it is named after the city of Cayenne in French Guiana, Cayenne Pepper can grow in a variety of climates and is widely used in Indian, Middle Eastern, Arabic, African and Mexican cuisine. Flavour: Hot, fiery Pairs well with: Paprika, garlic, cumin, coriander, oregano, beef, chicken, eggs, rice, chickpeas, onions, tomatoes, coffee, dark chocolate The health benefits: Cayenne has natural thermogenic properties that have been shown to raise metabolism, making it a popular ingredient in many fat burning supplements. It is a powerful anti-inflammatory, a known circulation booster, and is often used during detox programmes and cleanses. How to use: Cayenne is extremely versatile, and great for adding a little heat to your favourite dishes. Use it in marinades, home-made sauces, or combined with other spices in curries and chillies. Believe it or not, it is also great with dark chocolate and coffee! Cinnamon Origin: Sri Lanka, Bangladesh Flavour: Sweet, warming, fragrant, Pairs well with: Ginger, cardamom, nutmeg, cloves, apples, pears, plums, bananas, dates, sweet potatoes, butternut squash, pumpkin, pecans The health benefits: Cinnamon has been shown to lower blood sugar levels, improve insulin sensitivity, and decrease the insulin spike that occurs when eating a sugary or carbohydrate rich meal. Coincidentally, it pairs incredibly well with many sweet foods! Cinnamon is also incredibly rich in antioxidants, with the ORAC scale noting that it is the third most antioxidant rich food known to man. The antioxidants in cinnamon have been linked to the prevention of neurodegenerative diseases, heart disease, and various cancers. How to use: You can buy cinnamon as a powder, or as whole sticks. It is found in almost all world cuisine, most notably Middle Eastern and Asian dishes. Use in either sweet or savoury recipes. Unbeatable sprinkled onto roasted sweet potato wedges, or used with orchard fruits such as apples, pears and plums. Cloves Origin: Indonesia Flavour: Pungent, sharp, subtle sweetness Pairs well with: Cinnamon, ginger, pork, venison, apples, pears, plums The health benefits: Cloves have a long standing history in traditional herbal medicine, thanks to their natural anti-fungal, anti-bacterial and anti-viral properties. They are often used to treat bacterial imbalances such as candida, and as a treatment for intestinal parasites. Cloves are also used to treat infections, especially in the respiratory tract, and have been shown to support the immune system and prevent colds and flu. Cloves have the highest antioxidant capacity known to man, according to the ORAC scale. How to use: Cloves are very strong, so use sparingly! Pierce them into orchard fruits before baking, grind and add small amounts to fragrant curries and tagines, or combine with cinnamon and ginger for a classic ‘pecan pie’ spice. Coriander Seeds Origin: North Africa, Asia Flavour: Fresh, fragrant, citrusy Pairs well with: Cumin, ginger, chilli, lemongrass, lemon, lime, coconut, garlic, fish, chicken, cauliflower, parsnips, mango The health benefits: Technically the ‘berries’ of the coriander herb, coriander seeds encourage the production of enzymes in the digestive tract to help with the absorption of vitamins and minerals. They have also been shown to improve fasting blood sugar levels and improve insulin sensitivity. How to use: Coriander seeds are a mainstay in Indian, Chinese, Thai, Mexican, Middle Eastern, Southern European and African cuisine, lending a fresh, citrusy twist to just about any dish. They are the base of many common household spice blends, including garam masala and harissa. Use in curries, as a marinade for meat, or as a seasoning for vegetables. Cumin Origin: South East Europe Flavour: Warm, earthy, pungent Pairs well with: Coriander, paprika, garlic, ginger, onion, oregano, chilli, pork, chicken, fish, tomatoes, lemon, orange, cauliflower, pistachio The health benefits: In Ayurveda, cumin is known as ‘Jira’ meaning ‘the spice that helps digestion.’ Cumin helps in the production of enzymes and soothes the digestive tract, and is often used as a treatment for diarrhoea, constipation, and GI distress. It has also been linked to an improvement in sleep quality and an increase in memory and recall. How to use: Cumin and coriander go hand in hand in a wide range of world cuisine. Use the pair as a base for curries, stews, marinades and sauces. Cumin pairs brilliantly with lighter meats such as chicken and fish, often accompanied by a squeeze of citrus. Be sure to read the second part in the series here! [icegram messages="7123"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Amazing Health Benefits of Your Spice Rack
There are some seriously amazing health benefits that can be found in your spice rack. Discover how common household spices can improve your health!

item.title: The Amazing Health Benefits of Your Spice Rack (part 2)
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: In our previous article, we took a look at some common household spices and the remarkable health benefits that they offer. If you missed it, click here to view “The Amazing Health Benefits of Your Spice Rack Part 1!” In today’s post, we’ll be taking a look at six more spices and their unique health benefits. They’re all incredibly tasty, and can easily be used in your own kitchen. Don’t be afraid to experiment! Fenugreek Origin: Middle East Flavour: Pungent, nutty, slightly bitter Pairs well with: Ginger, coriander, cumin, black pepper, garlic, tamarind, fish, lamb, prawns, lentils, chickpeas, cauliflower, coconut, red chilli, lemon The benefits: Fenugreek was used as a medicinal spice before it began to work it’s way into Indian, Turkish and Arabic cuisine, and is one of the few spices that has been the subject of clinical trials that have proved it’s many health benefits. It has been shown to lower LDL cholesterol and blood triglycerides, and to significantly reduce fasting blood sugar in diabetic and prediabetic patients. In Ayurveda, it is also used as a remedy for acid reflux and heartburn. How to use: Fenugreek is very pungent, and works better when used in combination with fresher spices such as coriander, ginger and black pepper. Often found in Indian cuisine, fenugreek is a popular ingredient in dhals, rice dishes, and fish curries. Ginger Origin: Southern China Flavour: Zingy, zesty, spicy Pairs well with: Garlic, ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg, chilli, turmeric, orange, lemon, bay, squash, sweet potatoes, carrots, parsnips, prawns, chicken, fish, red meat, rice, noodles, pineapple, apple, pear, cashews, pecans, dark chocolate The benefits: Ginger is one of the few spices where the fresh root is often easier to buy and use than the powder. It is cheap, versatile, and exceptionally healthy, so there’s no reason not to use it regularly. Ginger is a powerful anti-inflammatory and is fantastic for joint health – so much so, that it is often used as a natural way to treat arthritis. Ginger is also especially beneficial for digestion, as it stimulates secretion of digestive juices, increases the absorption of nutrients from food and provides relief from stomach cramps. For an incredibly easy and delicious way to harness the health benefits of ginger, check out this delicious herbal tea! How to use: Along with garlic, ginger is used liberally in almost all world cuisine. You’ll find it served pickled with Japanese sushi and bento, grated into Indian curries and Thai stir fries, and used in various marinades in Caribbean and Latin American cuisine. It is also great in sweet dishes, pairing especially well with dark chocolate and fruit. Paprika Origin: Central and Southern America Flavour: Sweet, smoky, sometimes spicy Pairs well with: Chilli, garlic, cumin, oregano, basil, chicken, pork, fish, mushrooms, chickpeas, almonds, aubergines, tomatoes, potatoes, beans The benefits: The opulent red colour of paprika is a clear indication of the rich levels of antioxidants that it contains. It is traditionally air dried rather than processed by heat, so is widely considered to be a raw food. Paprika has been shown to combat inflammation, enhance circulation, and even have a beneficial impact on gut bacteria. How to use: Although it originated in the Americas, paprika first became popular in European cuisine, and is used widely in many Spanish, Portuguese, Hungarian and Turkish dishes. It is an essential spice in both meat and vegetable chillies, and makes a delicious seasoning for just about anything when combined with salt, pepper, garlic, and a squeeze of lemon. There are many different varieties of paprika, including sweet, smoked, and hot – don’t be afraid to experiment and find your favourite! Turmeric Origin: Southern India Flavour: Earthy, robust Pairs well with: Coriander, cumin, fenugreek, garlic, chilli, ginger, black pepper, cardamom, salt, lemon, orange, coconut, coffee, chicken, lamb, lentils, eggs, cauliflower, sweet potato, broccoli, banana The benefits: If a king of healthy spices were ever to be crowned, it would surely be turmeric. This bright yellow root is one of the most powerful antioxidants and anti-inflammatories known to man, and has been used as much for it’s medicinal qualities as it has for flavour for thousands of years. Turmeric contains a powerful medicinal compound called curcumin, which numerous studies have shown to have preventative effects against various cancers and degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s. Turmeric fights free radicals, supports blood and liver function, promotes healthy joints and improves circulation. It benefits the kidneys and adrenal glands, promotes immunity and improves digestive function. How to use: The subtle, earthy notes of turmeric are great for adding a real depth of flavour to various curries, dahls, and rice dishes. It also makes a great seasoning, combined with a little salt, black pepper, and a squeeze of lemon juice. For something a little different, try a turmeric latte by combining hot almond milk, a spoonful of turmeric and a spoonful of raw honey. If you’re struggling to get to grips with the taste of turmeric, consider taking a high quality turmeric supplement to reap the benefits instead. Black Pepper Origin: South India Flavour: Woody, floral, somewhat spicy Pairs well with: Lemon, salt, and virtually all meats and vegetables. The benefits: Even the least adventurous of kitchens usually has a pepper grinder somewhere; and whilst the health benefits of pepper are not quite on the same level as rivals such as turmeric and ginger, it still has a fair bit to offer the user. Black pepper has been shown to have detoxifying and metabolism boosting effects, and is often recommended on many weight loss programmes. In herbal medicine, pepper is often used to treat coughs and colds, and to clear nasal congestion. How to use: Use black pepper as a table spice, grinding on to just about any dish to suit your taste. Black pepper has also been shown to significantly increase the absorption of the bioactive compounds in turmeric, so combine the two for even greater benefits. Himalayan Salt Origin: Mined from ancient Himalayan seabeds Flavour: Erm… salty? Pairs well with: Everything! The benefits: Salt is often vilified by conventional wisdom, but not all salts are created equal. Yes, we would probably all benefit from avoiding the chemically made salt found in processed foods; but there are other types of salts available, some of which are actually extremely healthful. Our favourite at Vivo HQ is Pink Himalayan Salt. Quite the opposite from common table salt, Himalayan Crystal Salt is an excellent source of essential nutrients. In total, it contains 82 different minerals, all key components for human health. It regulates your fluid balance, improves muscle function and digestion, and aids the absorption of other minerals such as calcium and potassium. Himalayan salt is also a must for athletes, helping to replace the electrolytes and minerals lost through sweating. How to use: Although Himalayan Salt is undoubtedly a health food, you can have too much of a good thing. As long as you keep your intake below 1 teaspoon each day, you will remain firmly in health promoting territory. As you can see, the contents of your spice rack can be used for much more than just flavouring your food. Just a few sprinkles of your favourite spices here and there can provide serious health benefits – so don’t be afraid to unleash them next time you’re in the kitchen!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I use turmeric on almost everything! I've heard you need to eat 1 gram a day to get any benefits, but try telling that to the people in Southern India who have some of the lowest cancer rates in the world. Nice to see that a little salt never hurt anybody either.
Turmeric is the best isn't it Joanne!

item.title: Busting the Myth: Should You Really Eat Six Small Meals Per Day?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: If you’ve been interested in health and fitness for any period of time, you’ve more than likely seen the theory of ‘6 small meals per day’ regurgitated on more than one occasion. If you’re like 95% of people (myself included) you’ve probably bought into it at some point too. Eating small meals every 2 – 3 hours is the optimal way to burn fat, build muscle, and altogether win at life. At least, so we were told. But who is responsible for this theory? Has it ever been proven by clinical studies on humans? Is it backed by any shred of scientific evidence? Or was it, in fact, a myth created by the fitness industry? If you’re reading this whilst eating meal #5 of the day from your Tupperware box, you may want to sit up and take note. The theory At some point in the early 1990s, the theory of ‘6 small meals per day’ was born. If you didn’t eat every two hours, on the button, your metabolism would begin to slow down. Your body would enter a catabolic state and start to eat it’s own muscle stores for fuel. You’d get fat. You’d get weak. Your hair would fall out. And although none of this actually ever happened, for some reason, people began to believe this theory. It was on the internet, so it must be true – right? As a result, we began ignoring our hunger signals and started eating to the chime of alarm clocks. We carried Tupperware boxes and cooler bags with us wherever we went. Our lives soon revolved around the buying, preparing, and eating of food. Sounds like fun, doesn’t it? To this day, the ‘6 small meals’ theory is still treated as gospel by personal trainers, performance coaches, and even many nutritionists. But if you have any kind of social life, hobbies, or work commitments, you’ll know that this eating strategy just isn’t practical. Thankfully, it’s not necessary either. The reality There have been numerous studies, often sponsored by the fitness industry, that have attempted to show how eating ‘little and often’ boosts metabolism and is therefore optimal for maintaining a lean physique. Unfortunately, despite their best efforts, there has never been any proof in this theory. Indeed, in the most recent clinical study¹ on meal frequency, a group of obese adults were divided into two groups – one that ate three meals, and one that ate six meals per day, with the total caloric volume remaining consistent. After eight weeks, both groups had lost weight on the calorie restricted diet; but there was no difference between the total weight loss in either. Meal frequency and muscle building Small and frequent meals are often recommended for muscle building, in theory to maximise protein synthesis. Yet again, however, it’s a theory that makes little sense. Our bodies are programmed to maintain muscle mass wherever physically possible. From an evolutionary perspective, lean muscle was essential to our survival. In times where food was scarce, we often went for days without eating a significant source of protein. If the ‘little and often’ theory was correct, we’d have quite literally disintegrated after the first few hours out hunting. During protein synthesis, protein (from food) is broken down in the digestive system into amino acids, released into the bloodstream, and then used for a number of physiological processes, including growth and repair. Our body can only use between 7 and 8g of amino acids in any given hour², so it slows digestion to make sure the protein we eat doesn’t go to waste. The amino acids in our digestive system are then slowly released into the blood stream, allowing protein synthesis to continue hours after your last meal. Whilst eating 15g protein in one sitting may mean your requirements for protein begin to increase again after two hours, eating 40g means that you can comfortably go without protein for at least five. The bottom line is to eat enough protein in any 24 hour period to support your own lifestyle and training demands. When you eat it is of little significance. Should I eat little and often? The above information doesn’t mean that eating six small meals each day is necessarily wrong. If you’ve got the appetite, time, and money, then go for it; at the end of the day, the most important thing is the quality of the food you are actually consuming. Just make sure that you are legitimately hungry, so that when you do eat, your enzyme pool is fully replenished and ready to digest your next meal. As for me? I simply feel better when I spend less time eating. My days are busy with work, training, and social commitments, and eating ‘little and often’ just gets in the way. I prefer to eat my meals mindfully rather than shovel them down at the desk or on the train, and my digestion starts to act up when I don’t leave enough time between sittings. Three square meals works perfectly for me. It’s what the majority of the human race have done for centuries, and we’ve done ok so far. That’s not to say that three meals a day is the right approach for you. Experiment with your meal frequency, and see what works best. But please - put away that stopwatch. Sources 1) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19943985 2) http://alrindustries.com/pdf/A-Review-of-Issues-of-Dietary-Protein-Intake-in-Humans.pdf

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Busting the Myth: Should you really eat 6 small meals per day?
For years, we've been told that eating 'little and often' is required to build muscle and burn fat. But is this really the case?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Completely agree, 6 meals per day is fitness hogwash and belongs in the bin along with waveloading, 5 x 5 and expensive pre workouts!

item.title: Ancestral Nutrition for the Primal Athlete
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: At last! The UK's first online Paleo lifestyle magazine, Primal Eye, has landed! If you're an aspiring caveman or cavewoman in the modern day world, then you'll absolutely love the range of brilliant articles, recipes and more in this magazine. In my first article for Primal Eye, 'Ancestral Nutrition for the Primal Athlete,' I have discussed how athletes can tweak the standard paleo diet to optimise their athletic performance. It's a must read for anyone serious about maintaining high level sporting performance whilst optimising health at the same time. Click here to read the full article at Primal Eye - here's a little taster below! ------ Without question, the standard Paleo template is perfect for anyone simply looking to maintain excellent health and maximise longevity. But for those of us that are eating to fuel our athletic performance and attain high level physique goals, a few tweaks are required. Whilst Joe Bloggs (the office worker who spends his free time on the sofa watching Game of Thrones re-runs) may do well on a diet of meat and leafy greens; as an athlete, you won’t. You see, our ancestors were not swinging kettlebells, thrusting a barbell above their head, or partaking in any other glycogen depleting, high intensity form of exercise on a daily basis. If a prehistoric human were ever to find himself watching a group session at a nearby Crossfit box, he’d undoubtedly think we were all insane. Traditional hunter-gatherers did what was required for their survival and little else. In fact, when they weren’t out hunting, fishing, or foraging, they were deliberately doing as little as possible to conserve their energy. With no idea where there next meal would come from, maintaining a chiselled torso and rock hard glutes was the last thing on their mind. But that’s not to say that a Paleo diet is wrong for athletes. Quite the contrary; when utilised correctly, the Paleo template can provide an excellent platform to make serious progress in your athletic pursuits. By focusing on anti-inflammatory, nutrient dense foods, we are putting our bodies in the best possible position to cope with the intense demands of high level training. All that’s left to do is make a few small tweaks to optimise our performance. Read the rest of this article over at Primal Eye Magazine - The UK's first online Paleo lifestyle magazine!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ancestral Nutrition for the Primal Athlete
For those of us that are eating to fuel our athletic performance and attain high level physique goals, a few tweaks to the standard paleo diet are required.

item.title: What defines a healthy diet?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
With so much conflicting information out there, it’s hard to know who to trust when it comes to eating healthily. Rather than simply being healthy eaters, we’re now dividing into separate ‘sub categories’ in our never ending quest to achieve optimum health. We’re now vegan, paleo, raw, zone, macrobiotic, high carb low fat, high fat low carb, ketogenic and fruitarian. We're allowing ourselves to be defined by a set of dietary rules that are apparently becoming part of our identity. And with highly convincing arguments coming from each camp about why this particular diet will help you live longer, feel better, lift more, run further, and look better naked than ever before – just who do we believe? Cutting through the conflict The truth is, there is no ‘one size fits all’ diet. We are all highly unique individuals, so whilst one person may thrive following a particular diet, that doesn’t mean it’s the right one for you. The key to healthy eating isn’t finding out what’s healthy for everybody else – it’s about finding out what’s healthy for you. What you eat depends on what’s going on in your body. How do certain foods make you feel, look, and perform? When we listen to our bodies, we start to learn which foods we should be eating and those that we shouldn’t. And, as it turns out, our own bodies are inherently wiser than any health blog or diet coach. Evolution of the human race is perhaps the biggest indicator that there is no one diet that is right for everyone. Traditional societies have evolved eating strikingly different diets; take the Inuit, for example, who thrived on a high protein, high fat diet consisting almost entirely of wild fish, game, and kelp. Compare this with the Hadza tribe, who were equally as healthy eating a diet based primarily around starchy carbohydrates including wild roots, tubers, and honey. Although their diets were dramatically different, both cultures maintained excellent health and suffered from remarkably low occurrences of diseases such as heart disease and cancer. Despite cultures around the world evolving on such diverse diets, there was one thing that remained consistent throughout them all – whole, unprocessed, nutrient dense foods. People relied on the earth to put food on their plate, whether that was in the form of fruits, vegetables, meat, fish, nuts or seeds. Diets would inevitability change depending on the seasons and what was available at any given time, but the fundamentals remained the same. Traditional, healthy societies ate food that has always been food. The fundamentals So what does this mean for us? In a way, it’s about going back to basics. No matter what the individual make up of your particular diet may be, it should be built around real foods that don’t come with an ingredients list the size of your arm. Food should be fresh, local, and seasonal wherever possible for a wide variety of nutrients throughout the year. Whilst ‘fad’ diets have come and gone, the fundamentals of healthy living have remained largely the same. There is no particular diet that is right for everyone, but the main principles are as follows. 1) Eat plenty of plants No matter our age, sex, weight or body type, we could all benefit from eating more fresh fruits and vegetables. You’ll be very hard pressed to find anyone who would argue otherwise. Enjoy them in all shapes, sizes and colours; berries, orchard fruits, roots, shoots, tubers and greens. Ideally, eat fruits and vegetables that are local and in season. They will be fresher, more nutritious, and better tasting than their imported counterparts, and it will also ensure that you consume a wide variety of produce throughout the year. Plants should form the basis of each meal and take up the majority of your plate. Aim for at least 12 portions each day – it sounds hard, but is easily achieved when you eat them at each meal! 2) Consume high quality protein Our natural satiety mechanisms for protein (especially when it comes to meat) make it naturally difficult to drastically over or under eat. Therefore, we should prioritise the quality of our protein intake, rather than focusing on quantity:
  • If you eat meat, then choose the highest quality that you can find. Grass fed, organic beef and lamb; free range poultry; outdoor reared pork; and wild caught game. Animals that are raised in humane conditions, with freedom to roam outside and fed on a natural diet contain more nutrients and have a healthier ratio of fatty acids than conventionally reared animals. Conventionally reared animals contain toxins that develop thanks to their poor diet and unsanitary living conditions.
  • We understand that organic meat is more expensive, so in order to save money, opt for cheaper cuts; beef shin instead of sirloin steak, lamb shanks instead of lamb chops, or chicken thighs instead of chicken breasts. These cuts are often tastier too, and with just a little TLC can make a fantastic dinner for the whole family. Eat less meat too - it's better to eat small amounts of high quality meat than copious amounts of the factory farmed stuff.
  • When it comes to fish, choose wild caught and prioritise omega 3 rich fish such as salmon, mackerel and sardines. If you’re vegan or just don’t like fish, then a high quality omega 3 supplement is highly advisable.
  • Eggs are a cheap and highly nutritious protein source. Choose free range and organic, preferably from your local farm.
  • If you’re vegetarian or vegan, then you have to be a little more discerning to make sure you meet your daily protein requirements. Choose nutritious, easy to digest protein sources: pulses such as lentils and chick peas (ideally soaked and sprouted), hemp, chlorella and spirulina, flaxseed, and chia seed.
For a rough guide to your required protein intake, check out our daily protein calculator. 3) Adjust carbs to suit your lifestyle Despite what some voracious low carb circles would have you believe, carbohydrates are not the enemy. They fuel our workouts, keep our hormones in check, nourish our adrenal glands and generally make us feel good. But some people need more carbohydrates than others. In general, the more active you are, the more carbs you require. If you regularly partake in high intensity, glycogen depleting sports that involve sprinting or heavy lifting, then you’ll need to eat enough carbs to fuel your performance and training goals. As with protein, your carbohydrate intake should come from high quality, whole food sources. Starchy vegetables such as potatoes, sweet potatoes, yams, squash and plantains are excellent choices, as they come packaged with plenty of beneficial nutrients and soluble fibre. Processed carbs are very easy to over consume, as the lack of nutrients and fibre throw off our satiety mechanisms. When it comes to carbs, experiment with what works for you. If you’re struggling to lose weight, then you may wish to consider lowering your intake. On the other hand, if you’re lacking energy in the gym or your recovery is suffering, you probably need to be eating a few more. Again, it’s about listening to your body and giving it what it needs. 4) Don’t fear fat Fat is essential, so don’t fear it. We need it for brain function, cardiovascular health, joint mobility, digestive wellness, hormonal balance, and healthy skin, hair and nails. It provides a rich source of easily metabolised energy, and eating more of it teaches our body how to burn it in stored form and actually lose weight. Like protein and carbohydrates, the quality of the fat you consume is essential (see a pattern emerging here?). Grass fed beef and lamb, wild caught fish, egg yolks, avocados, nuts and seeds are all excellent sources of healthy fats. Choose unrefined, virgin oils such as olive oil for dressing, and use heat stable fats such as coconut oil for cooking. On the other side of the coin, avoid highly processed, refined fats such as vegetable oil and margarine. These are high in oxidised, unstable fatty acids that cause inflammation in our bodies. Fats contain more calories per gram than protein and carbohydrates, and are therefore the most satiating nutrient and great for keeping hunger at bay. Eat high quality fats as close to their natural form as possible on a daily basis for optimum wellness. Anyone for some guacamole? 5) Choose nutrients, not numbers Rather than focusing on calorie intake, prioritise high quality, nutrient dense food. Don’t force yourself to under eat or go hungry; on the contrary, when eating high quality food, you should feel more satisfied than ever before! Chasing numbers and weighing food isn't sustainable, and it's certainly not much fun. So put the calorie counter to one side for now, and focus on filling your plate with nutrition, not mathematics. 6) Keep it interesting! Keep your diet interesting by rotating your food choices! Variety is key to preventing ‘food boredom’ and eventually falling off the wagon head first into a jar of Nutella. Even more importantly though, varying your food choices ensures that you benefit from a greater variety of nutrients and antioxidants from foods of all shapes, sizes and colours. Eat with the seasons to enjoy food at it’s freshest and most nutritious. Try a different fruit or vegetable every week. Swap your peanut butter for almond butter, or your green tea for a herbal tea. Whatever diet you follow, keeping it interesting will benefit both your body and tastebuds. So… what defines a healthy diet? To answer our own question, a healthy diet shouldn’t be defined by a strict set of rules. Eating healthily isn’t about following the latest fad diet or weight loss programme. It’s not about obsessively counting calories or weighing every meal. Whether you’re vegan or paleo, a high level athlete or just a recreational frisbee player; healthy eating is about eating real, unprocessed foods as close to their natural forms as possible. And most of all, it’s about listening to our bodies, and learning what works for us. Simple, isn’t it? If you like this article, please share it with a friend :) [icegram messages="7123"]

item.title: An easy guide to pre and post workout skincare!
item.dc:creator: Leyla Cooper
item.content:encoded: This article is a guest post by Leyla Cooper, skincare expert and founder of Pretty Athletic, the UK's first skincare range for active women! Exercise is great for your skin. Working up a good sweat allows your pores to dilate and expel trapped dirt and oils, and more blood reaches the skin's surface to deliver key nutrients. There is even research which suggests that exercise keeps skin younger and may help reverse the aging process. However, exercise can also be associated with a whole host of skincare problems - skin breakouts, redness, sensitivity, and sun damage, just to name a few. The right pre & post-workout skincare regime can help to prevent these common skincare problems to leave you with healthy, glowing skin. Follow my tips below to keep your skin glowing with health before, during, and after you exercise! Cleanse It is important to cleanse your skin both before as well as immediately after exercising. The key here is to use a gentle cleanser that is effective at getting rid of sweat, oil and dirt but that doesn't upset or dry out your skin. Look for gentle plant-based cleansing agents such as lauryl glucoside and coco glucoside rather than the more widely-used synthetic cleaning agents that can irritate skin and strip it of its natural oils. Soothing botanical extracts such as aloe vera, lavender and green tea help to reduce redness and sensitivity. After you workout, it is important to avoid products that can exacerbate sensitive skin such as cleansers with abrasive scrub particles. Exfoliation is important, but not before or after you exercise. Also aim to limit the time you spend in a hot shower, as this can dry out your skin. Protect If you exercise outside regularly, you should be applying sun protection before you head out the door. Don't just rely on using a basic moisturiser that has a low SPF, if you are regularly exercising outside you need a sun cream with a high SPF to protect your skin from sun damage. Ensure your product provides both UVA and UVB protection. Look for sunscreens with zinc oxide or titanium dioxide which are considered to be highly effective against sun damage. These two ingredients work by reflecting the sun's rays, they sit on the skin (rather than penetrating the skin like other sun protection ingredients) and as a result they are considered to be less irritating. In the winter months, if your concern is dryness and dehydration from the wind and cold you should apply a lightweight barrier cream. Look for great natural ingredients such as castor oil and shea butter. Repair Post-workout, apply a light moisturiser after cleansing to rehydrate and nourish the skin. (It goes without saying that you should also drink plenty of water to rehydrate from the inside!) If your skin is prone to redness look for soothing ingredients such as aloe vera and chamomile. Ensure your post-workout moisturiser is rich in antioxidants. Antioxidants assist with skin repair by helping to protect your skin from the damaging effects of free radicals from sunlight, air pollution, wind, and intense exercise. The moisturiser or serum you apply after exercising should have a range of antioxidants such as vitamins C and E, or ingredients that are naturally rich in antioxidants such as rosehip oil. Just like your body is in recovery mode after exercise, the same goes for your skin. Treat it with the TLC it deserves and you'll notice the difference! Click here to browse the full Pretty Athletic skincare range, created especially for active women who want beautifully radiant skin - no matter how hard they train!

item.title: How I overcame my food addiction and lost weight naturally
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: The following story comes courtesy of Holly Ifeanyi-armstrong, a friend and customer at Vivo Life. Holly's weight loss journey is quite a remarkable one, and we're very proud to feature her story on our blog. Have you been on a health journey and would like to share your story with the Vivo Team? Contact us here and your story could be featured in a future article! Take it away, Holly! Right from an early age , I've always been that little bit bigger then most, my weight and the way I looked was always an issue. Being 5ft 11 you can hardly hide yourself away in the crowd! In the past, food always found a way to control me. If I was sad I would eat, if I was happy I would eat. Before long I found myself saying oh it's only food, just one more portion wouldn't hurt. Little did I know it was having huge physical and mental effects on my body. My Turning Point In 2013 I was blessed with a beautiful baby girl. She was the apple of my eye, my everything. That happiness soon faded and I was finding myself plagued with sadness and depression; how will I take my daughter to the park without getting out of breath? What will I say to my daughter when she asks to go on a ride and I'm told I'm too big or I'm too overweight? From that moment I knew I had to do something to not only change my appearance but to change my mental state as well. So I set myself a target to lose 2 stone for my daughters 1st birthday. At aged 23 and weighing 17stone 7lb I started my journey into getting healthy. First it was easy; I cut down on my sugar intake, gave up bread, crisps and coke, and stopped eating past 6pm at night. Living in London it is easy to get public transport anywhere you need to go, but instead of taking the bus 10 stops down the road I would walk instead. After a while I joined a gym and went 3 times a week. After a few months people started to tell me how I had lost weight and how much better I was looking - but I kept my head down and kept working! In 2014 my daughter's birthday arrived and it was time to weigh. Not only did I lose weight but I smashed my original goal of 2 stone, losing a total of 4 stone 4lb. I couldn't believe it, I was beyond happy, my health wasn't considered a risk anymore, I was able to buy clothes in shops I could only dream of buying in before. Things didn't stop there - I continued to eat healthily and exercise, and the weight continued to fall off. Yes there were good days and bad days, but I knew that by overcoming my addiction the food was no longer in control. I was. I knew that if I slipped up today, I can work extra hard tomorrow and get straight back on track. So another year on, and in total I am 6 stone 7lb down, I'm happier then I've ever been, and can run around with my daughter without getting out of breath! For me, that's worth every second of the last few years. In my journey I've learned so much about myself, I'm mentally stronger, I'm in charge of my body and what goes into it. I've changed everything about my lifestyle from what I eat and drink to what I wear. But most importantly, I've changed the way I see and think about myself. Are you inspired by Holly's story? Are you ready to make positive changes TODAY? Download our FREE 24 page ebook 'How to Lose Weight Naturally' - and effortlessly slim down to reach your ideal weight!

item.title: Choosing the Perfect Protein Powder
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: Nowadays, protein powders aren’t just for bodybuilders and gym junkies. People from all walks of life are now whizzing them into their smoothies, sprinkling them over their breakfasts, and even using them for baking. For many of us, particularly those who are busy and often on the go, a high quality protein powder is an excellent way to make sure we are consuming enough protein from a variety of sources. In our previous article, we discovered what you should be looking for in your protein powder. Doing this cuts out 99% of the junk on the market, and leaves you with a carefully selected handful of premium quality protein powders. It then comes down to a simple case of personal preference, and choosing the right product to suit your lifestyle, your health goals, and of course, your budget. Check out the list below to help find the perfect protein powder for you! Best protein for value If you’re looking for value for money from your protein powder, then look no further than Pulsin’s Raw Hemp Protein. It costs just £23.99 per kilo, which works out at under 50p per serving. Hemp has a complete amino acid profile, which makes raw hemp protein ideal for use after your workouts. It is also high in fibre, so is great for keeping hunger at bay and stopping cravings in their path! Best protein for taste Taste is so important when choosing a protein powder! If adding protein to your shakes and smoothies feels like more of a chore and less of a pleasure, it’s time to change things up. We love Revolution Foods’ Raw Plant Protein, which has a delicious berry flavour that is just perfect for adding to your fruit smoothies. Purple Balance’s Raw Natural Protein and Chocolate Warrior Food are great for all you chocoholics out there, and Ezyprotein Silk Superfood is delicious if you fancy something smooth and sweet. Best protein for athletes If you take a protein powder to support your training, there are two questions you need to ask. Does it contain all the essential amino acids needed for growth and repair? And is it easy to digest? We love Organic Whey Protein, Revolution Foods Raw Plant Protein, and Sunwarrior Warrior Food for post workout recovery. Vega Performance Protein is also great, as it comes with added BCAA to maximise protein synthesis, and digestive enzymes to help you absorb all the goodness. Best protein for vegans Finding a vegan protein powder isn’t difficult – in fact, most of the best protein powders on the market these days are plant based! Garden of Life, Sunwarrior, Purple Balance, Ezyprotein and Vega all make fantastic vegan protein blends. A special mention also goes to Epic Protein Green Kingdom, which is made with some of the most nutrient dense green superfoods on the planet - perfect for getting some real nutritional bang for your buck! Best protein for hunger cravings If you’re looking for some nourishment in between your main meals that won’t leave you hungry again in an hour, a high protein snack is always the best option. As the most satiating nutrient, protein will help satisfy your hunger cravings and keep your blood sugar levels stable. Purple Balance Raw Green Protein is a great option, blending cold pressed hemp protein with organic superfoods such as maca, spirulina and lucuma. If you’d prefer something solid to eat, we love Pulsin’s protein bars: Maple and Whey, Maple and Peanut, and Vanilla Choc Chip.   Remember – protein from whole foods is always preferential to protein in powder form; but there is definitely room for a high quality protein powder in a balanced diet. Browse our selection for some of the most nutritious protein powders available anywhere today – so you can guarantee whenever you use it, you’ll be making the best choice for your health. Unsure of how much protein you should be eating? Check out our easy to use Daily Protein Calculator to work out your daily needs!

item.title: Recipe: Banana and Butterscotch Fudge Topped Cacao Bites
item.dc:creator: Sinead McGill
item.content:encoded: The following recipe is a guest post by Sinead Mcgill of SCM Fitness. Are you a talented recipe writer who would like to be featured on the Vivo Life Blog? Get in touch here with your ideas! Fitness and food are two things very close to my heart, but as much as I love cakes, cookies and sweet treats, it definitely isn't a diet advisable for anyone (let alone a PT)! Although for any diet to be sustainable it needs to be enjoyable, just like exercise. A diet shouldn't mean rabbit foods and the same plain boring meals, so I've been experimenting in the kitchen to come up with a range of delicious yet healthy treats which I hope you will all enjoy making! Banana and Butterscotch Fudge Topped Cacao Bites Recipe makes 20 bites Ingredients: 2 tbsp extra virgin coconut oil 100g dates 50g almonds 2 tbsp raw cacao powder 2 tbsp lucuma powder 2 tbsp raw cacao nibs 30g organic puffed rice (optional, for texture). For the butterscotch: 1 ripe banana 2 tbsp raw cacao brazil nut bliss 1 tbsp lucuma powder 1/2 tsp vanilla extract Method:  1) Gently melt 2 tbsp of coconut oil in a pan until liquid. Add to the food processor with the dates and almonds, and blitz until you create a paste. 2) Add the raw cacao powder and lucuma to the mix, then blitz again until a thick mixture has formed. 3) Remove the mixture from the food processor and stir in the cacao nibs and puffed rice. Flatten in a square baking tray and leave to set in the refrigerator. 4) Meanwhile, mash the banana in a bowl with the cacao brazil nut bliss, lucuma and vanilla until a rich, fudge like texture is formed. Spread this over the base, and leave to set in the fridge for an hour. 5) Cut the bites into squares before serving. Enjoy!

item.title: Recipe: Dairy Free 'Cookie Dough' Ice Cream
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: When the sun's out, all I want to do is dive face first into a giant tub of ice cream. But I don't (can't) eat dairy... so that means ice cream is off limits, right? Wrong! With just a few simple ingredients, you can make your own dairy free, vegan ice cream in minutes. No ice cream maker or fancy equipment required - just a freezer, some frozen bananas, and flavours of your choice. I've made a few different flavours in the past, but this 'Cookie Dough' tops the lot! Let's get to the recipe... Dairy Free 'Cookie Dough' Ice Cream Serves 4 Ingredients: 3 ripe bananas 1 large tablespoon Pip and Nut Coconut Almond Butter 1 teaspoon raw honey (or maple syrup to make vegan) 1 teaspoon organic lucuma powder Drop of vanilla extract 2 tablespoons raw cacao nibs Method: 1) Dice your bananas, put them in an air tight bag, and place in the freezer for 3 - 4 hours. 2) Remove bananas from the freezer and add to your food processor. Blitz for 1 minute until smooth and creamy. 3) Add 1 large tablespoon of Pip and Nut Coconut Almond Butter and 1 teaspoon of raw honey / maple syrup. Blitz again until thoroughly combined. 4) Add 1 teaspoon organic lucuma powder and a drop of vanilla extract. Blitz again. 5) Transfer into 4 individual servings bowls. Top each bowl with a generous scatter of raw cacao nibs and enjoy! [icegram messages="7123"]

item.title: What's hiding in your toothpaste?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: Take a quick look at the label of your tube of toothpaste. Do you recognise the ingredients that go into your mouth each day, or do they resemble somewhat of a science experiment? Do you know where triclosan, carrageenan, or sodium lauryl sulfate actually come from – or, indeed, why they are in your toothpaste in the first place? If you’re anything like most people, chances are this is the first time you have taken any note of the ingredients that you use to clean your teeth every morning. You see, when someone tells us something is good for us, we tend to act first and ask questions later. Sometimes, those questions never get answered. For generations, we have grown up thinking that commercial toothpaste brands such as Colgate, Aquafresh and Oral B are essential for healthy teeth, strong gums and a bright smile. But is this really the case? Or are mainstream toothpastes actually causing us more harm than good? It’s time to take a look at what’s really hiding in our toothpaste. Fluoride Perhaps the main offender in commercial toothpastes is fluoride, an element that is supposedly added for its cavity preventive effects, despite there being very little evidence to support this claim¹. Fluoride has been shown to be toxic to the body – even in trace amounts. The Fluoride Action Network² gives a detailed analysis of the health impacts of fluoride, with strong evidence linking it to behavioural issues, endocrine disruption, impaired fertility, cardiovascular disease, and even cancer. There is also strong evidence³ that links fluoride with impaired thyroid function, immune system dysfunction, and the acceleration of the aging process4. Triclosan Triclosan is used for it’s anti-microbial effects, but is a known disruptor of the endocrine and thyroid hormones5,6. SLS SLS is found commonly in many skincare products, used to create a foamy lather in everything from shower gels and shampoos to your toothpaste. SLS has long been shown to irritate sensitive skin, but has also been shown in studies to cause mouth ulcers and canker sores7. Many people avoid SLS in their skincare products – so why should we still be using it in our toothpaste? Titanium Dioxide There are widespread concerns as to the potentially carcinogenic effects of titanium dioxide8, particularly when used in combination with other chemicals such as SLS. Titanium Dioxide is formed of tiny ‘nano particles’ that absorb quickly and easily into the bloodstream. Carrageenan Carrageenan has been shown to be destructive to digestive lining, even in trace amounts, triggering an immune response similar to when your body has when invaded by pathogens like Salmonella9. Artificial Colours and Sweeteners Artificial colours are regularly added to toothpastes to make them look lovely on the brush, and sweeteners such as sorbitol, glycerol and maltitol are added to give it a ‘sweeter’ taste. If you avoid artificial colours and sweeteners in your food, why not do the same with your toothpaste? But I'm not swallowing my toothpaste... so that's ok, right? Because we don’t technically ‘ingest’ toothpaste, the regulations about the ingredients that can and cannot be used are far more relaxed than the regulations that govern our food production. In fact, many of the common toothpaste ingredients are illegal in our food supply. But just because we’re not swallowing these ingredients does not make them any safer to use. Our mouths are one of the most absorbent areas of our entire body, and the nano sized particles of the chemicals found in toothpaste are easily absorbed; allowing these chemicals to reach our bloodstream in seconds. On commercial toothpastes, the following warning comes as standard: If swallowed, consult a doctor immediately. If you saw that warning on anything else, would you still put it in your mouth? A safer alternative Fortunately, there is a much safer alternative to conventional toothpaste. Brands such as Jason, Nature’s Answer and Kingfisher provide natural formulations that are every bit as effective as their counterparts – but without the scary health risks. Take one look at the ingredients list of any of these toothpastes and you won’t find any chemicals – just natural plant extracts, essential oils and active botanicals. From my own experience, after using Jason Powersmile Antiplaque and Whitening for almost a year now, my teeth have undoubtedly got stronger and visibly whiter. I suffer rarely from tooth sensitivity, which always used to be a problem when brushing with conventional toothpaste. Want to make the switch to natural toothpaste? Head on over to our Dental Care section and browse the full range! Sources: 1) The Case Against Fluoride – Paul Connett, James Beck, H.Spedding Micklem 2) http://fluoridealert.org/researchers/health_database/ 3) http://thyroid.about.com/cs/toxicchemicalsan/a/flouride.htm 4) Review of Fluoride Benefits and Risks, Department of Health and Human Services (1991) 5) http://www.beyondpesticides.org/antibacterial/health/ 6) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20562219 7) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7825393 8) http://www.ccohs.ca/headlines/text186.html 9) http://www.prevention.com/food/healthy-eating-tips/carrageenan-natural-ingredient-you-should-ban-your-diet

item.title: Finding your balance
item.dc:creator: Hannah Darvas
item.content:encoded: Guest post from Hannah Darvas of @hannahdarvas and Beating Bulimia. My name is Hannah. I am a 20 year old graphic designer, and in my free time a food blogger and health advocate on instagram under the handle @healthnuthannah. I am also a recovered bulimic. Like many in the quest to achieve happiness, I was once sucked into the dieting industry. Promised the perfect body, with the perfect life and bundles of happiness and joy. Oh how wrongly this was portrayed. The initial, naive process of eating ‘better’ soon turned into a full blown obsession and addiction. Due to the unrealistic and restrictive goals that I set myself, long periods of under-eating and over exercise inevitably lead to my body being in a huge deficit of the vital nutrients required to function. It also left my brain hugely malnourished, meaning that thinking straight was no longer a capability of mine. A result of this unhealthy lifestyle soon lead to periods of binge eating and purging - otherwise known as Bulimia. The guilt I would feel after consuming (even a small amount) of a ‘banned’ food would result in despair and a compulsive need to ‘self sabotage’ by consuming anything and everything in sight. I was deeply unhappy. My body swollen; hair and nails weak. It was an addiction that either I’d have to beat, or would eventually kill me. The problem with avoidance, in any form, is that you’re then putting your mind in a position where it’s likely to want that forbidden item 4x as more. Although we are all very keen to believe that our favourite celebrities or health icons are TRULY happy with eating steamed broccoli, avoiding carbs and living with all treats off the menu, I can almost guarantee you that this is NOT the case. Their portrayed lifestyles are both filtered, and unsustainable. I only wish someone was by my side telling me this 5 years ago. Luckily for me, the process of getting out of the woods has been nothing but an empowering one. Being honest and open with those around me has turned my negative situation into such a positive opportunity to create a change – in both my lifestyle and the lifestyle of those sharing my journey. For those of you that have followed my instagram, you’ll have all been aware that my life over the past two years hasn’t been plain sailing. But a dedication and drive to regain my life has seen me come on in leaps and bounds. I often get asked what my secret is. How I found my cure and how I continue to maintain and achieve a balance within my daily routine. But for this, there is no simple answer. It’s been nothing but a long and arduous process of trial and error. The good days often being engulfed by subsequent moments of falling off the wagon and despair, but there’s one thing that has always prevailed – my desire to change. I ditched the diets, the numbers and the self obsessed goggles that I’d been wearing for far too long, and decided that I wanted to achieve something that would sustain me for life; not just for the short term. This is where balance became key. From living in avoidance of all of the things that I loved (which, in the end, only lead to binge eating and subsequent self harm), I decided that eating well 70% of the time, surely allowed for the ability to have those 'feared foods' in moderation. And the rest is history. Letting go of the irrational and damaging rules that a diet confines you to is not only liberating, but it gives you back the life that you once knew and loved. Flexibility and balance in your day-to-day routine not only keeps your body healthy, but your mind healthy too – and that’s the most important crux of it all. Although an ice cream sandwich with chocolate sprinkles and caramel sauce may not be deemed 'healthy' on paper, it may just be the healthiest addition of all to your day if it is to create happiness. And that is for you to decide. When we stop scrutinising foods for their macronutrient values and instead appreciate them for how they taste and make us feel, food can once again become a friend rather than a foe. Diets are for today. Balance is for life.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Guest post by Hannah Darvas, recovered Bulimic. Discover how balance is an essential component of good health, yet one that is often overlooked.
Guest post by Hannah Darvas, recovered Bulimic. Discover how balance is an essential component of good health, yet one that is often overlooked.

item.title: Recipe: Caramel Protein Pancakes
item.dc:creator: Sinead McGill
item.content:encoded: The following recipe is a guest post by Sinead Mcgill of SCM Fitness. Are you a talented recipe writer who would like to be featured on the Vivo Life Blog? Get in touch here with your ideas! After Sinead's previous recipe went down a treat with so many of you, we had no choice but to invite her back for a second one! If you're after some serious breakfast inspiration, this one won't disappoint... Caramel Protein Pancakes Recipe makes 4 pancakes Ingredients: 1 tbsp organic virgin coconut oil 1 scoop unflavoured protein powder (such as hemp protein or pea protein) 1 mashed banana 2 eggs 2 teaspoons organic lucuma powder Drop of vanilla extract (optional) To serve: Drizzle of organic maple syrup or sweetener of choice Handful of raw cacao nibs (optional) Method: 1) Heat the coconut oil in a medium sized frying pan over a medium heat. 2) Whisk together the protein powder, mashed banana, eggs, lucuma and vanilla until a smooth batter is formed. The lucuma helps to bind the mixture and imparts a delicious caramel flavour. Take care to whisk thoroughly to avoid lumps. 3) Gently pour a quarter of the batter into the frying pan using a pouring spout. Fry for 2 - 3 minutes before flipping and cooking for a further minute on the reverse side. 4) When the pancake is done, transfer to your serving plate and repeat with the remaining pancake mixture. If you have a larger frying pan, you can cook more than one pancake at a time. 5) Serve and drizzle with a little maple syrup or raw honey. Finish with a scatter of cacao nibs. Enjoy!

item.title: The wonders of Coconut Aminos
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: Is there anything that can’t be made from coconuts? Perhaps the most famous coconut-based health food is coconut oil, well known for being perhaps the healthiest cooking oil on the planet. Then there’s coconut water, coconut butter, coconut sugar and coconut flour. Coconuts can be used to make snacks, soaps and even raw chocolate – they truly are one of the most versatile foods on the planet! And just when you thought that there was nothing left that you could possibly do with a coconut, along comes another innovation that might just be one of the best yet. Although a fairly unknown product in the UK, Coconut Aminos has been taking countries like the USA, Canada and Australia by storm for years. Taste it for yourself, and you soon realise they’re on to something pretty good. So what is it? Made from the nutrient dense sap of the coconut tree blossom, Coconut Aminos is an incredibly delicious all-purpose seasoning that can be used as a direct replacement for soy sauce. The flavour is similar but more well-rounded; Coconut Aminos is slightly sweeter, less salty, and enhances the natural flavour profile of your food rather than overpowering it. Coconut Aminos is amazing in marinades, sauces, stir fries, or simply drizzled over salads. How’s it made? Coconut Aminos is made by ‘tapping’ the nutrient rich sap of the coconut tree blossom, a traditional process that has been used by coconut farmers for thousands of years. When the tree is tapped, the sap flows in abundance from the blossom, causing no harm to the tree which can be returned to time and time again. This sap is then aged to develop a delicious flavour profile that is savoury and sweet in equal measure, before being blended with a little sun dried, mineral rich sea salt from the Philippines. The resulting product is 100% raw and organic, low GI, and naturally gluten free. The health benefits Given the health risks associated with soy consumption, swapping your soy sauce with coconut aminos is an excellent way to improve your health without missing out on any of the umami-rich deliciousness. The nutrient rich sap of the coconut tree blossom contains 17 different amino acids, B vitamins and vitamin C, and is an excellent source of essential minerals such as potassium, magnesium and phosphorus. How do I use it? Coconut aminos is exceptionally versatile, imparting an exquisite depth of flavour to just about any savoury dish. As we touched on earlier, coconut aminos is rich in ‘umami’, the recently discovered fifth taste after sweet, sour, salty and bitter. Umami is a uniquely savoury compound which has been acknowledged in traditional Asian cuisine for centuries – yet only in the last few years has it been recognised in the Western world. Other recognised sources of umami include roasted tomatoes, parmesan cheese, soy sauce, bacon and mushrooms. It’s that deep, savoury flavour that brings otherwise boring dishes to life – which is why coconut aminos makes such an excellent addition to such a wide range of cuisines. Here are a few easy ways to use coconut aminos: As a garnish: Drizzle coconut aminos over hot meals to activate the umami flavour compounds and bring your dinner to life. It’s incredible on roast chicken, vegetable chillies, warming soups and root vegetables. As a salad dressing: Combine coconut aminos with a glug of extra virgin olive oil and toss liberally over your salad. In your stir fries: As the perfect replacement for soy sauce, add a dash of coconut aminos to your stir fries to replicate an authentic Asian flavour sensation. Combine with rice wine vinegar, garlic, ginger, coriander, fresh pineapple and cashew nuts for an out of this world meal in minutes. As a marinade: Use as part of a marinade for meat to tenderise and enrich it with awesome flavour. Amazing with beef, chicken, and even fish. It’s an integral part of this recipe for "damn fine chicken", which is a real hit if you have guests over. As a sauce: Combine coconut aminos with other ingredients to make a homemade sauce. Add a splash to homemade ketchup to boost the flavour profile, or combine with tomatoes, onion, garlic, blackstrap molasses, paprika and oregano for a seriously tasty bbq sauce. If you fancy something a little more exotic, why not try this recipe for Paleo Hoi Sin Sauce? One thing to note with coconut aminos – a little goes a long way! One bottle yields approximately 48 servings, and just a subtle splash is more than enough to transform your meals in seconds. Click here to try coconut aminos for yourself – be sure to let us know what you think!

item.title: 9 simple food swaps for a healthier store cupboard
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: For someone that’s new to healthy eating, knowing where to begin is often the trickiest part. No matter how hard you may try, when your store cupboard is packed with convenience foods and sugary snacks, it’s almost impossible not to give in to temptation. If you’re serious about making a positive change, your best bet is to remove all the rubbish and rebuild your store cupboard from scratch. If you already live in a healthy household, why not do this with a friend or family member instead to help them get started? Check out our 9 simple swaps for a healthier store cupboard, and take the first step towards a healthier lifestyle today! 1) Vegetable oil → Extra Virgin Coconut Oil If you make one change to your store cupboard, make it this one! Despite the healthy sounding name, ‘vegetable’ oil is not actually made from vegetables at all; rather, a mix of hydrogenated seed oils, including soybean, corn, and cottonseed. They are a relatively new addition to the human diet – approximately 300 years ago, they were used as fuel for cars and as an emulsifier in cleaning products! Vegetable oils contribute to inflammation in our cells thanks to the extraordinarily high omega 6 content, and have been directly linked to numerous alarming health conditions including heart disease, hypertension, diabetes and various cancers1,2,3. They oxidise at low temperatures too, which makes them unsuitable for cooking. Oxidised fatty acids form free radicals in our body, which accelerate the aging process from the inside out. Coconut oil, on the other hand, is composed of medium chain triglycerides, a healthy fatty acid that burns easily for energy. It has natural antibacterial and antimicrobial properties, and is safe to cook with because it doesn’t oxidise at a high heat. Coconut oil has even been linked to the prevention of degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s and dementia4,5. Use coconut oil in the very same way that you would use vegetable oil – for cooking, baking and frying. Be sure to buy raw coconut oil rather than refined coconut oil for maximum health benefits and flavour. Once you make the switch to coconut oil, you’ll never want to go back to rancid vegetable oils again! 2) Sugar → Coconut Palm Sugar / Honey We already know that cutting down on refined sugars is one of the most important things we can do for our health. If you’re a sugar addict, it’s probably in your best interest to eliminate sugar entirely – at least for a few weeks until your palate adjusts and your sugar cravings subside. Once these are under control, you can replace your refined white sugar with a healthier alternative, such as coconut palm sugar or raw honey. Coconut sugar has a much lower GI than table sugar, so won’t cause the same spikes in blood glucose, whilst honey contains beneficial enzymes, phytonutrients and antioxidants. Remember though, they should both be considered as an occasional treat rather than an everyday indulgence! For more about sugar and healthier alternatives, read this article. 3) Tea → Herbal Tea Whilst there is certainly nothing wrong with the average cuppa, it is the things that usually accompany it – i.e milk, sugar, and the occasional biscuit – that are the main offenders. Herbal teas, on the other hand, have numerous beneficial health properties that make them a much more viable alternative. Antioxidant rich green tea, for example, has been shown to improve fat oxidation6, ginger tea can improve digestion7, whilst chamomile tea may aid relaxation and improve sleep quality8. This just scratches the surface of the many benefits that herbal tea can offer, so don’t be afraid to experiment to find your favourite varieties! 4) Wheat Flour → Coconut Flour / Almond Meal / Chickpea Flour It is estimated that wheat intolerance has increased by approximately 400% in the last 50 years alone9. Along with the much maligned gluten, wheat also contains high concentration of lectins and phytate, both of which interfere with nutrient absorption in the digestive tract. Wheat flour is devoid of virtually all nutrients; so much so, that it is now European law that manufacturers must add certain minerals to wheat flour to help prevent deficiency in consumers. [icegram messages="7123"] Whether you are gluten intolerant or otherwise, wheat flour contains nothing but empty carbohydrate, and has little place in a healthy store cupboard. Whilst whole foods are always the healthiest option, if you do need to use a little flour in baked goods, try using coconut flour, almond meal, or chickpea flour. All three are much higher in protein and fibre, and are easier for our bodies to digest. 5) Chocolate → Raw Chocolate Good news – eating healthily doesn’t mean you have to give up your chocolate habit! But rather than heavily processed chocolate containing milk and sugar, opt for raw chocolate instead. Raw chocolate could well be one of the tastiest health foods ever discovered. It is packed full of powerful antioxidants, is rich in minerals including magnesium, iron and zinc, and has been shown to have a profound impact on our heart health10,11. Believe it or not, there really is such thing as a healthy chocolate habit. Want to learn more about the benefits of raw chocolate, and how you can make your own? Read this article! Or click here to browse our full range of raw chocolate delights! 6) Malt / Spirit Vinegar → Apple Cider Vinegar Much like tea, there is nothing particularly wrong with malt or spirit vinegar (unless you are coeliac, as malt vinegar may contain traces of gluten). But if there were a much healthier, better tasting alternative, you would choose that – right? Step forward apple cider vinegar. With natural antibacterial and anti-pathogenic properties12,13,14, apple cider vinegar is an excellent way to detoxify the body and prevent against a build-up of potentially harmful bacteria. Apple cider vinegar has also been proven to help with weight loss and body fat reduction15. It contains beneficial enzymes which help to improve the assimilation of nutrients when taken before or with a meal, boost immunity and stimulate the lymphatic system16. Apple cider vinegar truly is a miracle food, and a great addition to any healthy store cupboard! Use it as part of your favourite dressings and marinades for some serious health benefits. 7) Crisps → Nuts / Kale Chips If you have a craving for something crunchy, don’t turn to a packet of ready salted. Healthy snacks such as nuts and kale chips are excellent ways to satisfy your cravings without compromising your health! Both are packed with more protein and fibre too, so won’t leave you hungry for more soon after eating. 8) Soy Sauce → Coconut Aminos There is strong evidence that links soy consumption to potential hormonal disruptions, hypothyroidism and impaired endocrine function17. Soy also has high levels of phytic acid, which binds with minerals in the digestive tract and renders them useless to the body, and trypsin inhibitors, which interfere with protein absorption. Luckily, there is a like-for-like replacement for soy sauce that means you don’t have to compromise on flavour in your stir fries, marinades and dressings. Coconut Aminos, made from the nutrient rich sap of the coconut palm blossom, is rich in B vitamins, vitamin C, amino acids, potassium, magnesium and phosphorus. It is 100% raw and organic, vegan friendly, and contains 65% less sodium than soy sauce. Click here to read more about the wonders of coconut aminos! 9) Table Salt → Himalayan Rock Salt Quite the opposite from common table salt, Himalayan Rock Salt is an excellent source of essential nutrients. The vibrant pink colour is a sign of the rich concentration; in total, it contains 82 different minerals, all key components for human health. Whilst we should definitely all look to avoid refined table salt, Himalayan Rock Salt is an excellent way to improve the flavour profile of your meals and benefit your health at the same time. Ready to get started? Check out our healthy store cupboard starter pack, and transform your pantry from health hazard into a treasure trove of wellbeing! Sources 1) Price, Weston A. Nutrition and Physical Degeneration: A Comparison of Primitive and Modern Diets and Their Effects, 8th ed. La Mesa, California: Price-Pottenger Nutrition Foundation 2008 2) Colpo, Anthony. The Great Cholesterol Con: Why Everything You’ve Been Told About Cholesterol, Diet and Heart Disease is Wrong! Raleigh, N.C: Lulu, 2006 3) Erasmus, Udo. Fats That Heal, Fats That Kill: The Complete Guide to Fats, Oils, Cholesterol, and Human Health. Burnaby, BC, Canada: Alive 1993 4) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3207358/ 5) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24150106 6) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23493529 7) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18403946 8) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2995283/ 9) http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/11/03/grain 10) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21807659 11) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21559039 12) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10656352 13) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9713753 14) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12380754 15) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19661687 16) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1785201/ 17) http://www.westonaprice.org/soy-alert/
