item.title: 9 signs you need more magnesium
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: Magnesium deficiency is the second most common deficiency in developed countries around the world, surpassed only in the Northern Hemisphere by lack of vitamin D. Less than 25% of adults in the UK now consume their Recommended Daily Allowance of magnesium (RDA) – that is, the minimum requirement as advised by the Food Standards Association. In many people, particularly those that are active, magnesium needs may be even greater. No matter how healthy your diet, there is a good chance that you could be at risk of magnesium deficiency. I discovered this myself the hard way, when faced with a couple of symptoms that (after much trial and error) I realised were being caused because of a lack of magnesium. Despite an incredibly healthy diet, I just wasn’t getting enough magnesium to meet my needs. But why was this the case? After doing further research, I realised that magnesium deficiency was a widespread problem. We are now, on average, consuming 50% less magnesium than we were 50 years ago¹. Magnesium is a mineral found in our soils and our water. However, thanks to intensive modern farming methods and the use of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, the mineral levels found in our soil have dropped rapidly. The result is a significantly reduced level of magnesium in our food supply, particularly in meat, vegetables and fruit. In some regions, magnesium levels in soil have dropped by as much as 80% since 1950. The same has happened with our water supply, with modern filtration and purification techniques significantly reducing the magnesium concentration. In today’s environment, it is exceptionally easy to become magnesium deficient. But how do you know if you are lacking in this essential mineral? Here are 9 signs to look out for! 1) You’re lacking energy Magnesium is utilised by every enzyme associated with ATP², the production of intracellular energy. When our magnesium levels are low, our production of ATP slows down, causing us to feel fatigued. Given the role that magnesium plays in ATP, supplementing with the mineral has been shown to offer significant performance boosting benefits for athletes – particularly those that had an existing magnesium deficiency³. 2) You sleep poorly Magnesium is crucial to good quality sleep, essential in the production of the hormone melatonin that regulates our circadian rhythm. Taking between 250 – 500mg magnesium before bed has been shown to boost sleep quality and duration, particularly for those that already suffer from difficulty sleeping4. 3) You’re stressed Magnesium is essential in a healthy stress response, and a lack of it can cause difficulty in dealing with both physical and mental stressors3,5. Conversely, our magnesium levels are depleted by the stress hormone cortisol, putting us at further risk of a deficiency, and in turn, more stress. Magnesium and stress are like two peas in a pod – only the peas really dislike each other. 4) You’re 'backed up' No one likes talking about poop, so I'll keep this one as brief as possible! If you're constipated, irregular, or are having difficulty passing stool, you may well be magnesium deficient. Magnesium helps to draw water into the colon to make stools softer and easier to pass. It's also a muscle relaxant, so eases any tension in the walls of the colon that may be causing constipation. 5) You suffer from headaches, lack of concentration, and ‘brain fog’ Studies have shown magnesium to be extremely beneficial for brain function, helping to improve concentration, along with both short and long term memory and recall6. By improving blood flow to the brain, magnesium has been shown to reduce the frequency and duration of headaches and migraines7. Magnesium also acts as a catalyst for dopamine production, the neurotransmitter associated with pleasure and reward. In other words, it makes you feel good too. 6) You eat a ‘standard western diet’ Not that this will apply to many readers of this blog (we hope!); but eating a standard western diet consisting of processed foods, grains and sugars puts you firmly at risk of a severe magnesium deficiency. Firstly, the diet is low in magnesium to begin with. But more importantly, popular western food ingredients including caffeine, alcohol, grains and sugar have actually been shown to prompt the expulsion of magnesium in the kidneys8, thus further increasing our demands for the mineral. Another culprit are carbonated beverages, which contain phosphates that have been shown to bind with magnesium in the digestive tract and impair our ability to absorb it9. 7) You get sick often If you fall sick often, it may be due to low magnesium. According to a 2008 study by the Universidade Tecnica de Lisboa in Portugal, a magnesium deficiency can weaken the immune system and make the body more susceptible to infection. 8) You eat a calcium rich diet, or take a calcium supplement Conventional wisdom tells us that we need calcium to build healthy bones, but this is only half the story. Calcium doesn’t work without the presence of magnesium (and visa-versa), so these minerals must be consumed in a complementary ratio (between 1:1 and 2:1) to harness the benefits. Consuming too much calcium and not enough magnesium may lead to abnormal levels of cellular calcium; so if you eat a calcium rich diet, taking a magnesium supplement is advisable to even things out. 9) You recover slowly from your workouts Magnesium, along with zinc, plays a central role in the recovery process (protein biosynthesis) of rebuilding muscle tissue after exercise. It also helps in the conversion of carbohydrates to muscle glycogen. If your exercise recovery is taking longer than you would like, consider upping your magnesium consumption. How to get more magnesium In today’s environment, it’s harder than ever before to consume enough magnesium from diet alone. The best sources are nuts and seeds, in particular pumpkin seeds, along with dark leafy greens, dark chocolate, mackerel, and avocados; but even by eating these foods regularly, it’s still very easy to be magnesium deficient. It is for this reason that I recommend most people to take a magnesium supplement, aiming for a total magnesium intake (from food and supplements) of 500 – 800mg per day. There are two types of magnesium supplements to consider, both of which are equally effective: Dietary magnesium Usually taken in the form of a capsule or powder. Absorbed through the digestive system. May be more beneficial when taken at night, particularly for those using it to improve sleep quality and muscle recovery. Transdermal magnesium Ideal for those with impaired digestive function, transdermal magnesium is absorbed through the skin. Usually comes in the form of a spray, or bath salts. Magnesium sprays can be particularly effective for muscle soreness after exercise. Magnesium bathing salts contain very high concentrations of magnesium, so often only require use once or twice a week to harness the benefits. If you enjoyed this article, please share it with a friend :)   Sources 1) Pao EM, Mickle SJ. Problem nutrients in the United States. Food Technology 35:58-79 2) http://chriskresser.com/9-steps-to-perfect-health-4-supplement-wisely/ 3) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9794094 4) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12163983 5) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1844561 6) www.cell.com/neuron/abstract/S0896-6273%2809%2901044-7 7) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18705538 8) http://www.burtsremedies.com/skin/frontend/default/apparel/files/ukvbgde379we6tgdf3o87yhfrhdf40389/Magnesium-Deficiency.pdf 9) Weiss GH, Sluss PM, Linke CA. Changes in urinary magnesium, citrate and oxalate levels due to cola consumption. Urology 1992;39:331-3

item.title: What are 'food grown' supplements?
item.dc:creator: Henrietta Norton
item.content:encoded:
Since the dawn of time, our bodies have evolved to run best on the nutrients found in food and botanical sources. No one can dispute that it is ‘real’ food itself that has made us the sophisticated and complex beings we are today. However modern life and farming practices have made it harder for us to receive the complete nourishment from food alone. Supplementing the diet has, for many, become more a necessity rather than a luxury. But are all supplements the same? Unsurprisingly, many people commonly believe that because a supplement product contains vitamins and minerals, it must be ‘natural’. However many of these ‘natural’ supplements aren’t natural at all, rather they are synthetic chemical products made in a lab just like pharmaceutical drugs deemed ‘unnatural’. How a nutrient is made can determine how well your body recognizes and therefore uses it. So just as you may be mindful about eating ‘processed’ foods, so too is there a need to be mindful about the supplements that you use. The Food-Grown™ difference Food-Grown™ Nutrients however are just as they sound; grown in food. The easiest way to understand this is to think how a plant provides nutrients in nature. A plant draws up salts from the soil (calcium carbonate for example) and converts them into a form of nutrient that we as humans can absorb and successfully utilize in our cells. We are not able to perform this conversion ourselves, hence our historic reliance on plants for our nutrient intake. The Food-Grown™ process is really very similar. We take an inorganic salt and embed it into a live food cell such as citrus pulp, carrot, cabbage, alfalfa, baker’s yeast or probiotic yoghurt. These live food cells then metabolize the inorganic salt and change its cellular structure into a nutrient food form that our bodies can recognize. The magic however is in the food as a whole. Food itself, is pretty clever. You will never find a plant that just contains iron for example. So if we eat a food rich in iron because we want to support the production of healthy red blood cells, the iron itself is surrounded by necessary co-factors that make this process even more possible, like vitamin B1 or folate. Each food contains its own orchestra, the harmonies of which our body is attuned to recognize. To quote Nutritional Therapist Judith A. DeCava in her book the Real Truth about Vitamins and Anti-oxidants: "Isolated, synthetic vitamins (or minerals) are devoid of all their synergists – factors which cooperatively work together to enable biochemical operation and action." The following chart demonstrates the absorption rate of Food-State nutrients in comparison with chemical nutrients: More than 50 independent studies have shown that Wild Nutrition’s Food–Grown™ process provides: 1) Greater Bio-availability: Unlike synthetically isolated vitamins and minerals, Food–Grown™ supplements are easily absorbed through the digestive system and delivered to the cellular level.  2) Targeted Delivery: Co-factors and co-enzymes within Wild Nutrition’s Food-Grown™ vitamins and minerals ensure that nutrients get to the places where they are needed. Imagine the most perfect and complete address on a letter, passing through the post office sorting office and beings swiftly delivered by the postman to the correct house. It’s like nutrition satellite navigation at its best! 3) Lasting Action: Because your body recognizes them as food, Food–Grown™ nutrients are retained in the body for much longer. 4) Less Requirement for Nutrient 'Mega-Dosing': Because food state and wholefood nutrients have superior bio-availability, this means that less is definitely more. But with synthetic nutrients, the doses are often higher to accommodate for the loss of strength as it passes through the digestive system. The British Pharmacopoeia (used worldwide as the main reference book) states that only up to 10-11% of the elemental value of a mineral salt is utilized by the body. An example of this would be Calcium gluconate which is calcium consisting of 8% - 9.3% calcium (elemental) combined with gluconic acid. This is not a form of calcium you would find in food. Therefore if you take 500mg calcium (gluconate) this would mean that 500mg calcium gluconate provides 46.50mg (9.3%) of elemental calcium, at best. If the utilisation rate is 11%, this leaves you with a calcium value to be utilized of 5.11mg. Why Wild Nutrition? Wild Nutrition’s products are formulated by Co-founder and experienced Nutritional Therapist Henrietta Norton. Henrietta has combined her 13 years in clinical practice and 9 years of product formulation to develop this leading range of Food-Grown nutrients that support and reflect a deep respect for the body’s own healing ability. Wild Nutrition’s Food-Grown™ nutrients produced slowly using a low heat and therefore classified as raw. All products are free from GM ingredients, toxic metals, pesticides and herbicides. Wild Nutrition do not use alcohols or solvents at any stage (just filtered water), nor fillers or binders in any products. All you are consuming are the nutrients and botanicals themselves - Just as Nature Intended.

“Human physiology will always be able to distinguish between Vitamin C in synthetic form and that from an orange” Dr Albert Szent Gyorgy MD, PhD, Nobel laureate

Discover the benefits for yourself - click here to browse the full range of Wild Nutrition Food State Vitamins and Minerals!

item.title: Leptin - The reason you're not losing weight?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
For years, we considered ‘calories in vs calories out’ to be the holy grail of weight loss. If someone was overweight, they were clearly eating more calories than their body required and were therefore storing them as fat. To combat this, the same solution was always provided; eat less, move more, and the weight will drop off before you know it. But we now know that weight loss isn't just a numbers game. The fact is, there are numerous factors that influence whether we lose (or gain) weight - one of the most significant being a hormone called leptin. Leptin is a hormone that many people don’t even know exists, but understanding it may help us unlock the secret to healthy, sustainable weight loss. What is Leptin? Leptin is a satiety hormone that regulates our appetite and our metabolism. Secreted by adipose (fat) tissue, it communicates directly with the hypothalamus in our brain and certain cells in our stomach to tell us when we are hungry and when we are satiated. In the early years of human existence, leptin was quite literally a life-saver. When we lived through times of feast and famine, leptin would rise and fall accordingly to maintain survival:
  • When food was abundant and our body fat at a healthy level, leptin would ensure our metabolic rate increased - therefore increasing the rate at which we burn fat. After all, food is plentiful and we have enough fat cells to survive, so there is no need to store the calories we are consuming as more fat.
  • When food was scarce, our leptin levels would fall as a survival mechanism, in turn slowing our metabolism to prioritise fat storage at all costs. After all, who knows how long we need to survive before our next meal? At the same time, leptin is in constant communication with the brain telling us to search for food, resulting in an increase in appetite to encourage us to find calories - and fast. 
Of course, in modern times, very rarely do we experience a true ‘feast or famine.’ Yet, our bodies still produce leptin in exactly the same way that they did when it truly assisted our survival. In healthy people, leptin is responsible for letting us know when we have eaten enough and when we have eaten too little. Healthy leptin levels are what help the majority of people who maintain a consistent weight to do so with relative ease. So how is leptin causing weight gain in so many people? The answer lies in what is proving to be an epidemic of modern times; leptin resistance. What is leptin resistance? ‘Leptin resistance’ occurs when the leptin produced by our fat cells in our body cannot successfully communicate with our brain. Although leptin is still being produced by the fat cells, our bodies have become less sensitive (or resistant) to the hormone, and therefore do not adjust metabolism and appetite accordingly. The resulting physiological response is an increased appetite and a decreased metabolism; in other words, we actually become hard-wired to store fat. But why does leptin resistance occur in the first place? As leptin is a hormone, there are many factors that could be at work: Crash dieting: One of the main reasons for leptin resistance is the modern ‘crash dieting’ mantra when it comes to weight loss. By embarking on a rollercoaster of excessively restrictive calorie consumption and long sessions of exercise, our leptin response becomes damaged and therefore stops working as it should do.  Ten thousand years ago, we certainly wouldn’t have gone on a ten mile run when food was scarce. Yet, in our efforts to lose weight, this is exactly what we are recommended to do. It’s all about eating less and moving more, remember? Fructose Consumption: Another factor that can contribute to leptin resistance is fructose consumption, especially in isolated forms like high fructose corn syrup. Excessive fructose has been shown to mute leptin responses in the hypothalamus1, whilst also elevating blood triglycerides and blocking the passage of leptin to the brain2. Lifestyle factors: There are also many modern lifestyle factors that could be contributing to leptin resistant. Excessive consumption of grains and soy has been strongly linked with leptin resistance, as the phytic acid they contain has been shown to bind with the leptin receptor3. A lack of sleep4 and stress5 have also been shown to interfere with leptin production. How to fix leptin resistance If you suspect that leptin may be the secret reason you are not losing weight, then there are steps that you can take to improve your leptin response. These are:
  • Consume high quality sources of protein and fat to regulate your appetite and produce satiety hormones. Avoid refined sugars, simple starches, and especially fructose. Limit your fruit consumption to 1 – 2 pieces per week in the initial period of healing.
  • Take measures to manage your stress levels; meditate, get outside in the sunshine, and do yoga.
  • Get plenty of sleep (8-9 hours each night) and try to maintain a strict circadian rhythm (I.E going to bed at 10pm and waking at 6.30am every day)
  • Avoid cardio, as this puts stress on your hormones. Limit your exercise to 2 – 3 weights or sprint sessions per week. As your system heals you can gradually start to re-introduce more exercise, if desired.
  • Avoid snacking; try to space your meals at least 4 hours apart and eat 2 / 3 larger meals each day rather than many smaller ones. This will reduce the stress on your liver, digestive system and hormones.
As you begin to heal and your leptin response improves, you should notice your appetite begin to stabilise to a more normal level. How long this will take depends on how severely leptin resistant you are, so be patient; it may take months to undo years of metabolic damage. Remember, the key to long term weight loss is patience and consistency; attempting to accelerate results through dramatically low calorie diets and excessive exercise is a sure fire way to damage your hormones and make maintaining your weight more of a struggle than ever before. Are you struggling to lose weight? Are you sick of crash diets that do more harm than good? Download your FREE EBook today, and discover a simple, sustainable approach to healthy weight loss. Sources 1) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18703413 2) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15111494 3) http://www.biomedcentral.com/1472-6823/5/10 4) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC535701/ 5) http://molpharm.aspetjournals.org/content/74/6/1610.full

item.title: Q & A with Dean Howell - Vegan Athlete and Founder of Revolution Foods
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded:
One of the best things about working in the health and fitness industry is being able to surround yourself by inspiring, like-minded people every day. There are some truly awesome guys and girls behind the brands we support at Vivo Life - none more so than Dean Howell, founder of the UK based nutritional pioneers Revolution Foods. Dean is a vegan athlete, ex professional footballer and philanthropist; a laid back, easy going character with a burning passion for health and wellbeing. Since turning towards a plant based diet, Dean has seen both his health and performance skyrocket - epitomised in his recent journey from John O'Groats to Lands End by bike! We recently caught up with Dean to discuss diet, training, intermittent fasting, supplements and more. Check out the Q and A below! Q) How long have you been vegan, and what changes has it made to your health and performance? A) 9 - 10 years ago I turned vegetarian, and shortly after, vegan. I have to state that there are many lifestyle factors, and not just my diet, that contribute to my athletic performance. Consuming a plant-based diet gave me the mental clarity to implement the lifestyle changes that give me optimum health. A plant-based diet has to be implemented correctly. My diet is very low inflammatory. This is partly down to no consumption of meat or dairy but also consuming a gluten free diet. Grains are a staple of many vegan/vegetarian diets and are highly inflammatory. My diet is high plant fats, moderate protein and carbohydrates. My carbohydrates only come from plant sources to ensure my blood glucose and endocrine systems are always balanced. Many vegan/vegetarian diets are predominantly high starch/carbohydrate based and as a result detrimental to long-term health. I make sure all of my food is organic and ensure my water is distilled and recharged using a vortex jug and sometimes I'll put it through an alkaline filter jug. This may sound a bit much to some people, but in my opinion, the human body cannot process the amount of toxins we are now exposed to. I also avoid alcohol - this stuff really throws the body out of balance physically & mentally. To go back to the original question, my vegan plantbased diet gives me the vitamins, minerals, micro-nutrients that govern the function of so many biological processes. This is what allows me to feel healthy, strong and energetic every day. Q) What sports and training do you do? A) I was a professional footballer for 18yrs. I continue to train hard, my current hobby is endurance road cycling. I have just completed a charity ride from lands end to john o groats for world peace and promoting a plant based diet. I do regular strength and conditioning work. Press ups & core work while I'm in cycling training. I use the watt bike a lot for fasted high intensity training and for recovery sessions. Q) What does an average day's food intake look like to you? A) As I have mentioned, my diet is high in essential fats (efas). I also intermittently fast on a 16/8 basis. Without going into mass details, I only try to eat within an 8hr window of the day and fast for around 14-16hrs during which time I can consume fluids like herbal teas, and saturated fats such as coconut oil. I train fasted 2-3 times a week in the mornings and will only consume either herbal tea, or if going on a long bike ride I'll blend a bullet proof coffee in the nutri bullet with chaga mushroom, reishi, coconut oil and raw cacao powder, sweetened with a little stevia. I drink loads of liquid throughout the day - herbal teas, smoothies and juices. My evening meals will consist mainly of complex carbohydrates to aid glycogen recovery when doing the amount of exercise that I do. Sweet potato, quinoa, vegetable chillies and curries are my favourite. My food is pretty consistent over seven days. Of course if I have been out on a long ride there will be a calorie deficit and I will consume more food. Q) What is your go to post workout recovery meal? A) I always use smoothies post work out. Much mainstream hype surrounds protein, and whilst it is a huge part of recovery, I feel antioxidants are ignored. Exercise is a stress on the body with Co2 by products created that cause oxidation. Oxidation creates free radical damage and high anti oxidant foods are needed to mop up the damage to maintain long-term health. I put various ingredients in my smoothies that provide both antioxidants and protein - Revolution Foods Raw Protein Powder, Super Greens, Super Fruits, Pacifica, Chia Seeds, Hemp Seeds, Maca, Baobab, Acai. Q) What advice would you give a vegan athlete looking to push their performance? A) To put health first and performance will follow, people who strive for quick results with sythetic man made products are compromising their long term health. For me performance enhancing is having a strong immune system to be able to stay consistent with training. Consistency in anything brings results.
  • Avoid gluten
  • Consume carbs from plant sources (starchy vegetables and fruit)
  • Avoid soya
  • Plenty of phytonutrients is critical
  • Eat organic wherever possible
  • Eat plenty of plant fats for energy and performance
  • Train with weights to produce natural growth hormone
  • Mix endurance with HIIT training to keep the body guessing
  • Eat high antioxidant foods
  • Stay hydrated.
Whether you are vegan or otherwise, the Revolution Foods range of health supplements are designed to take your diet and training to the next level. Click here to view the full range!

item.title: Top three supplements that (almost) everyone should take
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: Before I begin this article, we need to get one thing straight. Without a shadow of a doubt, you cannot out supplement a bad diet. Profit hungry pharmaceutical manufacturers will have you believe you can, but the reality just doesn’t work that way. Healthy, nourishing food should always be prioritised. Regular exercise, sound sleep, and time spent outdoors are equally important in the quest for good health. Once these have been optimised, we can start taking a look at supplements. Naturally, the supplements that are right for one person are not necessarily right for the next. We are all very different; with different health goals, different body compositions, and different metabolic programming. Age, gender, activity levels, hormonal balance, and even the time of year can determine which supplements you should be taking. Depending on your current lifestyle, you may not even need any at all. It’s unlikely, but it’s certainly possible. For the vast majority of the population, however, there are three supplements I recommend over and above any other. All three are essential components of a healthy diet; but sadly, all three are lacking in almost all of us. What are they? Let’s take a look.. #1 - Probiotics A healthy digestive system is the foundation to a healthy body. The discovery of the role of the gut in virtually every other aspect of our health has been one of the most exciting developments in nutritional research in the past few years. It has been shown to influence almost every physiological and psychological process in the body, contributing directly to our mood, brain function, immunity, energy levels, metabolism, hormonal balance, and virtually everything in between. Inside our gut, we harbour a highly diverse ecosystem that features trillions of bacteria (known as probiotics) which are crucial to our digestive wellbeing. Traditional cultures consumed probiotics on a daily basis; both from the soil, and in fermented foods such as sauerkraut, kimchi, kefir and kombucha. These foods helped to repopulate our guts with healthy bacteria, but are notable absentees from the modern diet. Add to the equation the widespread use of antibacterial soaps and sanitizers, antibiotics for little more than the common cold, chronic stress and processed food (all of which have been shown to adversely impact our gut bacteria), and it comes as no surprise that so many of us struggle with poor digestive health. Recent research has shown an imbalanced gut bacteria to contribute to far more than we ever imagined. Neurological disorders such as ADHD, autism, depression, Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s have all been linked to our gut bacteria, as have countless other health complaints including chronic fatigue, lack of focus, sugar cravings, weight gain, hormonal imbalances, skin complaints, and poor immune function. Even if you don’t suffer from digestive issues, taking a probiotic is quite possibly one of the best things you can do for your overall health. What to look for in a probiotic: Numerous strains of bacteria to ensure greater diversity in the digestive system. When are they most important? In times of stress, when travelling, during and after antibiotic use, and when suffering from digestive complaints. If you are frequently ill, or suffer from allergies, probiotics have been proven to be highly beneficial. How do I use them? Take your probiotic first thing in the morning, ideally on an empty stomach. Fermented foods can be enjoyed as part of your meal, at any time of day. Who doesn’t need a probiotic? If you consume fermented foods on a daily basis, you may not need to take a probiotic supplement. Kombucha is a great starting point, as it’s tasty and good value too. Sauerkraut is also a very good choice – just make sure you look for a raw variety, as pasteurisation kills all the beneficial microbes. Click here to browse our full range of probiotics! #2 - Omega 3 Omega 3 is an ‘Essential Fatty Acid,’ meaning that it cannot be produced by the body and must therefore be consumed through diet. Extensive research has shown the positive impact that Omega 3 fatty acids have on the health of our joints, brain and circulatory system, along with our bone, skin and eye health. Omega 3 reduces cellular inflammation, boosts our cognitive function, improves our circulation, and increases our immune response. It’s called ‘essential’ for a reason, playing a crucial role in so many different processes within the body. By far the best source of dietary omega 3 comes from oily fish, such as salmon, sardines, mackerel and trout – which the vast majority of us don’t eat enough of to meet our required daily intake. Omega 3 can also be found in seeds such as flax and chia, but this comes in the form of ALA, rather than the DHA and EPA that is found in oily fish. Our bodies have to convert ALA to DHA and EPA, and the conversion rate is estimated to be 1 in 100. So you would need to eat 100 grams of ALA just to get the benefits of 1 gram of EPA and DHA – that’s over half a kilo of flaxseed each day! An interesting fact about omega 3 is that it competes for the same conversion enzymes as omega 6. Omega 6 is also an essential fatty acid, but it’s one that is much easier to source and is abundant in the modern western diet. The ideal ratio of O3 to O6 is between 1:1 and 1:4, which is thought to keep the body in an anti-inflammatory state and is the approximate ratio that the human race evolved eating. Worryingly, it is not uncommon to consume a ratio upwards of 1:20 when eating the standard western diet. Omega 3 is anti-inflammatory, whilst Omega 6 is pro-inflammatory. When balanced, they keep the body in perfect harmony. But too much of one and not enough of the other is seriously bad news for our health. By far the best way to improve your Omega 3 : Omega 6 ratio is to cut out the biggest source of omega 6 in the modern diet – vegetable oil. This helps to bring your omega 6 intake down to a much more reasonable level, with the majority of your O6 intake now coming from whole foods such as nuts, seeds, and egg yolks. The next step is to increase your daily omega 3 consumption – either through diet, or supplementation. What to look for in an omega 3 supplement: Quality and purity are everything here. Far too many omega 3 supplements are made using fish from polluted waters, and are often processed using heat which can damage the delicate fatty acids. Look for sustainable, cold water fish oil processed at low temperatures. Who needs them most? Anyone who doesn’t consume oily fish at least 3 – 4 times per week. They are also especially beneficial for athletes, helping to accelerate recovery and improve cardiovascular health. For vegans, an omega 3 supplement derived from algae is by far the best choice. For many people, 2g – 3g per day of Omega 3 is plenty. That’s the equivalent of approximately 75g – 125g of wild salmon. It’s certainly not hard to consume enough omega 3 through your diet, but on the days where you don’t eat oily fish, taking a supplement is a wise choice. Click here to browse our full range of Omega 3 supplements! #3 - Magnesium Magnesium deficiency is the second most common deficiency in developed countries around the world, surpassed only in the Northern Hemisphere by lack of vitamin D. Less than 25% of adults in the UK now consume their Recommended Daily Allowance of magnesium (RDA) – that is, the minimum requirement as advised by the Food Standards Association. In many people, particularly those that are active, magnesium needs may be even greater. No matter how healthy your diet, there is still a good chance that you could be at risk of magnesium deficiency without supplementation. This is because the magnesium levels in our soils have been depleted severely in recent years; in some regions, by as much as 80% since 1950. The food we eat is only as healthy as the soil in which it is grown – and thanks to heavy pesticide use and intensive farming methods, much of our soil contains nowhere near as much magnesium as it did in years gone by. As for the health benefits? Magnesium helps maintain muscle, nerve and heart function, balances hormones, boosts immunity and helps in the conversion of food to energy. It improves sleep quality and stress response, and increases the absorption of other minerals, most notably calcium and phosphorus. Magnesium is undoubtedly an essential nutrient, and one that many of us are seriously lacking. What to look for in a magnesium supplement? Look for a highly absorbable form such as taurinate, gluconate, or citrate. If you prefer not to take dietary magnesium, you can try using transdermal magnesium, which is absorbed through the skin – either as a spray, or in a mineral bath. Who needs it most? Athletes, and those suffering from stress, fatigue, insomnia, or decreased immunity. If you eat a diet high in calcium, a magnesium supplement is also highly advisable, as these two work in a harmony similar to omega 3 and omega 6. Too much calcium and not enough magnesium can lead to abnormal levels of cellular calcium. How to take it? Magnesium supplements are best taken in the evening, without food, approximately 30 minutes before bed. Taking magnesium in the evening has been shown to be especially beneficial for improving sleep quality and duration. Browse our full range of magnesium supplements here! Thanks for reading this article! If you liked it and know someone that it can help, please share it with a friend :) [icegram messages="7123"]

item.title: Get fit and get rewarded with Earthmiles!
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: Vivo Life have recently teamed up with the fantastic team at Earthmiles, the exciting new fitness app that rewards you for staying fit and healthy! Here's a little more information on one of the hottest health and fitness trends in the UK right now... What is Earthmiles? Earthmiles was founded just a few months ago by ex-bankers Megha Prakash and Som Gosh in London. The app came out of an “aha” moment for the founders. “It made so much sense,” Megha said, “we didn’t know how we could go back to our day jobs and not see this turn to reality.” Megha suffered from degenerative disc disease from the young age of 22. The entire experience of losing and slowly regaining her spinal health really made her think deeply about wellness. She dedicated an entire summer after her diagnosis rediscovering her strength, doing yoga, acupressure, swimming, and physiotherapy. That wonderful experience of getting better and stronger stayed with her and after six years of a desk job she decided to spend her time building something closer to her passion for health. “I knew that not only did I want to work on some positive ideas but I wanted do so in a way that would help others avoid ending up in a similarly unhealthy situation if they could help it”. And that’s how Earthmiles came to be. Earthmiles, the name, came to the team all of a sudden. Air miles – but for moving on the ground – of course! They love that users have told them that the name to them connotes the overall human community and the idea that health is everyone’s business. Without being positioned as an app that only athletes can benefit from, Earthmiles currently rewards walking, running, cycling and yoga but they aim to expand the suite of activities soon. How does the app work? Almost a quarter of the people in the UK are already tracking some form of fitness activity with a tracker or app, and this trend continues to grow. Earthmiles app syncs with these trackers to automatically award you points as you exercise. With these earthmiles you can redeem rewards which could be a free class or a discount you would not otherwise get. For example, you can grab yourself a free bag of kale chips or peanut butter at Vivo Life as you earn your Earthmiles! The biggest appeal of the app is the fact that not only it makes being active fun, but it also serves as a platform to discover healthy, nutritious food brands as well as wellness brands, fitness classes and gear. Megha explains the idea behind the rewards platform: “We only have health and fitness-related rewards, so that we help change the mindset that makes people pick up a doughnut after their workout—and instead help them discover something else that’s good for them!” The founding team believe ‘healthy’ is all about knowing your own body. “We have both tried different things and ultimately gone back to the basics – workout regularly, eat well, get the rest that my body needs. I am a big believer in authenticity – in sticking with basic natural principles and not doing anything too gimmicky or faddy while learning more and more about this miraculous human body. In my time working on Earthmiles I have met some amazing people in this industry and explored new ideologies and beliefs about what is good for our health. Right now I’m also trying to become a vegan and it’s great to see London is really becoming an increasingly supportive city for such lifestyle choices.” Speaking of London, what do the founders of Earthmiles think about the health and fitness scene in London? “I genuinely think London is an amazing place to be healthy & well. When I first moved here 5 years ago I was blown away by how many people were always jogging on the pavements, come rain or shine. Over the years I have gained a really huge respect for the culture that supports people in taking care of their physical and mental health. Even so, over two thirds of Britons are said to be overweight or obese, and Diabetes and other such illnesses are on the rise. World Cancer Research Fund says that over a third of cancers are preventable through lifestyle changes, so there is definitely a knowledge gap. That’s where Earthmiles came in.” So what is next for Earthmiles? At Earthmiles Megha, Som and their team believe in creating a real community for people who want to live active and healthy: “Whenever a user has told us they are paying more attention to how much they move, that they are walking now instead of taking the bus, that they love discovering healthy products and rewarding themselves with something that’s good for them – it genuinely makes our day!” In the future, they want to grow the Earthmiles family even bigger, and partner with more brands that they would love and make them walk the extra mile! Earthmiles is available as an app for iPhone, iPad and Android. Download it for yourself today and get moving!

item.title: 8 Simple Steps to Sleep Like a Baby
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: There is nothing more important for your health than your sleep. It directly affects every single process in your body; including brain function, immune system regulation, hormonal balance, muscle repair, metabolism and energy levels. But in today’s fast paced modern world, many of us do not get enough. Staying fit and healthy has never been more popular. But whilst many of us are super strict with our diet and exercise, why is sleep still looked at as a necessity rather than a priority? Sure, you might get by on 6 hours of sleep a night. But if you want to be truly healthy, you’re going to need a lot more. 8 is the magic number – and in some people, it’s even higher. If you’re struggling to lose weight or build muscle, the chances are your sleep has something to do with it. If your hormones are out of whack, you’re irritable, or you can’t concentrate at work, the first place to look is between the sheets. So how do you go about improving your sleep quality? Check out my 8 simple steps to sleep like a baby right here. #1 - Get into a routine Our sleep is determined by our circadian rhythm – that is, our internal body clock that tells us when we should be awake and when we should sleep. Our circadian rhythm governs the production of melatonin, the primary sleep hormone; but when our sleep patterns become erratic, our melatonin production is disrupted. By going to bed at roughly the same time each night, we naturally produce melatonin at the correct times to promote deep, restorative sleep. Going to bed at the same time should also mean you naturally begin to wake at the same time – eliminating that jolt of panic induced by the alarm clock every morning. #2 - Dim the lights Our circadian rhythm is influenced by numerous external factors, with one of the most impactful being the presence of light. Bright light tells our body it is day time, whilst low level lighting helps our body transition into ‘night mode.’ For thousands of years, this system worked pretty well – until, of course, the invention of lightbulbs and computer screens. Nowadays, many of us are in a constant state of overstimulation created by unrelenting brightness around the home; and yet we wonder why we struggle to switch our brains off when we lie in bed at night. To combat this, dim the lighting a couple of hours before bed to allow your body to naturally wind down. Energy saving bulbs, dimmer switches and candles are great ways to transition your body into night mode. Turn off your laptop and smartphone (see step 3), and when it comes to bedtime, use blackout blinds or an eye mask to shut out any potential light disruption. Conversely, we should aim to take in plenty of bright light during the day time to trigger melatonin production at night – so aim to get outside in full sunlight for at least 15 minutes per day. #3 - Log off and power down The blue light emitted by electrical devices interferes with melatonin production by overstimulating the optic nerve, which passes on a message to the brain that it is still day time. Computers, laptops, tablets and smartphones are the main culprits – but television can also have similar effects. In the first clinical trial of it’s kind, researchers compared the sleep patterns of two groups of subjects; one who read books before bed, and another who read the same content but on a computer screen. Researchers found that the group using the computer screens before bed took longer to fall asleep and experienced disrupted REM sleep patterns throughout the night. Try and shut down your laptop as early as possible – ideally at least two hours before bed. Put your phone away shortly after, or at the very least, turn the brightness down. Try to turn off the TV in the last hour before bed in favour of some light reading, chat, or a board game. If you have to watch TV, choose something non-stimulating – the latest Hollywood action blockbuster may not be the wisest choice. #4 - Eat carbs at night It may go against conventional wisdom, but saving up the majority of your carbs for your evening meal has been shown to improve sleep quality by increasing baseline melatonin and the plasma concentration of tryptophan, an amino acid that helps promote healthy sleep and relaxation. In a clinical trial, subjects who ate a higher carb meal at dinner fell asleep faster and experienced deeper sleep patterns than subjects who ate a low carb meal at dinner. Besides, who doesn't love chowing down on carbs in the evening!? #5 - Exercise, but at the right time In a study by the International Sleep Foundation, researchers found that just 150 minutes of exercise each week saw an average 65% improvement in sleep quality amongst patients. There are numerous theories put forward on why this is the case; increased stimulation to the brain during the day time, increased oxygenation of the blood, or simply increasing energy expenditure and thus increasing our demands for sleep. Whatever the reason, the most important thing is that it works – so if you need any more incentive to exercise, this is it. However, timing your exercise is important. Exercise stimulates the central nervous system and increases cortisol production, both of which wire your brain to stay awake. Exercise earlier to avoid sleep issues; ideally in the morning, or early afternoon. #6 - Eat earlier Eating too soon before bed can make sleeping uncomfortable. Furthermore, deep REM sleep is harder to achieve when you eat before bed, as the body is still expending energy trying to digest the food you just ate. I personally need to leave at least 2.5 – 3 hours before my last meal and going to bed; but experiment, and see what works best for you. #7 - Lower your body temperature We need a cool environment to sleep well, so open the windows and allow a steady stream of fresh air to come in throughout the night. In summer, you may also wish to take a cold shower or ice bath an hour before bed to lower your core body temperature and prepare for sleep. #8 - Supplement Wisely Finally, the right supplements can make a huge impact on your sleep quality. Here are a few of my recommendations: Magnesium: Magnesium is a natural muscle relaxant and stress reliever, so can be extremely beneficial in helping you fall asleep – particularly if you have an existing magnesium deficiency. Taking between 250mg and 500mg of magnesium before bed has been shown to improve both sleep quality and duration. Tryptophan: As we touched on earlier, the amino acid tryptophan promotes healthy sleep and relaxation. Like magnesium, tryptophan has also been studied for it’s abilities to promote healthy sleep, demonstrating very promising results.  Take a small amount of supplemental tryptophan half an hour before bed, and see if it makes a difference for you. Chamomile Tea: The herb chamomile has been used for thousands of years as a natural aid to deep sleep. I love a mug of Pukka’s Three Chamomile tea in the evening. Ashwagandha: The ayurvedic herb Ashwagandha helps to relieve stress and anxiety. In India, Ashwagandha is often prescribed to men and women with high pressure jobs. Ashwagandha is not directly used as a sleep aid, rather a mind-relaxer; perfect for those who find it hard to switch off their thoughts at night. A good night’s sleep is perhaps the most important thing we can do for our health – so let’s start treating it with the priority it deserves. [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: 7 healthy recipes we're loving right now (September 2015)
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: It feels like change is in the air, doesn't it? The air is crisper, the mornings are darker, and suddenly everything feels very Autumnal. Right now all we can think about is roaring log fires, crunching leaves, roasted root vegetables, chai tea, English apples, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger. And pumpkin pie. Lots and lots of pumpkin pie. And what better way to welcome in the new season than to get the ball rolling on our new monthly feature - 7 healthy recipes we're loving right now. Our customers often ask us where they can find good sources of recipe inspiration - now, once a month, we're going to list our favourites all in one place! We're kicking off our first edition with plenty of Autumn-inspired culinary creations from some of our favourite food bloggers around. Just click on the pictures to get the recipe! #1 - Pumpkin Chilli (GF, DF, Vegan) - The Iron You Nothing says Autumn quite like pumpkin, does it? You might have to wait a few more weeks until they come into season, but if you're feeling impatient, butternut squash will do just as good a job. We added a dash of coconut aminos to ours for added umami! #2 - Sugar Free Chocolate Pecan Pie (GF, DF, Paleo) - Healthful Pursuit You knew it was coming, didn't you? These mouthwatering mini chocolate pecan pies are made using almond flour, pecans, coconut oil, stevia, and a secret ingredient that may well surprise you! #3 - Raw Chocolate Chip Mocha Cookie Dough Protein Bars (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) - Greens Of The Stone Age Made with Sunwarrior protein powder, these home made protein bars are the perfect post workout snack. Make a big batch - they'll disappear faster than you think! #4 - Carrot, Apple and Ginger Juice (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) - Naturally Meghan If you have access to a good juicer, this fiery carrot, apple and ginger juice is the perfect way to transition into Autumn. Made with just three simple ingredients and ready in minutes, you can't go wrong! [icegram messages="7123"] #5 - Cumin Spiced Root Wedges (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) - Primal Eye Sweet potato, parsnip and celeriac, roasted in coconut oil and tossed in cumin seeds. Simple, but so delicious! #6 - Carrot and Cardamom Soup (GF, DF, Paleo) - Ruhlman Does anyone else crave a big bowl of soup in the Autumn? This Carrot and Coriander Soup by Michelle Tam is just the ticket for those cooler evenings. #7 - Raw Chocolate Orange Brownies (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) - Deliciously Ella Deliciously Ella is famous for her brownies - if you've never tried the ones made with sweet potato, where have you been hiding!? In our humble opinion, these ones are the best yet. No cooking required! What recipes have caught your eye this month? [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: 6 muscle building tips for the classic 'hardgainer'
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
Imagine you went out on to the street today and found 10 skinny guys of around the same age who had never set foot in a gym before. You write each of them the same training programme, the same nutrition plan, and tell them all to come back in 6 months to show you the results. When you reunite, two of the guys are strikingly bigger and more defined than the rest. Three more have made visible progress. The remaining five stand before you in more or less the same condition as before – narrow shoulders, very little muscle tone, and tee shirt sleeves that hang from their arms. This is the perfect example of the tremendous role our genetics play in the process of building muscle. No matter how level a playing field we create with our training and nutrition, some guys will always progress faster than you will. It’s not fair, but it’s basic metabolic science. For every genetically gifted dude in the gym who only needs to look at a barbell to gain five pounds of muscle mass, there are another ten who train hard day in, day out, and never seem to get anywhere. These guys are often referred to as “hardgainers.” But just because your genetics make it harder for you to build muscle, doesn’t make it impossible. Quite the opposite, in fact. With a few adaptations to your training, nutrition and lifestyle, you might never consider yourself a ‘hardgainer’ again. But one step at a time. The key here is learning how to optimise your genetic potential to get the best results from your training. If you consider yourself a hardgainer, here are 6 tips to help you make the progress you’ve been waiting for. #1 - Train with variety Far too often, hardgainers are told to focus on the ‘big lifts’ and little else. And don’t get me wrong; heavy squats, deadlifts and presses are important testosterone-boosting movements. But they also need to be balanced with appropriate ‘isolation’ exercises in order to fully stimulate muscle growth. If you’re training legs, for example, complement your barbell back squat and deadlift with some split squats and glute-ham raises. If you’re training back and biceps, throw in some pull ups and curls to go along with your upright rows. Muscles won’t grow unless they are stimulated sufficiently – so mix up your training programme to keep them guessing week after week. Isolation exercises are also much less stressful on your central nervous system than the big barbell lifts, allowing you to train more frequently without frazzling your adrenal glands. Going too heavy in your workouts will overload your body with cortisol, the stress hormone that actually inhibits muscle growth and promotes fat storage. Far from ideal. #2 - Consistency, Consistency, Consistency Whilst the genetically gifted guy on the bench next to you may well make progress on just a couple of sessions each week, as a hardgainer, you will not. If you want the results, you’re going to have to put the work in. If you’re not prepared to do so, I strongly suggest you find a new hobby. As with everything else in life, the key to getting stronger is consistency. If you wanted to get better at reading, you sure as hell wouldn’t only practice three times per week. If you wanted to learn to play the guitar, you best believe you’d be practicing every day. So why should muscle growth be any different? Think how a football player has big calves, a mechanic has big forearms, or a gymnast has a set of washboard abs that most of us could only ever dream of. They achieve this through consistency – stimulating their muscles on a regular basis, which forces them to adapt and grow. As a hardgainer, you’re going to want to train each muscle group at least twice per week. This could be in the form of a twice weekly upper / lower split, or dividing your sessions into push, pull, lower, and full body workouts. At the very least, you’re going to want to train four times each week. Minimum. If you’re anything like me, this will come as good news. I hate rest days. I’d go mad if I could only train three times per week. So let’s keep it simple – put the time in, and see the results. #3 - Sleep like a baby Nothing is more important for muscle growth than sleep. During sleep, human growth hormone (HGH) and testosterone are produced, muscles are repaired and cortisol levels plummet. You’ll never recover properly if you don’t sleep properly. Prioritise deep sleep above all else, aiming for a minimum of 8 hours each night. Read this article to discover how to improve your sleep quality. #4 - Prioritise food quality, not quantity This is a big one. Common hardgainer advice tells you to eat everything in sight in order to get as many calories down the hatch as possible. And whilst it’s true that you do need to be in a calorie surplus to build muscle; feasting on pizza, pasta and cake is not the answer. Yes these foods are calorie rich, but they also wreak havoc with your hormones – and the last thing you need as a hardgainer is a messed up hormonal profile. Poor food choices will also increase inflammation in your body, which will slow your recovery and increase your risk of injury. If it takes you longer to recover from your workouts, you won’t be able to train as often as you need to - which will just delay your progress even more. Prioritise high quality sources of protein (organic meats, wild fish), carbohydrates (sweet potatoes, white potatoes) and fats (avocados, whole eggs, nuts, coconut oil) to fuel your body correctly. For a more comprehensive guide of the best sources of these macronutrients, check out this article. Oh, and throw out that tupperware. Eating food out of plastic never did anyone any good.   #5 - Supplement sensibly Don’t buy into the hype pedaled by the profit driven fitness industry. Nobody needs to take 20 different supplements to make gains. If that was really the case, I'd give up now. Seriously. Who has the time or money to take that many supplements each day? Most people should be able to count their supplements on one hand. I would recommend the following to the typical hardgainer: • High quality protein powder: For use before and / or after your workouts. • Probiotic: To enhance digestive wellness and improve your nutrient absorption. • Omega 3: For recovery and performance • Magnesium: For recovery and hormone optimisation You may also wish to consider a high quality BCAA powder if you’re training hard and training frequently. This is by no means essential, but used correctly, can be an excellent tool for stimulating muscle growth.   #6 - Get real Finally, one of the most important things you can do for your training results (and overall body confidence) is to get realistic about your physique goals. We spoke about consistency earlier – and in order to stay consistent, you have to stay motivated. One of the main issues with social media is that it creates an unrealistic platform to aspire to. If you follow any fitness models, bikini queens or bodybuilders on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram, remember:
  • They do not look like this in real life! Bodybuilders and fitness models plan their photoshoots months in advance to allow them to cut obscene amounts of body fat and create a condition that is impossible to maintain year round. They then tense, squeeze, and flex to the best of their ability during the photoshoot, before the photo is then edited and airbrushed to finally create the picture you see on screen. This is not real life, and therefore not something we should aspire to!
  • They get paid to do this! Professional athletes do not have to fit training around their life – training is their life. An athlete’s 9-5 consists of training, nutrition, recovery, and very little else. They dedicate their lives to their sport, so it’s impossible to expect to match their condition when you have a job to hold down and a social life to maintain.
I’m not saying that it’s wrong to compare yourself to athletes at the very top of their game – just don’t expect to be them. Instead, set yourself realistic goals; increasing your deadlift by next month, or having visible abs by the end of the year, for example. With something much more realistic (but not easy) to work towards, you’ll find yourself much more motivated to train hard, eat well, and make progress. If you liked this article please share it with a friend.   [icegram messages="7123"]

item.title: 10 tips for a clear, glowing complexion
item.dc:creator: Amy Saunders
item.content:encoded: This article is a guest post by Amy Saunders, natural skincare expert and founder of the beauty blog Get That Glow. I spent my teen years and early twenties plagued with acne. I hoped as I got older my skin would sort itself out, but my poor lifestyle choices meant it never did. In early 2014 I suffered from an exceptionally bad bout of acne which inspired me to act upon the root causes of my constant breakouts - working on my poor eating habits, negative mindset and stressful energy to achieve the clear skin I’d always dreamed of. Healthy diet, good sleep, plenty of water and a stress free life are some of the most basic ingredients for glowing skin. But what happens when our skin craves a boost? Everyday life can take its toll on our skin in more ways than we think so today I’m sharing 10 simple secrets on how to give your skin a bit of extra glow-factor. #1 - Green Tea Green tea is one of my favourite skin-foods - I try to have 2-3 servings a day and I really notice in my skin when I slack off. Green Tea is really high in antioxidants which help fight bacteria and infections and has higher antioxidant levels than spinach, dark chocolate and blueberries! These antioxidants will do their bit to promote healthier skin but the main acne-busting component in green tea is a polyphenol called EGCG. EGCG can help reduce inflammation, balance out hormones and blood sugar levels which are all major factors when it comes to clearing acne. My favourite way to enjoy green tea is by mixing some Clearspring Japanese Organic Matcha Green Tea Powder with my morning smoothie, or with some nut milk and stevia for a deliciously creamy Matcha latte. If I’m out and about during the day or don’t have the time to make a latte, I always keep a stash of these Pukka Supreme Matcha Green Tea Bags in my purse so I can enjoy green tea no matter what the day has in store for me! Another matcha product I love are these sugar-free Pink Dragonfruit Mints from Sencha Naturals - 3 of these tiny little mints have the same antioxidant power as 1 cup of Green Tea! Enjoy one, three times a day, after every meal to keep your breath fresh and add a sneaky extra serving of green tea to your routine! #2 - Natural Skin Care Mainstream beauty products are filled with toxic pore-clogging ingredients, which can lead to breakouts and skin drying ingredients, such as alcohol, which although dries the skin out temporarily, in the long run it’ll cause your skin to produce excess sebum - therefore more oil and spots! Natural and organic products on the other hand are full of skin-loving plant extracts which can actually help to balance sebum production, reduce inflammation, redness and can improve the overall tone and texture of your skin. Did you know Thyme is considered the best herb for acne? A study by Leeds Metropolitan University showed Thyme tincture actually has a greater antibacterial effect on acne than standard concentrations of benzoyl peroxide – that nasty, chemical ingredient found in most anti-acne creams and washes! That’s right - Thyme has been scientifically proven to be more effective than benzoyl peroxide which is why this Acne Antibacterial Serum from Simplicite could be the answer for those suffering with problematic skin! #3 - Stay Protected This SPF15 Face & Body Moisturiser from Antipodes is ideal for staying protected in the sun, without any of the harsh chemicals, all year round. For gorgeous skin in your 40s and beyond, limit your exposure to strong sunshine and always wear at least SPF15 – even during the winter! A recent study by Australian researchers has shown that a daily application of sun lotion significantly reduces wrinkles and visible signs of ageing so although the skin ageing process can never be stopped completely, daily SPF protection could go a long way to helping it slow it down. #4 - Regular, gentle exfoliation I’m loving this Pink Clay Konjac Sponge as it’s gentle enough to use everyday and leaves my skin feeling soft and smooth! Gentle exfoliation gets rid of dead cells that can leave the skin looking dull. It’s really important to never over-exfoliate skin with harsh exfoliants or chemical peels as this can thin your skin and make it look older over time. Gentle exfoliation stimulates circulation, promotes cell renewal, and refines the skin revealing softer, more radiant skin. As well as helping remove dead skin cells, exfoliation also helps oils, moisturisers, and serums penetrate the skin better – meaning the deeper layers of skin will also get to enjoy all those wonderful skin loving ingredients too. #5 - Feed your gut Long before probiotics became fashionable, in a time when there was no such thing as a fridge-freezer, our ancestors would preserve food by fermentation - these fermented foods would be full of good bacteria that would keep our inner eco-system healthy. However, with the advent of modern food science, we rely heavily on alternative preserving methods such as freezing, pasteurising and canning - meaning that are bodies are no longer receiving a regular supply of beneficial bacteria to keep our digestive system balanced. On top of this, there are other factors that cause even further problems to our gut flora. Birth control pills and antibiotics both disrupt the probiotic population in our gut and destroy all the good bacteria meaning our internal Eco system is out of balance and this lack of good bacteria in our gut means we are more susceptible to skin inflammation. Keep you gut happy by taking a regular dose of high quality probiotics like these Multi-Strain Biotic from Wild Nutrition and make sure you eat lots of prebiotic enriched foods (prebiotics feed the probiotics!) such as onions, garlic and leeks. Also try to incorporate fermented foods into your diet as often as possible. Fermented foods include kefir, kimchi, sauerkraut and kombucha to name a few. Kombucha is a fermented tea beverage which promotes healthy digestion, blood pressure, skin healing, detoxification, increased energy and balanced blood sugar. It’s by far the easiest to consume as it just tastes so good! #6 - Cut the sugar I hate to be that bearer of bad news but if you really want the best skin you can possibly have, you’re going to have to kick the sugar addiction! When you eat something sugary, your blood sugar will spike. When sugars get digested, they can cause the pancreas to produce more insulin and the insulin like growth factor (IGF-1) to help maintain the balance of blood glucose. Too much insulin and IGF-1 will, in turn, trigger a release of androgen hormones, which is one of the leading causes of acne. An excess of androgens means that our skin will produce too much sebum, which will then lead to clogged pores, blackheads and whiteheads which can then lead to further acne inflammation. As an alternative to sugar, I like to sweeten desserts, chocolate and ‘shakes’ with stevia, but be warned - you only need a tiny amount as stevia is reported to be 250 times sweeter than normal sugar but without the sugar-spike! #7 - Omega 3 Omega 3 fatty acids are essential for clear, acne-free skin! Try to eat oily fish such as wild salmon at least 3 or 4 times per week, or try taking an omega 3 supplement. #8 - Vitamin D Acne and other skin disorders can be associated with vitamin D deficiencies. Vitamin D is also known as the sunshine vitamin and plays a key role in healing and preventing acne by cooling inflammation, smoothing the skin, improving mood, boosting your immune system and helping to control insulin response. However, if you’re suffering with persistent acne it’s generally due to something deeper than just a single vitamin deficiency – but taking this vitamin could give your skin that extra boost you’ve been looking for whilst offering other health benefits such as healthy bones and muscle development! I like to supplement every day with Better You Vitamin D3 oral spray – especially during the winter. By using an oral spray you can ensure than you get a guaranteed level of absorption that a tablet or capsule cannot provide. #9 - Topical Antioxidants Vitamin B3, also referred to as “niacinamide,” has been proven in clinical studies to reduce inflammation, increase the elasticity of the skin, enhance the skin barrier function, reduce hyper pigmentation and improve the skin’s tone and texture! In fact, studies have shown that 4% nicotinamide cream, when combines with a carrier oil high in linoleic acid (grapeseed, rosehip, evening primrose, hemp etc), was more effective in reducing acne than 1% topical clindamycin (a commonly used antibiotic for treating acne). In another 12-week study, 4% topical vitamin B3 reduced acne by 60 percent while topical clindamycin only reduced acne by 43 percent. Get a daily dose of topical Vitamin B3 in MyChelle’s Clear Skin Serum. #10 - If all else fails, fake it! You’d be surprised what a little bit of expertly applied ‘glow’ can do to your face. Applying a highlighter onto specific areas of the face can instantly make you look fresher. Simply apply your highlighting pigment onto the inner corners of your eyes, under the arch of your eyebrow, along your cheek bones and down the centre of your nose for an instant face lift! This lavender-tinged, pearlescent illumising powder from Inika works beautifully on most skin tones and can be applied lightly for everyday wear or layered up for a bolder look. References: Topical clindamycin 1% vs. linoleic acid-rich phosphatidylcholine and nicotinamide 4% in the... (2015). [ONLINE] Available at: http://europepmc.org/abstract/MED/21668835. [Accessed 07 September 2015]. Topical nicotinamide compared with clindamycin gel in the treatment of inflammatory acne vulgaris [ONLINE] Available at: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7657446. [Accessed 07 September 2015]. Green Tea Polyphenols Provide Photoprotection, Increase Microcirculation, and Modulate Skin Properties of Women . [ONLINE] Available at: http://jn.nutrition.org/content/141/6/1202.long. [Accessed 07 September 2015]. Epigallocatechin-3-gallate improves acne in humans by modulating intracellular molecular targets and inhibiting P. acnes. - PubMed - NCBI . [ONLINE] Available at: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23096708?dopt=Abstract. [Accessed 07 September 2015].

item.title: Recipe: Matcha Chocolate Truffles (antioxidant bombs)
item.dc:creator: Healthy Jon
item.content:encoded: Food lovers take note - if ever you find yourself in a kitchen with Healthy Jon, stick around until he's made you something to eat. Jon is the master at creating delicious, innovative recipes out of simple, healthy ingredients; and to share his talents with you, we invited him to create a guest recipe for Vivo Life! We gave Jon a few of our favourite ingredients to play with, including two of the most antioxidant rich foods on the planet, matcha green tea and raw cacao. True to form, Jon's creation will blow your mind! Jon's Matcha Chocolate Truffles are everything you want in a chocolate truffle - soft, fudgy, rich and creamy. The matcha powder lends a subtle earthiness which balances the natural sweetness of the dates and really makes these truffles come to life. What better way to get your daily dose of matcha than with these antioxidant bomb chocolate truffles? Recipe: Matcha Chocolate Truffles (Antioxidant Bombs) Ingredients: 10 Medjool Dates 1/3 cup Raw Cacao Powder 50g dark chocolate (70% cacao solids) 1.5tbsp Pip and Nut Peanut Butter 1 tbsp Lucy Bee Coconut Oil 2 tsp Organic Matcha Powder Pinch of Pink Himalayan Salt How to make: 1) In a bowl over hot water, gently melt your chocolate and coconut oil.Add all the remaining ingredients to your food processor. 2) When the chocolate and coconut oil are fully melted, add them to the food processor with the remaining ingredients. Blitz together until the mixture starts to come together and everything is well combined. Remove the bowl from the food processor and place in the fridge for 30 minutes so that the mixture can partially set. 3) Remove the bowl from the fridge and roll into balls. When all the mixture has been used, place all your truffles on a plate and through a sieve sprinkle over a little more matcha powder. I chose to roll mine in matcha, but the taste slightly overwhelmed the lovely chocolate flavour of the truffles. We don’t want that! I recommend a light sprinkle instead. Keep your matcha truffles in the fridge for up to a week - not that they'll last that long! [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Get Bendy: A quick guide to yoga nutrition
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: Article by Hayley McAlinden, Vivo Nutritionist and Yoga Teacher When you first start yoga, you’ll find you pick up the basics pretty quickly. However, if you really want to improve your strength and flexibility, the first place to look is your diet! The food that we eat provides the building blocks for new cells, so if you want those cells to be strong and flexible, choosing the right foods is so important! Flexibility is determined by the length and elasticity of your connective tissues, whilst strength is determined by the amount of lean muscle mass you carry. Choose the right foods to compliment your training, and you’ll improve both! To support your strength and flexibility from the inside out, I recommend the following steps: #1 - Eat Real Food! It may sound simple, but you should always build your diet on real food - whether you are a yogi or not! Take out the hard to digest processed foods such as wheat, sugar, pasteurised dairy and ready meals. If your body feels tight and uncomfortable, this is a sign that your diet needs to shape up! Fill your plate with lots of fresh vegetables of different colours at every meal. Choose organic and seasonal vegetables whenever possible. Complement these with a palm sized portion of protein to help build healthy new cells – hemp, lentils, chick peas, oily fish and chicken are excellent choices. Compliment your meals with healthy spices such as ginger, turmeric, black pepper and cayenne to really nourish your body from the inside out. Most importantly, keep things simple – you’ll feel the difference! #2 - Stay Hydrated! Water is the transporter. More water, more elasticity in muscles and connective tissues. The planet is 70% water and so are we! As well as 2 litres of clean filtered water daily you should also eat your water. Fresh fruits and vegetables contain tons of highly absorbable structured water plus the vitamins, minerals and nutrients needed to nourish ourselves on a cellular level. A pineapple, for example, is 87% water by weight, whilst a cucumber is 96%! #3 - Embrace Fat! Just like a car engine, your body needs to be ‘well oiled’ to function optimally. Getting sufficient omega 3 fats is essential for healthy joints and skin – if you have dry skin or clicky joints, this is a clear sign you need more omega 3! A good saturated fat such as coconut oil is a great one to include especially for cooking as it is stable in high temperatures. Also a quality cold pressed olive oil used cold on salads is a must for internal oiling! [icegram messages="7123"] #4 - Eat your greens! Green foods contain chlorophyll, and chlorophyll helps the body absorb oxygen. Muscles and organs thrive on oxygen as this supports blood flow. More greens equals more oxygen which equals more energy, strength and flexibility! Obviously eating green leafy vegetables daily will help greatly but having concentrated super greens blends in your smoothies can really step up your chlorophyll oxygen boosting levels. #5 - Magnesium 80% of the population is deficient in magnesium. It is one of my must have supplements as it is no longer in our soils due to over farming. It is needed on a cellular level to help the body produce energy through the ATP cycle and help the detoxification pathway. But it is also used for the nervous system and as a muscle relaxant. If you suffer from any tightness, cramping, twitching, spasm, or general tension, anxiety or have high bouts of stress you need to get the vital mineral magnesium in to the rescue! Epsom salt baths are my favourite way to load up on magnesium. #6 - Silica Silica is the most abundant mineral on earth yet the least absorbed by the body. When we are younger we have heaps of this mineral, that’s why we are super bendy and wrinkle free, but as we age our levels rapidly decrease. Silica improves and restores the elasticity in the skin, connective tissue and ligaments. Having a shot of liquid silica daily will greatly improve your flexibility and I strongly believe it contributes to enhancing your natural ‘glow’ as it is one of the main ingredients in collagen formation. #7 - Amino Acids To maintain lean muscle mass you need protein. You also need sufficient amino acids for liver detoxification, and better cleansing equals more energy, strength and flexibility! Not all protein powders are equal, I use a plant based protein powder I trust and MAP amino acids daily. #8 - MSM MSM acts as a powerful antioxidant and healing agent. Stretching puts a great deal of stress on your muscles, joints, tendons and ligaments. MSM is an essential building block for repair and recovery. Again as we age our levels of natural sulphur in the body decrease, so topping up is a must. Another one to start slow on as it is used by the liver for detoxification. Following the above tips will 100% have you addicted to that yoga high in no time, and will also benefit your health & wellbeing long term! Don't forget to visit the Vivo Life Yoga Shop to stock up on all of your yoga essentials! [icegram messages="16075"]
