item.title: 25 ways to feel awesome every day
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: There are thousands of reasons why people choose to be healthy. Maybe you have a sport that you want to compete in, a health concern you want to eradicate, or maybe you just want to look good naked. I’ll be honest – the latter played a big part in the deal for me. Whatever your initial reason for choosing to be healthy, it probably came with a bunch of other unexpected benefits. Sooner rather than later, you come to realise just how good your body is designed to feel. In truth, you never felt bad before – but now you’ve set a new benchmark, why would you want to go back? If you want to discover what being healthy really feels like, follow these 25 tips to boost your energy levels and feel awesome every day! #1 - Wake up without an alarm (or use a smart alarm) Our bodies naturally sleep in cycles of 90 – 120 minutes, during which time we transition from light sleep into deep sleep, and finally into REM sleep, the most restorative sleep stage. When we wake naturally (without the use of an alarm clock), we do so at the end of a sleep cycle. When the alarm clock goes off, however, we often wake up in the middle of an incomplete sleep cycle – sending a jolt of cortisol through our body and leaving us feeling groggy all morning. In an ideal world, we would all be able to wake up naturally when our body dictates; but when we have work to get to, this obviously isn’t practical. If you have to be up by a certain time, I recommend a smart alarm clock that works with your natural sleep cycles, such as the Sleep Cycle App, or a Lumie BodyClock that gently transitions the room from dark to light to mimic a sunrise. #2 - Start the day with warm lemon water After being asleep for 8 hours, the most important thing to do before anything else is to rehydrate. Warm lemon water helps to wake up the digestive system and kick-start your metabolism, helping you to feel healthy and energetic throughout the rest of the day. #3 - Get outside Whether it’s walking the dog or reading the morning paper in the garden, try to get yourself outside and into natural light as soon after waking as you can. The bright light from the sun will help to regulate your circadian rhythm, increase your vitamin D levels and release a cocktail of ‘wake up’ hormones to set you up for the day. #4 - Stretch Stretch and mobilise your muscles and joints to get the blood flowing and increase your core temperature. Start from the bottom upwards – rotate your ankles, stretch out your calves, hamstrings, and mobilise your hips, elbows, shoulders. You’ve been lying in one position all night, so it’s time to get moving! #5 - Take a probiotic Take a probiotic in the morning to help keep your digestive system healthy. A healthy digestive system means greater nutrient absorption from the food you eat, leaving you feeling much more healthy and energetic. If you don't take a probiotic, be sure to eat some fermented foods at some point during the day. #6 - Eat some fruit We know that fruit is one of the healthiest things we can eat, but did you know it is best eaten first thing in the morning on an empty stomach? This is because fruit digests very fast, so when eaten with ‘heavier’ foods it can be hard to break down efficiently. Pineapple is one of my favourite fruits to start the day with, as it encourages the production of bromelain, an enzyme which helps digestion. Start your day with a couple of servings of fruit, either on its own or in a smoothie, and feel awesome. #7 - Exercise Get your exercise in early to release endorphins and leave you feeling great for the rest of the day. Try and make time for some sort of exercise each day; a gym session, some yoga, or even just a leisurely walk. Take your exercise outside to soak up even more vitamin D goodness. #8 - Enjoy a healthy breakfast If breakfast isn’t your favourite meal of the day, you’re not doing it right! I always recommend a breakfast featuring protein and fats to provide sustained energy without any slumps throughout the day. Take your time to enjoy it – don’t try and wolf it down on the train to work! #9 - Drink Green Tea For it’s metabolism-boosting, age-defying, toxin-eliminating properties. Just 1 or 2 cups each day of this stuff really makes you feel awesome. #10 – Move more Whatever your day job may be, try and incorporate as much movement as possible to keep you feeling energised. If you work in an office, try to get away from the screen every hour and go for a walk – or, even better, invest in a standing desk. Studies have proved the human brain to perform better when the body is active, so you’ll be more productive too. #11 – Take lunch outside Never do anything indoors that can be done outdoors. This includes eating; so take your lunch break outside (weather permitting), breathe deeply, and soak up all the sunlight that you can. Humans need sunlight just as much as plants. #12 - Eat a rainbow Different colours on your plate means different nutrients and antioxidants. Lunchtime is the perfect time to pile your plate high with lots of colours in your favourite salad – think carrots, beets, tomatoes, spinach, red onion, avocado, pumpkin seeds, or anything else bright and colourful you can get your hands on. #13 - Pay attention to how you feel after eating We’re all different, so a food that is ‘healthy’ for one person may not be so healthy for you. Pay attention to how your body feels after eating certain foods. If you’re bloated, sluggish, or suffering from headaches after eating a particular food, cut it out for 30 days to allow your system to heal. #14 – Simplify Cut your to do list in half. Throw out the baggage that’s holding you back. Focus on the things that matter. You don’t have to be ‘busy’ all the time. #15 – Drink lots of water Your brain, kidneys, liver, digestive system and skin will all thank you. Drink out of glass and avoid plastic wherever possible. And avoid drinking too much with your food. #16 - Chill out Stress impacts virtually every function in your body, including your digestion, your sleep, and even the rate at which you store fat. If you want to feel awesome each day, take steps to chill out and manage your stress levels. When things get on top of you, take a few deep belly-breaths to reduce cortisol levels and help your body return to a parasympathetic (resting) state. #17 - Learn Maintain an unquenchable thirst for knowledge. Listen to people you meet. Learn new skills. Read. Whatever you do, never stop growing. #18 - Eat more green foods The more green things you can eat, the better. Green foods get their pigment from a compound called chlorophyll, which has powerful antioxidant properties, promotes cellular healing and enhances ATP energy. If you struggle to eat enough greens, I recommend a high quality greens powder for use in your favourite smoothies and juices. #19 - Try new things Whether it’s a new fruit or vegetable, a new workout or a new hobby. Variety is the spice of life. #20 - Eat carbs at dinner Anyone who has been following my articles for a while knows that I’m a huge advocate of carbs at dinner. Eating carbohydrates with your evening meal helps encourage the production of melatonin, the hormone that helps your body transition into ‘night mode’ and prepares you for a healthy sleep. Just make sure you choose the right sources of carbs – starchy vegetables such as sweet potatoes, white potatoes, yams, squash and plantains are my favourites. #21 - Have some chocolate for dessert Do you really need me to tell you that eating chocolate will make you feel awesome!? Chocolate contains a compound called phenylethylamine (PEA), a proven mood enhancer, and also triggers the release of endorphins. Just make sure it’s of a high quality! #22 - Turn off screens in the evening The blue light emitted from computers, tablets and smartphones stimulates the brain into thinking it’s day time – making it hard for you to wind down in the evening. To properly prepare for a good night’s sleep, turn off your screens at least an hour before bed. #23 - Drink a herbal tea A relaxing herbal tea in the evening is the perfect way to help you wind down and chill out. I recommend chamomile tea, which has been used for centuries as a mild aid to sleep. If you don’t get on with chamomile, try a soothing mug of chai. #24 - Take magnesium Magnesium is a natural muscle relaxant and stress reliever, and clinical trials have shown it to improve both sleep quality and duration. I recommend 300mg of natural magnesium 30 minutes before bed. #25 - Aim for 8 hours sleep every night Feeling awesome every day starts between the sheets, so schedule a good night’s rest every night to reach your full potential the next morning. Try to go to bed at roughly the same time each night to keep your circadian rhythm in check – you’ll wake up feeling energised and ready to tackle the day ahead. What makes you feel awesome? If you liked this article please share it :) [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: 7 healthy recipes we're loving right now (October 2015)
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: What's your favourite thing about October? For us, it has to be the food. October is a month of abundance, especially when it comes to our favourite carb source; root vegetables. Pumpkins, carrots, beets, parsnips, Jerusalem artichoke, and squash of all shapes and sizes are now coming into season. These roots are tasty, nutritious, and at their very best right now - making it the perfect time to start adding them into your diet! The abundance of root vegetables is reflected in this month's 7 healthy recipes we're loving right now. We've handpicked some of the best Autumnal offerings from our favourite recipe writers, so if you're stuck for ideas on how to get more roots into your diet, give some of these a try! #1 - Chia Chai Butternut Breakfast Pudding (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) - Hemsley & Hemsley What better way to sneak more vegetables into your day than with this beautifully vibrant butternut squash pudding? It's made with chia seeds, coconut oil, butternut squash and chai spices - perfect as a make-ahead breakfast or a refreshing dessert! #2 - Hazelnut and Ginger Carrot Salad (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) - Empowered Sustenance Zesty, colourful and flavoursome, this Hazelnut and Ginger Carrot Salad makes the perfect side dish to any Autumn lunch. It's brought to life with a dash or two of coconut aminos - seriously, this stuff works with everything! #3 - Kabocha Squash and Lentil Curry (GF, DF, Vegan) - Healthful Pursuit If you've never tried kabocha squash, you're in for a treat! If we had to describe it, we'd say it's somewhere in between a butternut squash and a sweet potato, with a mildly nutty flavour. The dense texture makes it perfect in curries like this one by Leanne of Healthful Pursuit! [icegram messages="7123"] #4 - Stuffed Acorn Squash (GF, DF, Paleo) - Stupid Easy Paleo Yet another way to diversify your squash selection! Simply cut your squash in half, remove the seeds, and add a filling of your choice for a super-satisfying supper. Steph used grass fed beef and spices, but you can swap it for turkey mince, lentils, or just some more veggies! Note: If you're struggling to find anything other than plain old butternut, pay a visit to your local farmers market. #5 - Butternut Squash Gingerbread Cake (GF, DF, Paleo) - Greens of the Stone Age This might just be the best healthy cake recipe we've ever tried. Georgie at Greens of the Stone Age is the queen of 'paleofying' anything you can think of - and she's nailed it once more with this Autumnal butternut squash gingerbread!   #6 - Pumpkin Protein Bites (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) - Hummusapien Packed full of protein and fibre, these no bake protein bites are the perfect way to satisfy your cravings for pumpkin pie. And yes, they do contain real pumpkin! #7 - Raw Pumpkin Pie Macaroons (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) - The Chic Life If you have access to a dehydrator, then these pumpkin pie macaroons make a delicious twist on a classic recipe. Diana uses canned pumpkin, but if you can't find any, just swap for an equal amount of fresh pumpkin that has been cooked and cooled in the fridge! What's cooking in your kitchen this October? [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: How to make your own almond milk
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: Love almond milk, but hate the added ingredients found in the shop bought versions? Why not try making your own... Almond milk is everywhere these days, but finding one that doesn’t contain suspect ingredients is easier said than done. Shop bought almond milks contain a number of additives that are hard for our bodies to handle – added sugar, vegetable oils, carrageenan, colours and flavourings to name but a few. Thankfully though, it’s super easy to make your own almond milk at home! Make up a batch of this recipe, and you’ll never have to use shop bought almond milk again… You will need: 1 cup raw organic almonds Half a teaspoon of Himalayan salt 4 cups filtered water Half a vanilla pod, or 1 drop of vanilla extract 1 tablespoon raw lucuma powder or 1 teaspoon raw honey How to make: 1) Bring some water to the boil in a saucepan. Drop in the almonds for 1 minute, then immediately strain the hot water and rinse the almonds in cold water. The skins of the almonds should become loose. 2) Pop the almonds out of their skin using your fingers. They should come out easily and look like this: 3) Leave the newly blanched almonds to soak overnight in filtered water with half a teaspoon of Himalayan salt. This step is optional but makes for a creamier, smoother almond milk. 4) In the morning, rinse your almonds in cold water, before putting them in the blender with 4 cups of fresh filtered water. Blend for 3 – 4 minutes until smooth and creamy. 5) Strain your mixture into a large bowl using a nut milk bag or cheese cloth. Return the contents to the blender, and add the vanilla and sweetener of your choice. Blend again until smooth. Check sweetness and adjust to your liking. 6) Store in the fridge in a glass jar for up to one week. Use it in your favourite smoothies, with breakfast, or as the perfect partner to a raw hot chocolate! [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Super Purple Beetroot & Acai Breakfast with Banana Cacao Sauce
item.dc:creator: Pamela Higgins
item.content:encoded: One of the most important things you can do for your health is to eat a colourful diet. Different colours are signs of different nutrients, so eating a rainbow of foods every day is a great way to ensure you are getting all the goodness your body needs. Greens, oranges, purples, blues, yellows - the more colours each day the better. As long as they are coming from natural sources, that is! What better way to start than with a colourful breakfast? This fantastic guest recipe from Pamela Higgins uses two of our favourite purple foods - beetroot and acai. Both of these foods get their deep pigment thanks to their rich concentration of powerful antioxidants called anthocyanins, which have been shown to prevent against numerous degenerative diseases and even slow the aging process¹. The Acai Berry is particularly special. Harvested from deep within the Amazon rainforest, this sweet purple fruit is a fantastic source of vitamins A, C, and E, along with calcium and potassium. Acai is thought to have the highest ORAC value (a test of the antioxidant levels) of all other fruits and vegetables on the planet! In other words, if you want to look and feel youthful, vibrant and energetic, it's time to get some Acai in your life. This recipe is a great way to get your fix! Super Purple Beetroot & Acai Breakfast with Banana Cacao Sauce You will need: 4 tbsp chia seeds / gluten free oats 1 scoop vanilla protein powder 2 teaspoons Organic Acai Powder 4 tbsp blended cooked beetroot pureé 4 tbsp almond milk For the Banana Cacao Sauce: 2 bananas, frozen into chunks 1 tablespoon Organic Cacao Powder 1 scoop chocolate protein powder Dash of almond milk How to make 1) Mix together the chia seeds / oats, protein powder and acai powder in a kilner jar. Stir in the beetroot purée, then add the vanilla extract and almond milk. 2) Give it a good mix until you have a thick, slightly liquidy consistency - the chia will absorb any excess as you leave it in the fridge for at least an hour (overnight is best). 3) When you’re ready to serve, remove the banana chunks from the freezer a few minutes beforehand, and add to a high-power blender with the other ingredients. Add just enough milk to get it going - whizz up until thick and smooth. 4) Pour over the base layer and enjoy between two! Top with a little desiccated coconut if desired. [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Fats explained: What really is a 'healthy' fat?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
The 1990's just called. They want their 'low fat diet' back. Thankfully, our days of avocado avoidance and throwing out our egg yolks are now a distant memory. People are finally catching on – we need fat, and plenty of it, to be happy and healthy. Fat is essential for the health of our hearts, our skin, our digestive system, and virtually everything else in between. Besides, have you ever tasted an egg white omelette? But not all fats are created equal. There are some that we need more than others, and there are some that don’t belong in our bodies at all. We’re told to eat more ‘healthy fats’ – but what does that really mean? Here’s an easy breakdown of what we should (and shouldn’t) be looking for in our dietary fats. #1 - Prioritise whole food fats Undoubtedly, the best sources of fat in our diet is found in whole foods. Whilst there is also a place for healthy oils (we’ll come onto those later), whole food fats come packaged with some crucial nutrients that do not exist in protein and carbohydrate rich food. If you want to be getting these nutrients, you need to be eating whole food fats! Avocados, for example, are an excellent source of potassium, phosphorus, vitamin K and folate. Egg yolks contain B vitamins, vitamin A, zinc and selenium. Oily fish, nuts, seeds, cacao and coconut all have a variety of unique health benefits, so try and include a varied selection regularly in your diet. In general, enjoy fats as close to their natural state as you can. Eat a wide variety of whole food fats, and you won’t go far wrong. #2 - Avoid 'vegetable' oils They might sound healthy, but 'vegetable' oils are seriously bad news. Originally made as an alternative fuel source for cars and as an emulsifier for cleaning products, oils such as sunflower, canola, cottonseed and soybean oils have no place near your body. Vegetable oils contain an exceptionally high concentration of poly-unsaturated fatty acids, which oxidise (damage) easily when exposed to heat. These oxidised fatty acids turn into free radicals in the body, which contribute to premature aging, disease, and even various cancers¹²³. Vegetable oils are exposed to very high temperatures during the manufacturing process – meaning that they are oxidised before they even reach the supermarket shelves! Despite once being recommended as the healthy oil of choice, we now know that we are much better off avoiding vegetable oils at all costs. Without question, they are most certainly not a ‘healthy fat.’ [icegram messages="7123"] #3 - Cook with heat stable (saturated) fats Conventional wisdom once told us to avoid saturated fats. When I first started taking an interest in getting healthy, this is the precise advice I followed. In fact, we all did – after all, how were we to know any better? Newsflash: We were being lied to. As it turns out, saturated fats are among the ‘healthiest fats’ out there – and by far the best choice for cooking. This is because they are the most stable at high temperatures, unlike monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats which oxidise more easily. Here’s the (boring) sciencey bit.
  • Fats are composed of carbon and hydrogen atoms.
  • To stay happy and stable, carbon atoms like to have four bonds, usually surrounded by hydrogen atoms (H) and interconnecting with one or two additional carbon atoms (C)
  • A ‘saturated’ fatty acid is one that is fully cushioned by hydrogen atoms (a.k.a: a happy, stable fat), as per the figure below:
  • Unsaturated fats, on the other hand, feature fewer hydrogen atoms. To compensate for this, they form double bonds between carbon atoms like so:
  • These double carbon bonds in the fatty acid chain shown above cause the fat to become more bendy and fragile, making them less suitable for heating.
  • Unsaturated fats are grouped into two different categories – monounsaturated (mono meaning ‘one’ as in ‘one double bond’) and polyunsaturated (poly meaning ‘more than one.’) Here’s how the chemical composition of a monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fatty acid chain compares:
  • The more double bonds a fat contains, the more susceptible it is to oxidation – explained further below.
Note: This doesn’t mean that unsaturated fats are bad, they’re just less stable when heated. See point 4 for more information on this. Why should we worry about oxidation? Put simply, oxidised fatty acids (fat molecules that have broken away from the main chain and reacted with oxygen) create free radicals in the body that can cause cell damage. You have probably heard of the term antioxidants before; in a nutshell, these help to mop up the damage caused by oxidants – for example, a damaged fatty acid. Polyunsaturated fats are the most prone to oxidation, making them the worse choice to cook with. Remember, oxidised fatty acids = cell damage = bad news for our skin, brain, heart, joints, and virtually every other tissue in our body. Have you ever noticed how olive oil smokes or turns bitter easily when cooking? This is the perfect example of oxidation at work. And olive oil is mainly monounsaturated! Saturated fats, in general, are the least prone to oxidation and therefore the best choice for cooking. Although fats are often classified as ‘saturated’ or ‘unsaturated’, they are very rarely just one or the other. In fact, most fats contain a variety of fatty acid chains that make up their composition. For example: Coconut oil: 91% saturated, 7% monounsaturated, 2% polyunsaturated Butter: 68% saturated, 28% monounsaturated, 4% polyunsaturated Olive oil: 15% saturated, 75% monounsaturated, 10% polyunsaturated Sunflower oil: 12% saturated, 16% monounsaturated, 72% polyunsaturated. Mainly saturated fats, such as coconut oil, are excellent choices for cooking. Mainly monounsaturated fats can be cooked with, but at lower temperatures (think lightly pan frying) than saturated fats. Mainly polyunsaturated fats should not be cooked with. #4 - Use liquid oils for dressing only As a general rule, if it is solid at room temperature, it is suitable for cooking. If it is liquid at room temperature, it is most suited to dressing and using at cool temperatures. Although polyunsaturated fats are not suitable for cooking, they are still essential for our health when used correctly. One of the most well known fats, Omega 3, is in fact a polyunsaturated fat. However, these fats need to be treated with care in order to reap the benefits. Where omega 3 occurs in nature (for example, oily fish), it always comes packaged with Vitamin E – an antioxidant that helps prevent the oxidation of the delicate fatty acids. When polyunsaturated fats are extracted from their natural source, the vitamin E content is lost, which then makes them much more susceptible to oxidation. Therefore, when we eat polyunsaturated fats, they should always be in whole food form or cold processed (to avoid damaging the delicate fatty acids).  Good sources of polyunsaturated fats include oily fish, nuts, seeds, algae, and cold processed fish oil. Bad sources include any polyunsaturated rich oils (such as vegetable oil) that have been exposed to heat. If an oil is liquid at room temperature, it has a higher mono or polyunsaturated fat content. In this case, it is best use for dressing and cold temperature cooking only. Note: When you are buying liquid oils such as olive oil, make sure it has been cold processed (extra virgin). Cheaper olive oils are processed using heat, which makes them much less healthy. The Round Up To summarise, here are my five golden rules of fat: 1) Eat plenty of whole food fats – avocados, nuts, seeds, eggs, oily fish, coconut, cacao, olives. There is no such thing as an ‘unhealthy fat’ in it’s natural form. 2) Avoid vegetable oils at all costs. They are toxic and do not belong in the human body. This cannot be underestimated. 3) Do not fear saturated fat. It is the best choice for cooking. 4) Use cold pressed plant oils such as extra virgin olive oil for dressing. 5) Make sure you are regularly eating omega 3 – either from oily fish, or an omega 3 supplement. Read this article for more information on omega 3.   Thanks for reading! If you liked this article please share it with a friend. [icegram messages="16075"] Sources 1) Price, Weston A. Nutrition and Physical Degeneration: A Comparison of Primitive and Modern Diets and Their Effects, 8th ed. La Mesa, California: Price-Pottenger Nutrition Foundation 2008 2) Colpo, Anthony. The Great Cholesterol Con: Why Everything You’ve Been Told About Cholesterol, Diet and Heart Disease is Wrong! Raleigh, N.C: Lulu, 2006 3) Erasmus, Udo. Fats That Heal, Fats That Kill: The Complete Guide to Fats, Oils, Cholesterol, and Human Health. Burnaby, BC, Canada: Alive 1993

item.title: Spiced Raw Chocolate Truffles
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: Ever have those days where NOTHING but chocolate will do? We get it. It’s called being human. If you’re having one of those days, why not whip up a batch of these Spiced Raw Chocolate Truffles? These silky smooth, melt in the mouth balls of goodness are perfect for when you fancy something a little indulgent. Best of all, they’re 100% healthy too! Here’s how you make them… Spiced Raw Chocolate Truffles Makes 12 truffles Ingredients 6 medjool dates 100g Pip and Nut Almond Butter 2tbsp Raw Cacao Powder + extra for coating 1/2 tsp cinnamon 1/4 tsp nutmeg 1/4 tsp Himalayan Salt 1 tsp vanilla extract 2 tbsp cacao nibs 2 tbsp chia seeds 2 tbsp desiccated coconut How to make 1) Add your dates to a food processor and blend until it makes a paste. Add in the almond butter and blitz again until smooth. Add 2 tbsp cacao powder, spices, salt and vanilla extract and blend once more. 2) Transfer the mixture from your food processor into a mixing bowl. Using a spatula or wooden spoon, fold in the cacao nibs, chia seeds and coconut. 3) Roll the mixture into balls using your fingers. Leave to set in the fridge for one hour. 4) Roll the balls in a little extra cacao powder before serving. Enjoy! [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Is this the world's healthiest cooking oil? (hint: it's not coconut oil)
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
One of the most important advances in the world of nutrition over the past few years has been the understanding of fats. The word ‘fat’ was once considered a dirty word, but we now know that’s not the case. We need fats, and plenty of them, to keep our bodies healthy and performing at a high level. If you read my previous article about healthy fats vs unhealthy fats, you’ll know exactly what types of oils you should and shouldn’t be cooking with. If you haven’t read it yet, you might want to check it out before we go any further. When it comes to cooking oils, coconut oil is most people’s first choice – and for good reason too. I love coconut oil as much as the next guy, but there’s another oil I want to throw into the mix that is equally amazing. 100% Grass Fed Ghee. Surprised? Here's what you need to know about ghee. What is ghee? Ghee is a traditional cooking fat commonly used in Indian cuisine, made by clarifying butter until the milk solids are removed. As we’ll come on to shortly, this clarification process makes ghee safe to eat even if you are intolerant to dairy. Once the milk solids are removed, we are left with a delicious golden butterfat with a rich, nutty flavour. Ghee is stable at high temperatures (with a higher smoke point than coconut oil) which makes it the perfect choice for frying, baking and roasting. But what if I can't handle dairy? If you’re intolerant to dairy (like me), you may be surprised to know that ghee is completely safe for you to eat. The reason for this is that the process of making ghee removes all the problematic components of dairy that people commonly react to – including lactose and casein. It took me a little while to get my head around this. I hadn’t so much as looked at a glass of milk or stick of butter for at least five years, so when I started consuming ghee, I was convinced I was going to have some sort of reaction. But I didn’t – in fact, after just a few weeks of ghee consumption, I started feeling even healthier thanks to the addition of nutrients I wasn’t getting enough of before. Note: If you’re extremely sensitive to dairy, you may want to start slowly with ghee and see if you notice any adverse reactions. Even though this is very rarely the case, it’s better to play it on the safe side to make sure. The health benefits Ghee is a primarily saturated fat that is stable at high temperatures. By nature, this makes it a fantastic choice for cooking. But there’s so much more to it than just a high smoke point – choose an organic, grass fed ghee, and you’ll discover a bunch of seriously amazing health benefits:
  • See that rich yellow pigment? That’s a sure fire sign of the presence of conjugated linoleic acid (CLA), a fatty acid with powerful health benefits found only in meat and dairy products. CLA has been shown to be beneficial for fat loss and1,2, more importantly, regular consumption of CLA has been shown to lower your risk of diabeties and cancer3,4
  • Ghee is rich in butyrate, a short chain fatty acid, which has been shown to reduce inflammation and promote healthy digestive function5. In traditional Ayurvedic medicine, ghee is often recommended to individuals with weak digestion, constipation, or a poor immune system.
  • Ghee is a fantastic source of vitamin K2, a unique nutrient found primarily in animal foods that works synergistically with calcium and vitamin D (also found in ghee) which help to maintain strong bones and teeth, and a healthy heart.
  • Ghee is high in vitamins A and E, which help to maintain healthy skin, eyes, and a strong immune system. Consumption of ghee has also been shown to reduce LDL cholesterol and serum triglycerides6.
  • Grass fed ghee contains omega 3. It is one of the only non-marine sources of this essential fatty acid.
  • Ghee is primarily saturated fat, and is suitable for cooking at temperatures up to 240C. This makes it one of the best choices for high heat cooking, and can reach higher temperatures than coconut oil and regular butter.
Why I love ghee I’ll be completely honest – I don’t eat ghee for the health benefits. I eat it because I love the taste. Nothing beats a spoonful melted onto a baked sweet potato, or the delicious nutty flavour it lends to my roasted vegetables. Ghee is sustainable, ethical, wholesome and delicious. The health benefits? These are a pretty cool bonus too. [icegram messages="16075"] Sources 1) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2826589/ 2) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11316347 3) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22648724 4) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23475478 5) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3070119/ 6) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22131700

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Is this the world's healthiest cooking oil?

item.title: White rice vs brown rice: Which is healthier?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: For years, it has been drummed into our collective consciousness that brown rice is healthier than white. And from a common sense perspective, this makes complete sense. Brown rice undergoes less processing than white; and generally the more processed something is, the worse it is for us. White rice is more processed, but is it more unhealthy? Let’s take a look. Rice: What you need to know Rice, both white and brown, is a staple food in the diet of more than half of the world’s population. There are hundreds of different varieties; basmati, long grain, short grain, sushi, wild rice – but for the purposes of this article, we’re going to compare the fundamentals: white rice and brown rice. In it’s most ‘whole’ form, rice is made up of a hull, bran, germ, and on the very inside, the endosperm. Brown rice is simply the rice grain with the hull removed, leaving the bran, germ, and endosperm intact. White rice, on the other hand, is polished even further to remove both the bran and the germ, leaving just the endosperm remaining. The endosperm is composed almost entirely of starch, which converts very quickly to glucose in the bloodstream. The nutrients and fibre found in rice are located in the bran and the germ - and as you can see in the nutritional comparison below, the white rice has a lower nutrient content because it does not contain these parts: 100g Brown Rice (cooked) 111 calories 23g carbohydrates 1.8g fibre 2.6g protein 3.0mg niacin (vitamin B3) 0.2g thiamin (vitamin B1) 83.9mg magnesium 162mg phosphorus 100g White Rice (cooked) 130 calories 29g carbohydrate 0g fibre 2.4g protein 0.2mg thiamin 1.5mg niacin 8.0mg magnesium 33.0mg phosphorus On the face of it, it’s no contest – brown rice contains more nutrients and more fibre than it’s paler counterpart, so should therefore be considered a healthier option. Right? Introducing phytic acid Not necessarily. Because although most of the nutritional value of the rice grain is locked away in the bran and the germ, it also comes packaged with something not so pleasant – phytic acid. Phytic acid is a built-in defence mechanism in plants, indigestible to humans and animals with one stomach. It is found in some degree in more or less all grains, nuts and seeds, but is particularly concentrated in brown rice. The idea of phytic acid is to protect the grain from being eaten. Just as a chameleon changes colour to blend into the background, and pufferfish blow themselves up like a balloon to look as unappetising as possible, rice also has an in-built defence mechanism in the form of phytic acid. Phytic acid binds to minerals, including calcium, magnesium, iron and zinc, interfering with absorption and thus rendering them useless to the body. This makes what is a modest nutritional profile on paper (more on this later) become much less impressive, with the majority of vitamins and minerals in brown rice becoming obsolete. What’s more, phytic acid doesn’t just bind to the minerals found in rice, but also to minerals in the body – which explains why people who eat a diet heavy in grains often carry multiple mineral deficiencies¹. Whilst white rice contains less vitamins and minerals on paper, the nutrients it does contain are more bioavailable than brown, and it will not interfere with the nutrient absorption of the other food you are eating. In a nutshell, the phytic acid content of brown rice stops you from unlocking the good stuff - in both the rice itself, and the food you eat with it. Another worry about eating brown rice is the potential of being exposed to arsenic, a harmful carcinogen which can contribute to a number of cancers. The water flooded conditions required to grow rice mean that it absorbs arsenic from the soil, with the majority that is absorbed being found in the outer bran and germ. Further long term research is needed to determine whether or not the levels of arsenic found in rice could be harmful to health, but this study shows that brown rice consumption may lead to potentially harmful levels of arsenic in the blood. [icegram messages="7123"] Digestibility One of the biggest signs about whether a food is healthy or not for you is how you feel after eating it. Personally, I feel like I have just swallowed a brick after eating brown rice, which is a sure fire sign that my body is better off without it. White rice is easy for me to digest and I feel good after eating it, so I keep it in my diet. There’s no phytic acid in white rice – just simple starch that may not be the most nutritious food in the world, but tastes pretty damn good. The presence of phytic acid in brown rice is why people often feel bloated or sluggish after eating it. If any food makes you feel this way, it's probably advisable you cut it out from your diet. Unlocking the potential There are, however, ways to make brown rice more digestible and the nutrients more bioavailable. One of these methods is soaking and sprouting, but it does require a little planning ahead. Here’s how you do it: 1) Rinse the rice, and transfer to a glass bowl with roughly double the amount of warm water to rice. Cover loosely with a tea towel and leave for 12 hours. 2) Drain, rinse, and repeat this soaking process two or three more times, until a tiny sprout begins to appear. You now have sprouted brown rice, which will keep for about five days ready to cook when you need it. 3) The process of soaking and sprouting the rice neutralises the phytic acid and enzyme inhibitors that make brown rice hard to digest – making brown rice the fairly nutritious food source it promises to be on paper. But is it worth it? Of course, there is debate about whether the soaking and sprouting process brown rice has to undergo to neutralise the phytic acid content is actually worth the effort. Yes, brown rice does contain some nutrients; but, even when properly prepared, it really can't be considered a nutrient dense food. In comparison to the sweet potato, for example, brown rice contains less fibre and more calories. Sweet potato is also much richer in a wide range of nutrients, most notably Vitamin A, C, and potassium. The same is true for all other plant based starches, including squash, plantain, beets, yams, and even the humble white potato. All of these foods contain more nutrients per calorie than brown rice. Advocates of brown rice often tout the fibre content as a reason for brown rice being a ‘health food.’ It is true, brown rice is a source of fibre – but not any more so than most vegetables and even some fruits. If you’re eating a diet rich in veggies and fruits, and a few nuts and seeds too, then getting an adequate fibre intake shouldn’t be a problem you face. In fact, as brown rice is nearly all insoluble fibre, it may cause digestive discomfort among certain individuals. So what does it all mean? To summarise, I personally think that soaking and sprouting brown rice is too much effort and therefore always opt for white. White rice is essentially a benign starch, with not much going for it other than it is tasty and an easily digestible source of glucose. It is hard to make the case for white rice being particularly unhealthy, given that it is a staple in the diet of the vast majority of Asian populations, who have some of the highest life expectancy in the world. In fact, Macau, Japan and Singapore, all three of which are liberal rice consuming nations, make up 3 of the 4 countries in the world with the highest average life expectancy. Note: This probably isn't down to the nutritional value of the rice itself, rather the nutritious things it is paired with in Asian cuisine – fresh fish and copious amounts of vegetables being the two most notable. Rice isn’t a very nutrient dense food, so if you eat it, don’t do so at the expense of your veggies. But if you’re training hard and need the extra carbohydrates for fuel, white rice is a tasty and efficient way to do so. As for the brown stuff? I think it's probably best left on the shelves. Sources 1) Wills MR and others. Phytic Acid and Nutritional Rickets in Immigrants. The Lancet, April 8, 1972, 771-773. 2) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3251121/ 3. Walker ARP and others. The Effect of Bread Rich in Phytate Phosphorus on the metabolism of Certain Mineral Salts with Special Reference to Calcium. The Biochemical Journal 1948 42(1):452-461. If you know anyone who could benefit from this article, please share it :) [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: 15 Immune Boosting Superfoods to Stay Healthy All Winter
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: Nothing puts a dampener on the holiday season quite like falling ill. This time of year is all about spending quality time with your friends and family – the last thing you need is a stuffy nose or a pounding headache to screw up your plans. Unless you want to hibernate for winter, maintaining a strong immune system is the best way to stay healthy during the colder months. You can’t wrap yourself in cotton wool and sanitise everything in sight – so your best bet is to have a body resilient enough to fight off whatever comes your way. The food that you eat is one of the most important factors when it comes to maintaining a healthy immune system. Combine that with adequate sleep, good digestive health and low stress levels, and you’ll be strong enough to shrug off virtually anything that the cold weather may throw at you. With this in mind, here are 15 of my favourite immune boosting superfoods. Add them to your diet and stay healthy all winter! #1 – Fermented foods Did you know that 70% of your immune system is located in your gut? For this reason, it’s vitally important to take care of your digestive system in order to fight off illness and infection. Fermented foods such as sauerkraut and kombucha are an excellent source of beneficial probiotics, which help to maintain a healthy balance of good bacteria in the gut. If you don’t eat fermented foods regularly, we strongly recommend a high quality probiotic supplement to help keep your digestive system as healthy as can be. #2 – Coconut oil Coconut oil contains the short chain fatty acids lauric and caprylic acid, which have powerful anti-viral and anti-pathogenic properties. Just a couple of teaspoons of coconut oil each day are enough to reap the immune boosting benefits – you can use it for cooking, spreading, or even whizzing in your smoothies! #3 – Berries Berries are rich in vitamin C and antioxidants, but only recently researchers have discovered a new compound in berries called stillbenoids. In a study published in the US Journal of Molecular Nutrition and Food Research, stillbenoids were shown to increase expression of the Cathelicidin Anti-Microbial Peptide (CAMP) gene, which plays a direct role in healthy immune function. Strawberries, blueberries, raspberries and blackberries are some of the most nutrient dense fruits around, so make a great immune boosting addition to any diet. #4 – Wild Salmon Wild Salmon is one of the best dietary sources of omega 3, which reduces inflammation and can also enhance the function of immune cells. Lightly poach or steam it to avoid damaging the fragile fatty acids. #5 – Brazil Nuts Brazil Nuts are well known for their whopping selenium content – just four of these nuts is enough to meet your RDA of this mineral! Selenium deficiency is a major contributor to a weakened immune system, which make Brazil Nuts an excellent way to stay protected against illness. #6 – Turmeric As one of the most powerful antioxidants on the planet, it’s no surprise that turmeric consumption has been clinically proven to boost the immune system. Combine it with a warming spice such as black pepper or ginger for maximum benefits. #7 – Garlic Garlic has been used as a natural remedy for colds and flu for centuries, dating back to Ancient Greek times when patients were prescribed raw garlic cloves when suffering from flu like symptoms! Garlic contains a unique compound called allicin, which has proven immune boosting properties, along with a rich sulfur content which has anti-microbial effects in the body. In this large scale study, garlic consumption was shown to reduce the number of colds by 63% over a 12 week period! #8 – Elderberry Rich in immune boosting antioxidants and vitamins A & C, Elderberry has long been used as a seasonal health tonic. It also helps to alleviate mucus in the respiratory tract, which makes it an excellent remedy for coughs and blocked noses. Fresh elderberries can be hard to find, which is why Elderberry Syrup is such a convenient immune booster. #9 – Ginger In the practice of Ayurveda, ginger is known as vishabhesaj, which translates to ‘universal medicine.’ This fiery herb has been shown to significantly reduce inflammation and help to prevent against infection, and is also especially beneficial for the digestive system, helping to stimulate the secretion of digestive enzymes and improve the nutrient absorption of food. Ginger is versatile and great for both savoury and sweet dishes, or freshly sliced to make a warming ginger tea. #10 – Manuka Honey Have you ever wondered why the honey of the New Zealand Manuka Bush is widely considered to be the most superior of all honeys? Manuka Honey is so highly regarded for it’s health benefits because of it’s powerful concentration of enzymes, which work in a distinctive synergy to create what is known as a Unique Manuka Factor (UMF). This UMF acts as a natural anti-bacterial agent within the body, making Manuka Honey an extremely potent immune booster. Manuka Honey also promotes healing (both internally and externally), which is why it is often used as a natural remedy for sore throats, tummy-ache, and even eczema. #11 – Thyme The aromatic compounds in thyme have been shown to accelerate the healing of infections in the digestive, nasal and respiratory tracts – making it an excellent tonic for colds, flu, bronchitis, and even candida. Combine it with fresh garlic in a marinade for chicken, fish or vegetables for extra immune-boosting goodness. #12 – Apple Cider Vinegar Raw, unpasteurised apple cider vinegar is bursting with beneficial enzymes which help to detoxify the body of bad bacteria and promote an alkaline PH. The acetic acid in apple cider vinegar helps to break up mucus around the body, whilst also cleansing the lymphatic system to help it effectively process and remove toxins. A shot of apple cider vinegar can also be consumed before meals to improve the nutrient absorption of your food! #13 – Echinacea Echinacea is an extract taken from the Eastern Purple Coneflower native to North America. It was originally used by Plains Indians as a remedy for coughs, sore throats and headaches, but quickly shot to popularity in Europe when it became one of the first herbs to be the subject of clinical medicine trials. Echinacea consumption in winter has been shown to protect against and shorten the duration of cold and flu viruses. #14 – Reishi Mushroom Reishi’s nicknames of ‘The Mushroom of Immortality’ and ‘The King of all Herbs’ tell you all you need to know about this prized commodity. Reishi is extremely rich in antioxidants, and has unique compounds that up-regulate the immune system and improve energy levels. Reishi mushrooms are so powerful, they are even used as a treatment for tumours and cancer. #15 – Zinc rich foods (oysters, red meat, pumpkin seeds and dark chocolate) Last on my list is a collection of foods, all chosen for their high zinc content. Zinc is an essential nutrient for maintaining a healthy immune system, as insufficient zinc levels have been shown to slow down the immune response. Furthermore, zinc also accelerates healing, with clinical studies showing that zinc can significantly reduce the duration of common colds. Oysters, red meat, pumpkin seeds and dark chocolate all provide great sources of zinc! Remember, diet has a big part to play in maintaining a healthy immune system, but it’s not the only thing to look out for. A weak immune system is very rarely a result of just one factor – it is a system, after all, and requires a number of components to be in balance to work as well as it should. Be sure that you are getting plenty of sleep, managing your stress levels and exercising regularly to really take your immune system to the next level! If you know someone that this article could help, please share it :) [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Digestion Boosting Pineapple, Ginger & Baobab Smoothie
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: As winter begins to set in and with holiday season fast approaching, give your digestive system a much needed boost with this Pineapple, Ginger & Baobab Smoothie. Packed full of tummy-loving enzymes, vitamin C and soluble fibre, it's the perfect way to kickstart your morning and leave you fresh and energised all day! • Pineapple: contains the protein digesting enzyme bromelain, which helps the body to break down and assimilate amino acids from food. Also an excellent source of vitamin C. • Ginger: stimulates the secretion of our body's natural digestive juices, promotes motility in the digestive tract and soothes stomach upset. • Baobab: is exceptionally high in vitamin C (six times more than oranges!) and an excellent source of soluble fibre. • Banana: is an excellent source of prebiotic fibre and potassium. The less ripe the banana, the higher the prebiotic fibre content. The yellower (and less brown spots) the better! • Coconut milk: is rich in lauric acid, an anti-inflammatory and anti-bacterial fatty acid that inhibits the growth of unwanted bacteria and pathogens in the gut. Recipe serves 1: 200ml full fat coconut milk 1 large yellow banana 1/4 pineapple, chopped 1/4 teaspoon of minced ginger 1 tbsp organic baobab powder Add all ingredients to a high powered blender, and blitz for 30 seconds until smooth! 5 easy tips for better digestion: 1) Stress less: The gut-brain axis means that when your mind is stressed out, your tummy feels it too. Take steps to manage your stress levels for a happier, healthier gut. 2) Leave longer between meals: A constant flow of food means constant work for your digestive system. Leave 4 - 6 hours between your main meals to give your food time to fully digest. 3) Stay hydrated: Our guts need water to moisten the stool and improve intestinal transit. 4) But don't drink with your meals: As this dilutes stomach acid and makes food harder to break down. Leave 30 minutes to 1 hour after your meal before you grab a drink. 5) Take a high quality probiotic: To help populate your gut with beneficial bacteria. Even better, eat fermented foods such as sauerkraut and kombucha on a regular basis. [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Recipe: Apple & Cinnamon Baked Oats with Honey, Cinnamon and Cashew Butter
item.dc:creator: Pamela Higgins
item.content:encoded: As the weather gets colder, I’ve recently switched to warming bowls of porridge to refuel after a morning workout. However, I’ve also recently discovered baked oats and now developed a bit of an obsession!  This breakfast creation has a festive touch to it, thanks to the combination of apples and spices like cinnamon and ginger. What’s great about this recipe is that not only is it filling and delicious, but it's also packed full of fibre and is low in sugar. The addition of chia seeds adds an extra nutrient boost, while Pip & Nut’s new Honey & Cinnamon Cashew Butter makes the ideal topping for this winter-proof dish! Here's how I made it... Apple & Cinnamon Baked Oats with Honey, Cinnamon and Cashew Butter (serves 4) Ingredients 1 cup rolled oats 1 cup jumbo oats 4 tbsp organic chia seeds 4 tbsp coconut sugar 1 tsp each of mixed spice, cinnamon and ginger 1 tsp baking powder 1 tsp vanilla extract 1/2 cup apple puree 2 cups almond milk 2 small apples, chopped Honey, Cinnamon & Cashew Butter - to serve Get baking! 1) Preheat the oven to 190 degrees C and have a deep glass dish ready for your baked oats 2) Mix together the oats, chia seeds, brown sugar (or alternative), baking powder and spices in a large bowl. 3) Whisk together the egg, apple puree, vanilla extract and milk, then pour into the bowl. 4) Stir in the diced apples, mix everything together, then pour into your dish. Bake for about 15-20 minutes, until golden brown and cooked through. 5) Remove from the heat, leave to cool slightly then dish up - and of course, top with a drizzle of your favourite Pip & Nut nut butter! To make this dish extra festive, you could also scatter over fresh or dried cranberries and other nuts. [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Is your protein powder doing you more harm than good?
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded:
Protein powder is the biggest selling sports supplement on the planet. The market is saturated with hundreds of brands each claiming to be the best – but how many of them really live up to the promises? Sadly, no matter how sexy the packaging or how high the protein content, there’s some murky goings on in the world of protein powder. Questionable ingredients and artificial additives on the label are one thing, but in reality, that’s just the beginning. Before you whip up your next protein shake, it’s worth taking a closer look at exactly what’s going into it – and the effects it could be having on your body. Is your protein powder doing you more harm than good? Here are some important things to look out for. Step 1: Where has the protein come from? The most important place to start when checking out a protein powder is to see exactly where the protein is coming from. These days, more and more people are switching to plant based protein powders, which is a brilliant thing. But simply seeing a ‘vegan’ icon on the label is not enough. Remember - ‘Plant Based’ doesn’t automatically mean ‘healthy,’ especially when it comes to vegan protein powders that are made with soy protein as the main protein source. Some of the worst offending proteins include: Soy Despite it's high protein content, soy consumption comes with a number of health risks. One of the most notable is soy’s phytoestrogen content, which has been shown to disrupt endocrine function and cause severe hormonal imbalances in both men and women. Soy is also very high in the ‘anti-nutrient’ phytic acid, which binds to and removes important minerals such as calcium, magnesium and zinc from the body. Phytic acid also reduces the assimilation of amino acids; so despite the high protein content on the label, the presence of phytic acid means that your body is actually absorbing much less than you think. Brown Rice Another culprit, brown rice, is also very high in phytic acid. Phytic acid is notoriously difficult to digest, which is why many people feel bloated or sluggish after consuming cheap brown rice protein (or brown rice in general). To avoid this problem, brown rice protein must be sprouted and / or fermented before consuming to remove the phytic acid content. The majority of companies who use brown rice protein do not sprout or ferment it because it is much more expensive to do so; but as a result, they are left with a protein that is probably doing more harm than good. If you are buying a rice protein, always look for the word ‘sprouted’ or ‘fermented’ on the label. Whey A lot of people have difficulty digesting whey, but if this is not the case for you, then a high quality whey protein can be a great choice of protein powder. The key with whey is to choose one made from the milk of healthy, grass fed cows; not one that is loaded with hormones, antibiotics, and other by-products of the ‘conventional’ dairy industry. It should also be cold-processed – see step 2 for more details on this. What you should be looking for If you opt for whey protein, be sure that it is organic and grass fed. If you are choosing plant based proteins, look for easy to digest sources with low phytic acid content such as cold pressed hemp and pea protein. Step 2: Has the protein been heated? As discussed in our previous article Why Choose Raw Protein?, excessive heat used during the manufacturing stage can denature amino acids and make them difficult to absorb. Furthermore, heating may oxidise volatile fatty acids (especially in proteins such as hemp and whey) which renders them toxic and dangerous to consume. It may sometimes seem cheaper to opt for non-cold processed / non raw protein powders, but if they are harder for your body to absorb, you’re not really getting value for money. What you should be looking for For optimum absorption and assimilation of your protein powder, always choose raw or cold processed. Step 3: Read the label! By law, manufacturers have to list all ingredients present in a product on the ingredients list, so here is where you should look out for questionable additives and bulking agents that may be compromising the quality of your product. Here are a few of the most common offenders in protein powder, and why you should be avoiding them: Soy lecithin: Soy lecithin is an emulsifying agent that is made by “degumming” crude soya bean oil until the lecithin (a cell membrane) is separated from the oil, before it is dried and often bleached using hydrogen peroxide. We touched on the health risks of soy earlier, so keep an eye out to make sure there is none being slipped into your product without you realising. Maltodextrin: Maltodextrin is a cheap bulking agent made from genetically modified corn, commonly used as a ‘filler’ in protein powders. If you see this ingredient, it is a sure-fire sign that the manufacturer is trying to cut costs by packing out their product with cheap ingredients. Aspartame / Sucralose: To keep the sugar content down, companies often resort to using artificial sweeteners such as aspartame or sucralose; but just because they are ‘sugar free,’ doesn’t automatically make them healthy. Aspartame consumption has been linked to the formation of brain tumours¹, brain cell degeneration², and memory loss³; whilst sucralose has been shown to alter gut flora and increase intestinal permeability in animal models4 (no equivalent tests have yet been carried out on humans) and can also weaken insulin sensitivity5. Flavouring: The words ‘flavour’ or ‘flavouring’ on a label translates to ‘artificial flavouring’ – as by law, the manufacturers do not have to put the word ‘artificial’ in the ingredients list. If you would rather your protein powder was not flavoured in a laboratory, steer clear of products that use ‘flavouring’ as an ingredient. ‘Organic Flavour’ is flavour that has been derived from organic raw materials, such as fruits and vegetables, and is a much better choice. What you should be looking for Clean formulas with no ingredients you can’t pronounce. If you are choosing a flavoured option, keep an eye out for artificial flavourings and choose protein powders sweetened with stevia, monk fruit, xylitol, yacon or a little coconut sugar. Step 4: Why are you using it? If you’re training hard or playing sports on a regular basis, a high quality protein powder can be an excellent way to give your muscles that extra fuel they need to recover from your workouts. They can also be added to your recipes as a way to bump up the protein content and keep you satisfied for longer. But when protein powders start to replace real food, it’s time to take a step back. Whole foods should always be prioritised, with protein powders considered as a supplement to a healthy diet – only if and when you need them. By all means, have one after a workout, but don’t skip a healthy, nutrient dense lunch in favour of a protein shake. Quality vs Quantity Are you over consuming poor quality protein? Be cautious of cheap oversized protein bags and unnecessarily high amounts of protein per scoop. Consuming poor quality, hard to digest proteins such as these may well be doing you more harm than good. Remember, the protein industry has massively over-hyped daily protein requirements in order to drive sales of their products. The human body can only assimilate so much protein each day – any more is just wasted money and unnecessary strain on your digestive system. More does not always equal better. Protein quality should be your number one priority.
  Sources: 1) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8939194 2) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23553132 3) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23280025 4) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18800291 5) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23633524

item.title: Recipe: Coconut Almond Fudge Slices
item.dc:creator: Charlis Noms
item.content:encoded: The following is a guest recipe by Charli of the popular health food blog Nom Happy. We're delighted to welcome Charli to our blog to share this fabulous recipe! --- Regular almond butter is pretty amazing, but any of you who've tried Pip and Nut's Coconut Almond Butter will know that it's even better than the original. I love it so much that, immediately after Vivo Life contacted me to ask if I'd be interested in making a recipe, I knew exactly what product I'd feature. And that is how these lovely Coconut Almond Fudge slices were born! Although they have three layers, these slices are surprisingly easy to make; the perfect snack to whip up on a Sunday afternoon so you have something healthy to indulge in for the rest of the week! On top of that, they're vegan, gluten-free, (almost) raw, refined sugar free and delicious, so I highly recommend you give them a try! In my opinion, these are actually better than the millionaire's shortbread they resemble. That's a grand claim, I know, but I'm prepared to make it - they're definitely healthier if not tastier as well! In short, these are AWESOME, even if I do say so myself! I'd love you to give them a try and please let me know if you do. Here's the recipe! Coconut Almond Fudge Slices Makes about 8 medium sized slices Ingredients: For the bottom layer 1/4 cup soaked dates 1/2 cup shredded / desiccated coconut 3/4 cup oats 1 tbsp coconut oil, melted 1 tbsp maple syrup, honey, or other liquid sweetener For the middle layer 1/2 cup Coconut Almond Butter 1 tbsp maple syrup, honey, or other liquid sweetner 2 tbsp coconut oil, melted For the top layer 5 tbsp coconut oil, melted 1/2 tbsp maple syrup, honey, or other liquid sweetener 1 tbsp cacao powder 1/2 tbsp lucuma powder (optional) Flaked almonds (or similar), to serve Method For the bottom layer: 1) Place the oats and coconut in a food processor and blend until a powder is formed. 2) Add the dates, whizz for 10 seconds, then add the remaining ingredients and process until the mixture begins to form small clumps. 3) Pour the mixture in a small baking tray - I used a disposable foil 20cm x 13cm tray but you can use whatever you have around - and press gently into the corners, ensuring there is an even spread throughout the tin. You may want to use the back of a spoon t0 achieve a smoother surface. 4) Place the tin to one side and begin on the second layer. For the middle layer: 1) Place all the ingredients (make sure your coconut oil is melted!!) in a bowl and mix until well combined. 2) Pour on top of the bottom layer and shake to get an even covering, then place the tin in the freezer for 5-10 minutes to set. For the top layer: 1) Remove the tin from the freezer - you will want to leave it out for a few minutes so that the top layer doesn't crack when you pour it on top. 2) Whisk all the ingredients together until incorporated, then pour on top of the other layers and - yup, you guessed it - tap the sides of the tin to level it out! 3) If using, sprinkle the flaked almonds over the chocolate. Either place the tin in the fridge or leave out to cool, and then cut into slices and enjoy! Thanks for reading! Charli   [icegram messages="16075"]

Satisfy your cravings with these delicious and easy to make Coconut Almond Fudge Slices! You won't believe they're gluten free, dairy free and vegan!

item.title: Magical Maca: Could this superfood change your life?
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: It seems that 2015 has really been maca's year, doesn't it? I first heard about maca a few years ago, but back then, it was almost impossible to find anywhere that sold it. Nowadays, it's become so popular that earlier this year there was an official worldwide shortage! Make no mistake: people everywhere are falling in love with the rich, caramel like flavours of maca. We're adding it to our smoothie bowls, sprinkling it over our porridge, and even using it as part of our favourite desserts. But most importantly of all, those that use maca regularly are starting to notice some seriously amazing health benefits. So what is all the fuss about? Just what is causing maca to become one of the world’s most sought after superfoods? Let's take a quick look. Warrior Food Whilst maca may be a fairly new discovery to the Western world, it has been a staple in the diets of native Peruvians for thousands of years. Maca grows naturally in the mineral rich soil of the Andes Mountains at altitudes of over 10,000 feet, and is widely considered to offer a number of exciting health benefits; including a unique ability to boost energy, balance hormones, and bolster the immune system. Traditionally, maca was valued as such a prized commodity in it’s native Peru, it was often reserved for Incan Warriors before battle to promote strength, stamina, and longevity. It was also given to men and women trying for a baby as a natural way to boost fertility and sex drive. Amongst it’s many nicknames, maca was often referred to as ‘warrior food’, ‘food of the gods’ and, in more recent times, ‘nature’s viagra.’ Maca is widely considered to be an adaptogen – meaning that it ‘adapts’ to imbalances in the body and helps to correct them. It is for this reason that it is considered as a remedy to so many health concerns. Until recent years, maca has largely slipped under the radar of ‘conventional’ medicine. However, with more and more people incorporating maca into their diet and enjoying the many health benefits, scientists have started to stand up and take note. The evidence There are a number of exciting clinical studies emerging on the health benefits of maca. Putting this particular root to one side for a moment, how cool is it that people are starting to recognise the power of real food as medicine? Instead of trialling drugs, scientists have started looking to plants and herbs as the treatment and prevention of common diseases and deficiencies. Long may it continue! Although there are more studies yet to be released, here are just some of the health benefits that maca has been shown to offer thus far: Maca boosts athletic performance Since the days of the ancient Incan warriors, maca has been used as a natural performance booster. I personally like to put a teaspoon or two in my pre-workout smoothie to boost my energy levels. And, in a study on male cyclists, subjects who consumed maca every day for two weeks improved their time trial results faster than those who did not consume maca1. Maca boosts libido and sexual function Traditionally, maca was given to couples that were trying for a baby. And in numerous studies on both men and women, maca has been shown to improve libido and sexual function2,3,4 Maca improves fertility Further to it’s libido boosting benefits, there is evidence to suggest that consuming maca may improve fertility in women5 and sperm count in men6. Through my research on maca for this article, I have found countless testimonials all over the internet from couples that credit maca for it’s ability to help them conceive. Maca balances hormones If you have hormonal imbalances, maca may be able to help. Remember we spoke earlier about how maca is an adaptogen? When used to treat hormones, maca ‘adapts’ to the conditions presented by the endocrine (hormone producing) system and helps to restore balance. Maca is often recommended to people with adrenal fatigue or thyroid problems, and has been shown in a pilot study to be an effective natural alternative to HRT (hormone replacement therapy)7. Maca has also been shown to be beneficial for symptoms of the menopause8. Maca may improve memory and learning ability Further human research on this one is needed, but in studies on mice, maca consumption was shown to increase their ability to learn new skills, and improve short and long term memory and recall9. Maca increases energy levels and improves mood We touched on this earlier when we spoke about the cyclists, but there are also pretty solid studies that suggest regular consumption of maca can boost your energy levels and even improve your mood10! Remember, the above information only refers to the scientific studies that maca has been the subject of so far. With new studies emerging all the time, there is still a lot more we have to learn! How to get more maca in your diet One of the main obstacles against consuming more maca is not knowing how best to incorporate it into your diet. Here are a few ways to start eating more maca, starting today! In smoothies My favourite way to take maca is in a smoothie. It pairs with just about anything, but goes especially well with banana, cinnamon, vanilla, cacao, and just about any nut butter. A teaspoon or two in your pre-workout smoothie provides a great natural energy boost too! Photo by @rebecca.eats.leaves on Instagram In raw chocolate Maca and raw chocolate are a match made in heaven, so next time you are raw chocolate making, add a tablespoon or two of maca powder. If you don’t have time to make your own, try this cacao and maca superfood snack bar! Maca 'hot chocolate' Add a teaspoon of maca powder to a healthy hot chocolate to add a delicious, warming caramel flavour. My favourite D.I.Y hot chocolate consists of 1.5 teaspoons of raw cacao powder, 1 teaspoon coconut sugar, 1 teaspoon of maca powder and a pinch of cinnamon, mixed with warm coconut milk. Sprinkled on breakfast Simply sprinkle maca onto your favourite breakfast foods (coconut yoghurt, oats, or chia pudding) for extra flavour and health benefits! Photo by @jesssriv on Instagram Golden Mylk Here's an idea we made just yesterday at Vivo HQ! It combines maca, turmeric, ginger, cinnamon, bee pollen and black pepper in a nourishing, anti-inflammatory hot drink. The full recipe can be found on our facebook page! As you can see there are so many different ways to use maca! It's delicious, versatile, and a little really goes a long way. If you're looking to improve your energy levels, balance your hormones or perhaps even increase your memory, I'd definitely recommend giving this superfood a try. Thanks for reading! If you know someone that maca could benefit, please share this article :) [icegram messages="16075"] Sources 1) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19781622 2) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12472620 3) http://www.biomedcentral.com/1472-6882/10/44 4) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19260845 5) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24333960 6) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11753476 7) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3614596/ 8) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21840656 9) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16796734 10) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20090350

item.title: Healthy Christmas Recipe Round Up
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: Everyone deserves to treat themselves at this time of year. And yes, that includes you. Christmas is not the time for counting calories or worrying about making the ‘perfect’ food choices. It’s a time for celebration with friends and family, for enjoying the festivities and everything that comes with them. It’s inevitable that there will be tasty food on offer. And lots of it, too. So loosen the reigns on your diet, relax and enjoy it. We can’t be perfect all of the time, and guess what? That’s ok. But what if you’re hosting and are in control of the food? Or if you’re allergic to some of the main ingredients, like gluten and dairy? If this is the case, there’s absolutely no reason why you can’t switch up the menu a little bit to include some healthier alternatives. Your guests will be pleasantly surprised at just how delicious healthy food can be, and most probably, grateful of the respite from the more indulgent stuff! To give you some ideas about how you can make your Christmas dishes a little healthier, we’ve hand-picked a selection of amazing recipes from some of the best bloggers and chefs we know and trust. Get stuck in to the list below! #1 - Paleo Nut Roast - Greens of the Stone Age (GF, DF, Paleo, Vegetarian) Georgie at Greens of the Stone Age has well and truly revamped this Christmas classic! If you or anyone in your family doesn't eat meat, try out this healthy take on a Nut Roast that will have everyone going back for seconds. #2 - Six Ingredient Edible Snowmen - Dower and Hollingsworth (GF, DF, Vegan) Have you ever seen anything so cute!? #3 - Cran-Cherry Sauce - Nom Nom Paleo (GF, DF, Paleo, Vegan) Because no Christmas dinner is complete without the cranberry sauce. But if you don't want the supermarket stuff that's laden with sugar, why not make your own? This half and half combination of cherries and cranberries naturally increases the sweetness to help lower the sugar content. #4 - Raw Mince Pies - SpamellaB - (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) No one should be deprived of mince pies at Christmas! So why not try these raw mince pies with low sugar mincemeat from our very own Pamela Higgins. We challenge you to stop at just one!   [icegram messages="7123"] #5 - Brussels Sprout & Kale Superfood Salad - Honesty Healthy (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) With just a little bit of TLC, you can transform your Brussels sprouts into a stunning superfood side salad that has everyone going back for extra helpings. The addition of pomegranate and the toasted flaked almonds take this dish to a whole new level! #6 - Chewy Gingerbread Cookies - The Iron You - (GF, DF, Paleo, Vegan) These Chewy Gingerbread Cookies are so simple to make it almost feels like cheating! If you've recently stocked up on Lucy Bee Cinnamon Powder, this is the perfect recipe for the flavour to shine through. #7 - Chestnut and Rosemary Stuffing - Things My Belly Likes (GF, DF, Paleo, Vegan) There's not much worse than rubbish stuffing to sit alongside a thoughtfully prepared Christmas dinner. Fix it with this simple yet flavoursome paleo version. Want to make it vegan too? Sub the butter with coconut oil. #8 - Honey and Mustard Roast Veg - Madeline Shaw (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) This delicious combination of honey and mustard parsnips, beetroot and pumpkin seeds will add a real splash of colour to your Christmas day spread. This recipe works well with other root vegetables as well, such as butternut squash, jerusalem artichoke and swede. #9 - 'Turkey Con Chilli' - Jamie Oliver (GF, DF) It seems that no matter how many hungry guests you host on Christmas day, there is always some leftover turkey. Make the most of it with this comforting turkey chilli with homemade guacamole. If you're not down with legumes, swap them for some extra seasonal veg such as carrots or chopped parsnips. #10 - Mini Raw Christmas Puddings - Greens of the Stone Age (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) For the more adventurous chef, these vegan and paleo friendly Christmas Puddings are a real winner. Top them with plump, juicy goji berries to complete the festive look! #11 - Nom Nom Chocolate Truffles - Nom Nom Paleo (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) We've made these truffles the past two Christmases because they're just that tasty! Leave in a bowl on the coffee table if you have dinner guests round and watch how quickly they disappear.   #12 - Lucy Bee Roast Potatoes - Lucy Bee (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) Not only is coconut oil one of the healthiest oils to cook with, it also makes the best roast potatoes! Cook yours in Lucy Bee this year and taste the difference for yourself. #13 - No bake Christmas Snow Balls - Detox Inista (GF, DF, Vegan, Paleo) Rounding off our list is these beautiful no bake snow balls, made with dates, coconut, pecans and vanilla. They're much less sugary than the classic snowball recipe, but still perfect if your guests have a bit of a sweet tooth. We hope you all have a happy and healthy Christmas! [icegram messages="16075"]
