item.title: Upgrade your breakfast: 5 healthy recipes you'll make again and again
item.dc:creator: whatiateforbreakfast
item.content:encoded: Stuck in a breakfast rut? Can't face another boring breakfast? This is the article for you! We are delighted to welcome Emily Scott, best known as the creator of the extremely popular Instagram profile What I ate for Breakfast, to the Vivo Blog to share some of her favourite healthy breakfast ideas. They're all easy to make and ready in less than 15 minutes. No matter how busy you are, there's always time for a good breakfast! Perfect Protein Porridge Porridge is my blank canvas. When it’s cold and wintery outside, warm oats served with healthy toppings are something I turn to when I’m in need of a cosy breakfast that I know will keep me full. I especially love the short preparation time and awesome simplicity. This is a great option for vegans looking for a balanced breakfast of carbs and protein, with the help of ingredients such as oats, protein powder and almond milk. I always add fruit for natural sweetness and nutrients and some seeds for their crunchy texture and healthy fats. A favourite topping of mine is frozen cherries, chopped mango, pumpkin and chia seeds, cacao nibs and desiccated coconut. Another go-to topping is cinnamon and a drizzle of nut butter, such as Pip & Nut’s Coconut Almond Butter. Or if you’re craving something sweet, I’d recommend pieces of Pulsin's Vanilla Choc Chip Protein Bar, which melts as you stir it in. Here’s what you will need for the porridge: • 50g rolled oats • 200ml almond milk • 100ml water • 25g protein powder Method: 1. Mix the oats in a saucepan with the almond milk and water. 2. Bring to the boil and then turn the heat down so that it is simmering. 3. Heat for 4-5 minutes until the oats have absorbed most of the liquid. Make sure to stir every so often to prevent it sticking. 4. Alternatively you can microwave on high for 3 minutes, but make sure to use a suitable bowl! 5. Stir in the protein powder. 6. Serve with toppings of your choice and devour. Boiled Eggs with Super Soldiers Who remembers eating boiled eggs with toast cut into soldiers when they were younger? This has always been one of my favourites, but I’ve modified this well-loved classic to make it even healthier. It’s important to start the day with healthy fats and protein, of which eggs are an ideal source, and my “super soldier” alternatives will help you hit your fruit and veg quota even sooner. The beauty of this is there are lots of variations so you will never be bored! Here are some of my super soldier suggestions to start your day: • Crunchy raw pepper slices • Tenderstem broccoli • Steamed asparagus • Baby courgette roasted in Lucy Bee coconut oil • Gluten free toast, topped with mashed avocado and mixed seeds For that oozing yolk to dunk your soldiers into, my method for the perfect boiled eggs is as follows: 1. Fill a medium saucepan with enough water to submerge the eggs. 2. Bring the water to the boil. 3. Carefully add your eggs with a slotted spoon then turn the heat down so it is simmering. 4. For medium eggs cook for exactly 5 minutes and 6 minutes for large eggs. 5. Remove the eggs and place into your egg cups. 6. Serve with soldiers of your choice. Protein Pancakes Everyone loves pancakes for breakfast. But they come at the price of extra sugar that can give you an energy crash by 10am. Instead, these pancakes satisfy my sweet tooth, keep me full until lunch and keep my blood sugar levels more stable so that I’m not reaching for the biscuit tin! The idea is to replace the ingredients in pancakes that might not be as healthy with nutritious alternatives. Instead of white flour, you can use almond flour and use a mashed banana as a natural alternative to sugar. I also add protein powder for an extra protein kick and an egg to bind it all together. What I love about these pancakes is that from this simple base I can then add extra ingredients to the mix for different flavours... and don’t get me started on the toppings! My current favourite is to add cinnamon to the mixture to make winter spiced pancakes and top with Pip & Nut’s Honey Cinnamon Cashew Butter, which melts on to the warm pancakes. I also added chewy coconut flakes for texture and some of The Raw Chocolate Co Vanoffe pieces for extra indulgence. Ingredients (makes 6 pancakes): • 1 banana • 1 dessert spoonful of Pulsin Pea Protein • 1 dessert spoonful of almond flour • ¼ teaspoon of Lucy Bee cinnamon powder • 1 egg • ½ teaspoon of Lucy Bee coconut oil • Pip & Nut Honey Cinnamon Cashew butter • Any other toppings of your choice. Method: 1. Mash the banana and add to a mixing bowl with the protein powder, almond flour and cinnamon. Mix well. 2. Add the egg and stir until it forms a smooth mixture. 3. Heat a frying pan and add in the Lucy Bee coconut oil. 4. Add the mixture to the pan with a tablespoon. I use two tablespoons per pancake. 5. Cook the pancakes for 2-3 minutes on one side or until bubbles are starting to form. 6. Carefully flip the pancakes and cook for another 3 minutes. 7. Dish up a stack, smother with the Pip & Nut while still warm and add your toppings. 8. Enjoy and try not to lick the plate. A few other variations that I’m loving include: • Chocolate chip pancakes: add 1 tablespoon of cacao nibs to the mixture before cooking. I served these topped with peanut butter, some frozen blueberries, bee pollen and extra cacao nibs. • Chocolate and banana stack: divide the mixture in half and mix in ½ teaspoon of raw cacao powder to one of the mixtures before cooking. I topped with peanut butter, and added some sweet frozen cherries and bee pollen. Easy one pan breakfast If you’re like most people and don’t particularly enjoy washing up, then this colourful recipe is perfect for you as it’s all cooked in one pan. What’s more, I love to incorporate vegetables into my breakfast and this is the perfect way of achieving my five-a-day. Here’s an example of a one pan breakfast I created with red pepper, kale and eggs which only took 10 minutes to prepare – and even less time to eat! All you need to do is: 1. Heat a frying pan and add ½ a teaspoon of Lucy Bee coconut oil. 2. Add chopped vegetables of your choice to the pan and cook for a minute or so. 3. Make a hollow in the middle of the veg, crack in a couple of eggs and cook until the whites have set. 4. Serve up and breakfast is ready! I also tried this with leftover butternut squash that I roasted the night before. It was cooked in Lucy Bee coconut oil with sage and smoked paprika. I added peppers, spinach, peas and mixed seeds before adding 2 eggs. It was not only delicious but kept me satisfied until lunch time. Eggs in peppers I came across this idea of cooking eggs in peppers a while ago and it’s now one of my favourites. It’s a brilliant use for those stray peppers that always seem to be hanging around in the fridge at the end of the week. This is a healthy breakfast that looks impressive but is still easy to prepare and takes little time to cook - happy days! You could serve it with spinach for a nutrient packed breakfast, or with some creamy avocado and grilled halloumi for a treat. Method: 1. Slice a pepper so it is cut into rings about 2cm thick (I usually chop up the rest and add it to my lunch so that none is wasted!) 2. Meanwhile heat a frying pan. 3. Add ¼ tsp of Lucy Bee coconut oil and the pepper rings to the pan. 4. Carefully crack eggs into the centre of each. 5. Cook on a medium heat for 4-5 minutes. I find using a pan with a lid helps the eggs to cook through faster. 6. Serve and enjoy! Thanks for reading! Be sure to give Emily a follow on Instagram for daily breakfast inspiration :) [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Why diets suck (and what to do instead)
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: It’s that time of year again! You know what I’m talking about. Television adverts for turkey and mince pies have been replaced with ones for weight loss DVDs and diet meal plans. Gym memberships are at an all-time high, and as a nation we tell ourselves: “this will be our year.” In January, we’re full of good intentions and a thirst for improvement. So why do so many of us fail to even get out of the starting blocks? Maybe it’s because we’re making the exact same mistakes over and over again. Let me explain a little bit more. Why ‘dieting’ isn’t the answer You probably over-indulged this Christmas. I know I did. And now you want to get back to feeling like the healthier, more vibrant you that you were before the sugar-coated monster of December rolled into town. That’s awesome. But where do you start? Let’s face it; there’s no shortage of information out there these days. As you trundle through the archives of the internet or wander the fitness isles of the library, you’re hit with those all too familiar promises. “Lose weight in 3 weeks! Tone up in 28 days!” The problem with these programmes is that they are all chasing after the short term fix. The magic bullet. The panacea that will get us into shape faster than ever before. Having a health and fitness goal is great and everyone likes a challenge. But once you’ve achieved it – then what happens? 9 times out of 10: You slip back into the same old habits, and end up as unhealthy and out of shape as before. If anything is going to deliver long term results – in whatever aspect of life – it has to be sustainable. This means something that you can stick at. Not just this month, or even this year. My challenge to you is to create something that you can maintain for life. The fundamental dieting mistake In my opinion, the reason that most diets don’t work is because they focus too much on restriction. Restricting calories, restricting carbs, restricting sugars, restricting fats. But healthy eating isn’t about restricting at all. The problem is, when we focus on what we can’t have, we’re already setting ourselves up for failure. It’s basic human psychology. If someone tells us something is forbidden, it automatically makes us want it even more. If there’s no room for flexibility and enjoyment, sooner rather than later we’re going to fall off the wagon. It’s inevitable. In order for a diet to be sustainable, it must first be enjoyable. Which probably means you need to ditch the word ‘diet’ altogether. Instead of going on a diet, you’re creating a lifestyle. The Paradigm Shift Traditional dieting views food as the enemy. As soon as we change this mentality, things start to fall into place. Instead of depriving your body, nourish it! Instead of restricting food groups, start embracing others! It’s a simple change in mind-set, but one that I promise will make the world of difference. You already know the basics of a healthy lifestyle, so let’s not try and overcomplicate things. Eat plenty of brightly coloured fruits and veggies. Be sure to get a healthy balance of protein, carbs and fats. Avoid processed food wherever possible. Drink your H20, move often, sleep deeply. Enjoy life. We created our Ultimate Diet Blueprint to make this process even easier. But if you’re at a party or out for dinner with friends? Treat yourself. Relax, enjoy the company, and don’t stress out about making the ‘perfect’ food choice. What does that even mean, anyway? In fact, obsessively worrying and stressing about food choices is going to be much worse for you than treating yourself in the first place! The lifestyle effect Remember, food is not your enemy. The meal in front of you is not defined by it’s calorie content or macronutrient breakdown. It’s there to nourish your body, fuel your cells, to energise you and to make you feel good. Most importantly of all, it’s there to be enjoyed. The traditional method of ‘dieting’ leaves you feeling miserable, deprived, and ultimately on a path destined for failure. Creating a lifestyle allows you the flexibility to live healthily, whilst at the same time maintaining balance and enjoying life. Don’t start a diet with an end date. Create something sustainable: for 2016 and beyond. [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Raw Pistachio & Goji 'Rocky Road' Brownies
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: Does anyone remember those sinfully sweet 'Rocky Road' bars that you used to get at cake shops as a child? Packed full of chewy fruit, crunchy nuts and soft marshmallows, it was the combination of textures that made them so irresistible. They certainly wouldn't be something we would put on the menu now, but the nostalgia still remains! We wanted to create a healthier alternative to this classic recipe, so we used a combination of pistachios and cacao nibs for crunch, and goji berries for chewiness. We then folded these ingredients into a raw chocolate brownie base to create a 100% whole food based, raw and gluten free Rocky Road Brownie! Here's how we did it... Raw Pistachio & Goji 'Rocky Road' Brownies Makes 8 brownies Ingredients: 100g pecan nuts 250g medjool dates 2 tbsp raw cacao brazil nut bliss 2 tbsp raw cacao powder 1 tsp Lucy Bee organic cinnamon powder Pinch Lucy Bee Himalayan salt 50g shelled pistachio nuts, coarsely chopped 50g goji berries 25g raw cacao nibs Optional: 2 tbsp raw cacao brazil nut bliss, to serve Method: 1) In a food processor, blitz your pecan nuts for 30 seconds or so, until crumbly. Add the dates to the mix and blend them together until they start to form a ball. 2) Add the raw cacao brazil nut bliss, raw cacao powder, cinnamon and salt to the mix and blend again until combined. 3) Transfer the contents of the food processor to a mixing bowl. Fold in the pistachio nuts and goji berries. 4) Pour the mixture into a baking tray and transfer to the refrigerator. Allow 3 - 4 hours for the mixture to set before you cut the brownies into slices. 5) Drizzle with the extra raw cacao brazil nut bliss, if using. Serve and enjoy! [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: Recover like a pro: 5 ways to improve your exercise recovery
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: Anyone can go hard in the gym. But if you’re serious about making progress, it’s what you do away from the weights room that really counts. During training, you’re not building muscle. You’re tearing it down. So if you want to come back stronger the next time around, you need to make sure you’re recovering properly. Optimising your workout recovery will allow you to get back in training faster, which in turn, will accelerate the rate at which you make progress. If you're training hard but not making progress as fast as you should, I hope this article can help you. If your muscles feel sore for days after a workout, or you struggle to train multiple days in a row without feeling the effects, then this article is definitely for you. Here are 5 ways to accelerate your recovery, reduce post workout muscle soreness, and ultimately, become a better athlete than ever before. #1 - Sleep If you’ve been reading my articles for any length of time, you’ll probably notice that sleep is a consistent theme throughout them all. That’s because virtually everything that you do comes back to how well you are sleeping. It's that important. What does this mean for your training? In short, if you’re setting your alarm early and missing an hour of sleep to get your workout in, you’re probably not doing your body any favours. Sleep increases production of testosterone and human growth hormone, which help to build and repair muscle. At the same time, sleep reduces the production of cortisol, a stress hormone which promotes muscle degradation and fat storage. High testosterone + high HGH + low cortisol = optimised recovery. Usain Bolt sleeps 8 – 10 hours each day, and Roger Federer aims for 10 – 11 hours. Sleep is the most important part of muscle recovery, which is why you won’t find a single elite athlete who compromises on it. And you shouldn't either! #2 - Nutrition Remember how we spoke earlier about exercise tearing down our muscle tissue? Well, it’s the food we eat that repairs it. It goes without saying, therefore, that the greater the quality of food you consume, the greater results you will get from your recovery. High quality sources of protein are non-negotiable. Protein is made up of amino acids, which are used to build and repair muscle tissue. If you’re training hard, you’ll need around 1.4g – 1.6g protein per kilogram of bodyweight each day to maximise muscle growth and repair. To work out your own daily protein requirements, check out our easy to use protein calculator. Carbohydrates are equally important for recovery, as they help to replenish glycogen stores that get depleted during exercise. Healthy carbohydrate sources like sweet potato, white potato, bananas, butternut squash and white rice are excellent choices, especially in your post workout meal. I also recommend eating carbohydrates at dinner, as they assist with melatonin release which promotes healthy sleep. It’s easy to get sucked into the ‘low carb’ diet trap these days, but as an athlete, this isn’t the right nutrition strategy for you. Regular exercise means that your body demands carbs. I experimented with low carb dieting myself, and know plenty of others that have too. As a result, our performances all went the same way: down the toilet. Lastly, you’re also going to want to take steps to reduce inflammation in your body. Inflammation, caused by poor dietary and lifestyle choices, is what causes muscle soreness and joint pain. When we exercise we are creating acute inflammation in the body. To combat this, eat a diet rich in anti-inflammatory foods and limit the inflammatory ones. I’ve listed some of the most inflammatory and anti-inflammatory foods below: Anti-inflammatory Berries Citrus fruits Ginger Cinnamon Turmeric Omega 3 (salmon, sardines etc) Green vegetables (broccoli, spinach, kale etc) Onions Garlic Coconut Oil Inflammatory Processed food Vegetable oils Factory farmed meat Sugar Dairy As a general rule, a diet high in omega 3 fatty acids and brightly coloured fruits and vegetables is the optimum diet for reducing inflammation. [icegram messages="7123"] #3 - Supplements Once you’ve got your nutrition dialled in, you can start to look at supplementing to give your recovery an extra boost. These supplements are by no means essential, but here are a few that I typically recommend to high performance athletes: Magnesium: Due to intensive farming methods over the past 50 years, our soils are now depleted of their magnesium content. So much so, that over 70% of adults in the UK are now deficient in magnesium. As an athlete, you need even more than the average Joe or Jane, so there’s a good chance you fall into this category. Magnesium is essential in the production of ATP (intracellular) energy, and is also an important catalyst for muscle repair. Magnesium encourages the production of Insulin-like Growth Factor (IGF-1), which is a major contributor to the growth and repair of muscle tissue. Low magnesium levels can also result in a buildup of lactic acid, which makes the muscle feel tight and sore. Last but not least, magnesium promotes healthy sleep, making it an all-round recovery essential. For faster workout recovery and better sleep, I recommend 250 – 500mg magnesium before bed from a supplement such as this one. Omega 3: If you don’t eat oily fish on a regular basis, I’d strongly recommend an omega 3 supplement. Omega 3 has powerful anti-inflammatory properties, which help improve circulation and the rate at which nutrients are delivered to the muscles. I’ve seen clients literally improve their recovery overnight by taking omega 3. Aim for 2 – 3g per day; either from fish, or an omega 3 supplement. Probiotics: Not just for athletes, I’d recommend a probiotic to anyone looking to improve their overall health and vitality. Probiotics are essential for a healthy digestive system, which in turn, improves the rate at which we absorb nutrients from food. Greater nutrient absorption equals faster recovery – making probiotics a game changer for athletes. Does everyone need a probiotic supplement? Not necessarily. If you eat fermented foods such as sauerkraut, kimchi and kombucha on a regular basis, you don’t need to take a supplement. But as most of us don’t, a probiotic supplement is a good way to keep your digestive system healthy all year round. #4 – Cool down and mobilise muscles If you come home from training and collapse in a heap on the sofa for the rest of the day, you’re doing it wrong. Firstly, after your workout, you’re going to want to lower your body temperature. Cold water plunges and ice baths have been used for decades by elite athletes, but simply taking a cold shower will be enough to help reduce muscle soreness for the next day. Throughout the rest of the day, it’s important to stay active and mobile. Consistent, low level movement is the name of the game here. This will help transport nutrients and oxygen into the muscles, and prevent buildup of lactic acid. Walk more, stretch, and keep your body moving to prevent soreness and tightness the next day. Finally, for an extra recovery boost, try employing self-massage methods such as foam or tennis ball roll outs. Paying a visit to a sports massage therapist every month or so can help really release the areas of tension you can’t reach yourself. #5 – Take a salt bath Lastly, a good Epsom or Dead Sea Salt bath in the evening is a great way to banish any lingering aches and pains and promote a deep, restorative sleep. Salt baths are often used by athletes as an extra recovery booster, particularly in between days of hard training. High quality bath salts provide an excellent source of essential minerals, which absorb through the skin as you soak in the bath. These minerals help to regulate muscle and nerve function, and soothe muscle soreness. Epsom salts are also renowned for their high magnesium content, making them a great way to get more magnesium into your body if you don’t want to take a supplement. To make your salt bath, dissolve 250g of salts in warm water (not so hot that you burn your skin) and soak for 15 – 20 minutes. Best in the evening, as it may make you sleepy! Before I sign off this article, I wanted to throw another point into the mixer: stress. Whilst it’s not a recovery tip per se, it is essential to make sure your stress levels are low if you want to get the most from your workouts. Stress causes inflammation in the body, and as we know, inflammation severely impairs recovery. So spend time with friends, meditate, walk the dog, or do whatever else you need to do to chill out. You’ll recover faster, perform at a higher level, and be an all-round better person for it. Thanks for reading! If you enjoyed this article, please share it with a friend. [icegram messages="16075"]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 5 ways to improve your workout recovery
Here are 5 easy ways to accelerate your recovery, reduce post workout muscle soreness, and get yourself back in training faster than ever before.

item.title: Get active anywhere with MoveGB!
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: We love finding people that sing from the same hymn sheet as us. We’re proud to be working with some seriously awesome companies who are committed to inspiring positive change, including the likes of Earthmiles and Ecotricity. Today, we’re stoked to announce our latest partnership with another brilliant organisation: MoveGB! Who are MoveGB? MoveGB are on a mission to make living an active lifestyle as easy and accessible as possible. Instead of just joining one gym or health club, signing up with MoveGB gives you a ‘passport’ to hundreds of local classes, sports groups, activities and gyms! The beauty of this concept is it ensures that fitness never gets boring! Rather than being locked into a monthly fee at the same old gym, you’ve now got access to more choice than you could ever imagine. You can do Crossfit Wednesday morning, Yoga on a Thursday afternoon, Aqua Aerobics on Friday and hit the weights on Saturday! Here at Vivo we believe that keeping fit and active should never feel like a chore, so we’re delighted to be teaming up with MoveGB to help you stay motivated and on track. You’ll enjoy testing your body in hundreds of different ways, and meeting new people at the same time. MoveGB is also great for busy people who travel a lot – wherever you are in the country, you’ll always be able to get your workout in! Join MoveGB MoveGB is live in 25 cities across the country and growing. Whether you’re looking to test your body in new ways, or just want to make your workouts more fun, MoveGB are shaking up the fitness industry like never before. We’re excited to be a part of the movement, and hope you’ll be able to join us too! Click here to visit MoveGB, and sign up for free today! [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: How to eat well for less
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: The most common objection I hear against healthy eating is that it’s too expensive. “I’d love to eat more healthily, but I just can’t afford it!” Is the all too familiar statement. It’s now almost universally accepted that if you want to be healthy, you’re going to have to pay more for the privilege. And with industrially processed ‘food’ so abundant and so cheap, it’s becoming harder and harder for anyone to argue otherwise. I’m not going to try and tell you that most junk food on the supermarket shelves isn’t cheaper than organic fruits and vegetables. This would be a lie. But I’m also not going to tell you that you can’t eat healthily because you can’t afford to. I truly believe than anyone can enjoy a healthy diet, no matter what their budget. And when you start to add up the costs, you soon realise that your unhealthy diet is probably not saving any money at all. Here’s why I think healthy eating is the best choice for your body and your bank balance, and how you can eat healthily even on the tightest of budgets. Going back to basics The first rule of healthy eating is to keep things simple. That means building your diet on real, unprocessed, nutrient dense foods that don’t come in a box or have an ingredients label the size of your arm. Putting this into practice, it means going back to basics with the food that you buy. Prioritise fresh fruits and vegetables, meat, fish, eggs, potatoes, sweet potatoes, rice, maybe some nuts and seeds. Cook your food from scratch: not only will it be fresher and better for you, but it will save a lot of money in doing so. Shop close to home: Wherever possible, shop local and take a little extra time to visit your nearest farm shop or butcher. You’ll cut out the middle man and get better prices than at the supermarket, and your produce will be much fresher and more nutritious too! Look for offers: See that extra ripe avocado that’s going half price? It might be a bit too soft to eat, but you can bet it’s going to make some fine guacamole. I recommend shopping in the evening around 7pm, which is when you’ll pick up the best deals. Plan your meals Planning what you’re going to cook in advance is one of the best things you can do to stay healthy on a budget. This will prevent you from buying things you don’t really need, cut right down on food waste, and also make sure you’re never stuck without a healthy option. It’s all too easy to grab a takeaway or go out to eat when there’s nothing in the house, but if your fridge is always well stocked and your meals planned ahead, you won’t need to! Try to shop for groceries at least twice a week. This will prevent you from overbuying and also keep things much fresher. Lastly, batch cook wherever you can. Cook double portions of your meals and store them in the fridge or freezer. If you’ve got a busy week coming up, prepare food in advance so you’re not caught short. You’ll save both money and time. Organic vs Non Organic Rewind 100 years or so, and all produce was organic by default. Before chemical pesticides and fertilisers were used to increase crop yield, we were eating ‘organic’ whether we knew it or not. Times have certainly changed, so in today’s market, is it worth paying extra for organic produce? Well, yes and no. There’s no question that organic produce is certainly healthier, but it’s very hard for anyone to be able to eat 100% organic all the time. And the ‘organic’ label now comes at a premium, sometimes double the price of a ‘conventionally grown’ alternative. EU Law requires farmers to pay an annual fee if they want to use the word ‘organic’ on their produce. Whilst this system has it’s uses, it isn’t something that is affordable to the small family farm. And as the industrial chemicals used to grow ‘conventional’ produce are so expensive, you’ll find that most small farmers grow their food ‘organically’ by default – but without charging extra for it! If you’re in doubt, speak to your local farmer and ask if he uses any chemicals to grow his food. The same goes for your butcher – ask if the meat is grass fed / free range. A good butcher will be able to tell you the farm your meat came from, and in some cases, even the name of the cow! The key here is not buying too much into the ‘organic’ label, but instead focusing on buying the best quality you can afford. Is an organic tomato better than a conventionally grown tomato? Yes. But is a conventionally grown tomato better than an organic pizza? Damn straight. You see where I’m going with this one! How much are you eating? Whilst cheaper food may represent an initial cost saving, you’re going to find you need a lot more of it to be satisfied. Have you ever eaten 2000 calories worth of pizza, fizzy drinks and ice cream only to be hungry again two hours later? Now try doing the same with chicken breast, sweet potato and broccoli! The reason we feel hungrier when eating cheaper, low nutrient food is that it provides us with ‘empty’ calories that bypass our in-built satiety mechanisms and leave us craving more. But our body is craving nutrients, not calories; and when it doesn’t get it from the food we eat, the hunger signals turn back on. You’ve then got the inevitable rollercoaster ride of energy levels that comes with an unhealthy diet. That 11am sugary snack and that afternoon caffeine kick certainly doesn’t come cheap. But as anyone who has experienced healthy eating for themselves knows, you’ll no longer have to keep relying on ‘borrowed’ energy from sugar and stimulants just to get you through the day. So if you are going to purchase unhealthy food in your weekly shop to save money, be prepared to eat a lot more of it. If you fill your plate with healthier, nutrient dense foods, you won’t need nearly as much to feel satisfied, energised and focused throughout the day. Invest in yourself Maintain the mindset that healthy eating is a long term investment in your body. Putting the short term costs to one side for a minute, I strongly believe that making a commitment to your health will save you money in the long run. Firstly, there’s the productivity aspect. Whilst this doesn’t apply to everyone, speaking from the viewpoint of someone running their own business, I know that when I feel good, I get much more done. Leading a healthy lifestyle allows me to be more focused, more energetic, and ultimately achieve more on any given day. Looking even further ahead, you’ve got days off sick, doctor’s costs, prescription medication. Eventually, maybe even an early check in at the local nursing home. That’s not a nice thought, and I apologise for putting it so bleakly. But you can’t bury your head in the sand and ignore the long term consequences that come with failing to prioritise your health. Before I sign off, I want you to consider something. Can you really put a price on your quality of life? If being healthy really does mean spending a little extra (and as we discussed earlier, it’s really not much more), will it not be worth it 20, 30, 40 years down the line? Prioritise your health. Invest in yourself. You don’t have to break the bank to do so. I promise you: you won’t regret it. [icegram messages="16075"]

item.title: 5 herbal teas to beat the bloat and improve digestion
item.dc:creator: Vivoteam
item.content:encoded: You probably knew this already, but we love herbal tea here at Vivo HQ. Walk into our office and the first thing you’ll see is a shelf full of the stuff. Not only do they taste great, but they come with a range of amazing health benefits too! One of the main traditional uses for herbal tea is as an aid to digestion. For thousands of years, tea has been sipped after a meal to help with the assimilation of food. If you ever suffer from bloating or digestive discomfort after a meal, it’s always a good idea to have a few different blends on hand to help. Whether it’s a ginger tea to stimulate enzyme production or peppermint to soothe the digestive tract, herbal tea can make a massive difference to how you feel after eating. Here are five of our favourite herbal teas to improve digestion and beat the bloat! #1 - Ginger In Ayurveda, the ancient Indian art of wellbeing, ginger tea is traditionally consumed before the main meal of the day to ‘ignite the digestive fire.’ Ginger has been shown to stimulate the secretion of digestive enzymes, which help to break food down more efficiently – thus helping to prevent bloating and discomfort after a meal. Ginger is a fiery herb that has been shown to increase the body’s metabolic rate¹, encouraging healthy transit of food through the digestive system and promoting regular elimination. Along with it’s benefits for digestion, ginger is a powerful anti-inflammatory herb that is excellent for the health of our brain, joints and skin. One of our favourite herbal teas is Pukka's Three Ginger, which combines invigorating ginger root with galangal and turmeric. Try steeping a teabag in hot water for 5 minutes, and drinking it half an hour or so before your main meal. To really get the digestive juices flowing, squeeze in the juice of half a lemon. #2 - Peppermint As a natural anti-spasmodic, peppermint tea is ideal for easing bloating and tension in the digestive tract. If you feel a bit heavy or sluggish after a meal, try a small mug of peppermint tea. As one of the most well researched herbs, there's some good evidence on peppermint's ability to improve digestion. This herb has been clinically studied as a treatment for IBS, and has been shown to significantly reduce abdominal pain in subjects that were tested². It's calming effect on the digestive tract also helps to prevent flatulence, and helps to ease the passage of food through the intestine³. In Ayurveda, peppermint is traditionally combined with liquorice root (see number 3!) – so try a mug of Peppermint and Liquorice, or Refresh, after your meal and see if you notice the difference. #3 - Liquorice Liquorice root has a cooling, soothing effect on the digestive system, and has been used since Ancient Greek times as a remedy for digestive discomfort, stomach ulcers and acid reflux. It’s effectiveness is due to the high concentration of anti-inflammatory flavonoids, which help to treat conditions of high stomach acid such as heartburn, acid reflux or GERD. Liquorice is also a mild diuretic, which may help to reduce water retention. Liquorice tea can be enjoyed at any time of day, either on it’s own or combined with other herbs. Liquorice root is a key component in many of our favourite herbal blends, including Detox, Elderberry and Echinacea, and Lemongrass and Ginger. #4 - Fennel Dating back as far as Ancient Egyptian times, fennel seeds are one of the oldest known remedies for digestion. They are rich in essential oils which help to relax the muscles in the digestive tract, thus providing relief against cramping, bloating and flatulence. Fennel also stimulates bile production, which helps to break down food. Fennel seeds are traditionally chewed after a meal in ancient Egyptian and Indian folklore. They can also be enjoyed in a tea – such as this blend of sweet fennel, wild fennel, and fennel leaf. #5 - Chai Chai is a traditional Indian herbal blend used to boost the immune system and improve digestion. Take a trip to North India and you will find one thousand different recipes for chai; if you can’t, Pukka’s vanilla chai tea is as good as it gets. Vanilla Chai Tea contains ginger, liquorice and fennel, the benefits of which have all been discussed earlier. Also included is cinnamon, which helps to relieve digestive discomfort4, and cardamom, which can improve the rate at which food moves through the digestive system5. If you’re looking for an all-in-one digestive boosting tea, it doesn’t come much better than a tall, hot mug of chai! Ready to put the kettle on?

item.title: 5 essential nutrients you're probably missing as a vegan
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded:
There are tons of reasons why people switch to a plant based diet. Sometimes it’s ethical, sometimes it’s religious, or, most commonly, sometimes the switch is made for health reasons. And who can argue that eating more plants isn't one of the best things that you can possibly do for your health? Some of the healthiest people I know are vegans. Take Dean Howell for instance, who is living proof of how a well thought out plant based diet can optimise both your health and sporting performance. When implemented properly, a whole food based vegan diet can be one of the most amazing tools for vibrant health. Note when I say a whole food vegan diet – as opposed to the typical ‘junk food’ vegan that eats copious amounts of gluten, grain and soy products! As with any diet, the focus of veganism should always be piling your plate high with fresh fruits and vegetables, ideally those that are organically grown and in season. But, veganism does come with it’s drawbacks. Like it or not, there are a handful of essential nutrients that are incredibly hard to source of a vegan diet. That isn’t to say veganism doesn’t work – it just requires a bit of know-how! If you want to maintain vibrant long term health as a vegan, here are five key nutrients you need to pay careful attention to.  Vitamin B12 One of the main reasons why people fail to implement a vegan diet long term is because of the absence of B12. Essential for energy production and the oxygenation of red blood cells, a lack of B12 is why long term vegans often complain of fatigue or low energy levels. Critics of the vegan diet are quick to ask where your B12 comes from if you only eat plants – because, as traditional wisdom goes, B12 is only available in animal foods. But is this really the case? Not necessarily. Whilst B12 is more abundant in animal foods, it's not impossible to get it from plant sources. You just have to look in the right places! Plant based sources of Vitamin B12 are rare, but include: Nutritional yeast: After becoming increasingly popular amongst many vegans for the uniquely ‘cheesey’ flavour it imparts onto food, nutritional yeast is now available at most large supermarkets. Just 2 tablespoons of nutritional yeast contains approximately 130% of your daily requirements for vitamin B12. Nutritional yeast is cheap, delicious and versatile – so sprinkle some regularly over your favourite savoury meals! Sea vegetables: Sea vegetables such as nori, bladderwrack, Irish moss, and certain varieties of kelp all contain a good source of vitamin B12. If you’d rather not resort to direct B12 supplementation, consider taking a high quality sea vegetable supplement daily to meet your B12 needs. Jaggery: Taken from the sweet nectar of the Palmyra tree, jaggery is a traditional sugar substitute often used in Asian and African cuisine. Depending on the refining process used, just one tablespoon of jaggery can contain up to 70% of your daily B12 needs. This one is a bit harder to find, but keep an eye out for Asian supermarkets that may be able to source jaggery. B12 supplement: If you can’t access any of the three foods above, I strongly recommend a high quality B12 supplement to stay healthy and energetic on a vegan diet. This particular variety is very popular with our customers as it doesn’t need to be swallowed like a tablet – simply spray it directly onto your tongue for your daily dose of B12. Omega 3 Wait – omega 3? Isn’t that found in seeds such as chia, flax and hemp? Well, it is and it isn’t. Excuse me whilst I get my science geek on in the next paragraph. There are three forms of Omega 3 fatty acid: eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), and alpha-linolenic acid (ALA). EPA and DHA are found exclusively in marine life (fish and algae), whilst ALA is found in plants. Although these are all technically classified as omega 3 fatty acids, our body can only utilise EPA and DHA as ‘true’ omega 3. ALA, found in plants, has to be converted to EPA and DHA by the body. Unfortunately, the conversion rate of ALA to EPA and DHA is not good at all, currently estimated at 1:100. In other words, you would need to eat 100 grams of ALA just to get the benefits of 1 gram of EPA and DHA. That’s over half a kilo of flaxseed each day! But before you go diving head first into your bag of Linwoods, rest assured that there is a better (and much less filling!) way to get your omega 3. EPA and DHA isn’t just found in living sea creatures; as I mentioned earlier, it can also be found in underwater plant matter, such as algae. These sea vegetables are pretty amazing aren’t they? If you are a vegan and are looking to up your intake of omega 3, I strongly recommend an algae derived omega 3 supplement to keep your levels topped up. Omega 3 is essential for the health of your brain, skin, joints, heart, bones and immune system. In fact, every cell in your body needs it. So if there is one nutrient you shouldn’t be skimping on, it is this one. By all means, continue to eat your flax and chia seeds. But eat them for the protein, fibre and minerals that they contain; not the omega 3. Zinc Zinc is an essential nutrient for maintaining a healthy immune system and regulating hormonal balance. It is also a powerful antioxidant that fights against free radical damage, suppresses excess cortisol production, and helps maintain healthy energy levels. Zinc deficiency is one of the most common in the UK, and is particularly prevalent amongst non meat eaters. To make sure you are getting enough zinc in your diet, make sure you are eating the following: Pumpkin seeds: A handful of pumpkin seeds contains approximately 24% of your RDA of zinc. However, some of this zinc content is nullified by the presence of phytate, an enzyme found in plant foods that binds to minerals in the digestive tract and makes them difficult to absorb. To lower the content of phytate in your pumpkin seeds, consider soaking and sprouting them before eating. Cashew nuts: Like pumpkin seeds, cashew nuts also contain phytate, so consider soaking and sprouting them for maximum benefit. 1 handful of soaked cashew nuts contains approximately 12% of your zinc RDA. Dark chocolate: If you needed any more reason to get your daily chocolate fix, a 30g serving of the good stuff contains approximately 20% of your RDA of zinc. Whilst I wouldn’t advise relying on chocolate exclusively to meet your zinc requirements, it can be a useful (and delicious!) way to bump up your intake. Spinach: Popeye’s favourite vegetable contains 9% of your zinc RDA per cup, when cooked. You’d have to get through a lot of spinach to meet your RDA, but adding a serving to at least one meal each day can help you meet your target of this mineral. Chia seeds: Each tablespoon of chia seeds contains approximately 5% of your zinc RDA. Sprinkle them over your favourite foods, or use to make chia puddings, for an easy additional source of zinc. If you don’t think you can get enough zinc from your diet alone, consider taking a high quality zinc supplement to meet your daily needs. Iron Iron is well known for it’s role in the production of red blood cells, which is why vegans and vegetarians that lack iron are often soon diagnosed as anaemic. What’s more, plant based sources of iron are harder to absorb than animal sources – meaning a vegan may need up to 50% more iron than a meat eater. But, it is still perfectly possible to get adequate iron on a plant based diet with the following foods: Lentils: 1 cup of cooked lentils contains approximately 35% of your iron RDA Chickpeas: 1 cup of cooked chick peas contains approximately 29% of your RDA Swiss Chard: Contains 27% of your iron RDA per 100g cooked serving Spinach: Contains 22% of your iron RDA per 100g cooked serving Tofu: If you eat tofu (and if you do, make sure it is high quality and free from additives), you can find 15% of your iron RDA in a 100g serving. The vast majority of plant foods contain at least small concentrations of iron thanks to the soil that they are grown in. In other words, eat plenty of fruits and vegetables, and you won’t have to worry too much about your iron intake. Whole grains are often recommended as a source of iron, but because I am not an advocate of grains in any form, I do not recommend turning to whole grains such as wheat, barley or brown rice as a source of iron. Long term, a grain heavy diet can cause multiple nutrient deficiencies as it actually depletes the body of minerals. I also do not recommend taking an iron supplement, especially high dose ones that have been shown to cause iron toxicity. Calcium I’ve left calcium until last because, despite prevailing wisdom that it is only available in dairy products, it is actually quite easy to consume on a vegan diet. Calcium can be found in almonds, cashews, leafy green vegetables, hemp, blackstrap molasses, sesame seeds, broccoli, blackcurrants and even figs. If you are eating a wide variety of plant foods, you won’t have to worry too much about your calcium intake. If you do decide to take a calcium supplement (and you probably don’t need to), make sure it also contains magnesium. These two minerals work in a unique synergy, and too much of one and not enough of the other can lead to imbalances. All in all, your best way to avoid any kind of nutrient deficiency (no matter what your diet) is to eat as wide a variety of natural foods as possible. Pay close attention to these five nutrients and you’ll have no problem staying happy and healthy on a vegan diet! 
[icegram messages="16106"]

item.title: Superfood Protein Falafels
item.dc:creator: inspiredbynic
item.content:encoded:
Guest recipe from Nicola Rowe, personal trainer and vegan nutritional adviser. These aren't your usual falafels! My superfood falafels are made with all sorts of goodness including flaxseed, hemp protein, turmeric, coconut oil and Himalayan salt, so are the perfect healthy upgrade to the classic falafel recipe. Make a big batch of these in advance and add them to salads, or enjoy them as a snack at any time of day for a delicious serving of protein, fibre and essential nutrients! You will need: 150g Chickpeas, soaked overnight 100g Raw Carrot 1/2 tsp Organic Turmeric Powder 1 tsp Cumin 1 tbsp fresh parsley, finely chopped 2 tbsp Raw Hemp Protein 2 tbsp Linwoods Milled Flax Seed 1/4 tsp Lucy Bee Himalayan Salt, ground finely 2tbsp Coconut Oil, melted Method: 1) Drain your chickpeas and rinse with cold water. Add to your food processor or nutribullet blender along with your carrots, and blitz together until well combined but not too smooth. 2) Add the remaining dry ingredients (everything minus the coconut oil) and blend again until well combined. 3) Roll the mixture into 12 balls and leave to set in the fridge for an hour. 4) Pre-heat the oven to 180C / 350F / Gas Mark 5. Transfer your falafel onto a baking tray and lightly brush with the melted coconut oil. 5) Cook for 10 - 12 minutes, turning once to ensure an even bake. 6) Leave to cool slightly and enjoy! 
[icegram messages="16106"]

item.title: Why women should hit the weights (and where to start)
item.dc:creator: alipaton
item.content:encoded: Guest post by Ali Paton of mybigfitdiary.com If you’re after more from your exercise routine than spending countless hours slogging it away on the stair master - then weight lifting could be for you. It can be daunting stepping into the weight room for the first time, what with the scary looking machines and all those heavy weights you can’t even imagine ever being able to move. And that’s not to mention all that testosterone flying around, the grunting, and all of the posing - sounds terrifying right? Wrong! Yes, most men know how to bench press and bicep curl, but generally they’re just as clueless as we are. And don’t even start with the ‘but I don’t want to get bulky’ business! Remember the testosterone we were just talking about? Well women simply don’t have enough of it to build muscle in the same way as men. With that in mind, here's why you should start hitting the weights. More muscle = more calories burnt Think cardio is the only way to burn calories? Think again! When performing steady state cardio we can burn high amounts of calories but as soon as you step off the treadmill that calorie burn stops and your metabolic rate returns to normal. However studies have shown that strength training helps to keep your metabolism elevated long after your workout is finished¹, making it much better ‘value for money’ in terms of calories burnt! Improved mood Strength training can release endorphins giving you a boost of energy and helping to improve your mood. This makes it a great form of exercise for those who suffer from anxiety or simply to help you recover after a particularly stressful day at work. Better bone & heart health As we age we lose bone tissue and strength increasing the risk of breaks even from a small fall, which is why weight training is important especially in older women. Exercises such as squats, deadlifts and bicep curls put bones under pressure which in turn forces them to change, growing stronger and denser². In terms of heart health, weightlifting helps to lower blood pressure and LDL (bad) cholesterol³ and, as I pointed out earlier can help you to lose weight reducing any added strain you might be putting on your heart. Overall fitness All athletes will include weight lifting in their training plan as it helps to develop a stronger core and build more power in the glutes, arms and legs. So whether you’re a swimmer, footballer or gymnast, building a stronger body is a great way to improve your performance! So now we know why we should be lifting weights - it’s time to tackle how to get started. How to start a strength routine Take a class It’s always easier to do something for the first time in a group setting. You don’t feel like all eyes are on you and the chances are there will be others just starting out too. Joining a body pump class is a great way to get comfortable with picking up weights and can help you to develop your form in the main compound lifts such as squats and deadlifts. Have a PT session It can be pretty pricey but it’s worth investing in a couple of sessions with a PT to pick up some ideas on what to do in the weight room. Again they can show you how to lift with good technique which can help build up your confidence and prevent you from getting injured when you do go it alone. Go with a friend Everything is easier with a friend. You can help each other out and who knows, you may have a friend who already knows a little about lifting and can give you some tips. Ask for help Don’t be afraid to ask for a little help. Maybe you’re struggling to figure out a machine or to get clips on and off the bar. Just find a friendly looking fellow gym goer and ask for some advice… you may even find a new training buddy this way. Feel the fear and do it anyway! Find your program, learn the moves and just go for it! You’ve got nothing to lose and a strong sexy body to gain. Are you ready? Sources 1) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10939877 2) http://www.naturalnews.com/010528_bone_density_mineral.html 3) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16922820 [icegram messages="19024"]

item.title: Mini Raw Chocolate Caramel and Lucuma Cheesecake
item.dc:creator: Pamela Higgins
item.content:encoded: For those that didn't already know, our resident recipe writer Pamela likes to experiment in the kitchen. And when we say 'experiment' we mean 'take just about any conventional recipe and make it healthy!' Case in point: This Mini Raw Chocolate Caramel and Lucuma Cheesecake. If you've never tried Lucuma before, this recipe is the perfect way to get in on the act. Lucuma is a fruit native to the Peruvian highlands, with a soft, mellow sweetness and notes of maple and caramel. It compliments the raw chocolate topping of this cheesecake just perfectly, and also adds a hefty dose of B vitamins and iron! Combine this silky smooth lucuma filling with a crumbly biscuit base and a gorgeous raw chocolate topping, and we guarantee you're in for a real treat with this recipe. Here's how you make it yourself! Ingredients For the base: 3tbsp gluten free oats 1 tablespoon almond butter 1 tablespoon date nectar, or two large medjool dates blended to a paste 1 tablespoon Lucy Bee Coconut Oil For the filling: 1 banana, frozen in chunks 1 cup cooked sweet potato or butternut squash 3tsp Organic Lucuma Powder 1 scoop Sunwarrior Vanilla Protein Powder 1 teaspoon Lucy Bee Organic Cinnamon Powder 1 teaspoon vanilla extract 2 tablespoons almond milk For the topping: 1 tablespoon tahini 1 tablespoon Organic Cacao Powder 1 teaspoon date nectar (or sweetener of your choice) 1/2 teaspoon Organic Lucuma Powder A few squares of Vanoffe Raw Chocolate, broken into pieces How to make 1) First make the base: Mix together the oats, nut butter, date nectar and coconut oil to form a slightly sticky mixture. Press into a mini spring-form cake tin. 2) Now make the filling: Whizz up all of the ingredients in a blender until thick and smooth. Pour over the base and freeze for at least 2 hours. 3) Finally, make the topping! Simply mix together all of the ingredients to create a smooth paste. You may need to add a small splash of hot water to help it mix. 4) Remove the mini cake tin from the freezer at least 10-15 minutes beforehand. Gently remove the cheesecake from the tin, spread over the topping and scatter over the raw chocolate pieces. Return to the freezer for 10 more minutes to firm up. 5) Remove from the freezer, slice up and serve!

item.title: 7 reasons to switch to a plant based protein powder
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: For years, whey protein has been considered the ‘gold standard’ in protein powders. And with an exceptionally high protein content and an excellent amino acid profile, it’s been almost impossible for anyone to argue otherwise. But the marketplace is changing. New technology and growing awareness has not only seen plant based protein powders catch up with whey – they’re now surpassing it. What’s more, plant based protein powders don’t come with the drawbacks and pitfalls associated with whey protein. We’ll get on to those in more detail shortly. If you’re still contemplating making the switch to plant based proteins, here are 7 reasons to bite the bullet once and for all. Trust me; you’ll never look back. #1 - It won’t upset your gut Do you ever feel yourself getting bloated or uncomfortable after consuming whey protein? This is a tell-tale sign that you probably need to back off the dairy-based shakes. Approximately 65% of the human population have some degree of lactose intolerance¹. And as the symptoms are so wide ranging, the vast majority of us don’t even know it. Lactose intolerance can manifest itself in countless ways: skin complaints, headaches, lack of energy – but 9 times out of 10, the first place you’ll notice it is in your gut. If you get any sort of digestive discomfort when you eat dairy products, why should you make an exception for a whey protein shake after your workout? Whilst it is true that whey protein contains less lactose than other dairy products such as milk and cheese, lactose is still present. And with just trace amounts of lactose enough to cause a reaction in even mildly sensitive individuals, whey will still be a trigger for more people than not. Most plant proteins, on the other hand, are hypoallergenic. Hemp protein, pea protein, and sprouted brown rice protein are easy to digest and won’t cause you the same discomfort that you’ll have grown used to after drinking whey protein. Don’t believe us? Try a free sample of plant based protein after your next workout, and see how much better you feel. #2 - You’ll absorb more If you’re even mildly intolerant to whey protein, there’s no way you’ll be able to get all the benefits. That digestive discomfort that you feel after consuming whey? It’s an obvious sign that your body is struggling to break it down efficiently. So, whilst it may say 25g protein per scoop on the label, it’s very unlikely that you’re actually getting that much. Your body can only utilise what it can absorb, after all. In comparison to whey, hemp protein is composed of globular proteins edestin and albumin. Don’t panic – I don’t need you to remember the names. What I do need you to remember is that globular proteins are regarded as the most bio-available of proteins due to the ease of which they are absorbed². Why waste your money on extra grams of protein that you can’t absorb, when every penny of a plant based alternative can be used efficiently? #3 - You’ll build muscle faster Controversial statement, I know. But hear me out. If you struggle to break down whey efficiently based on the reasons mentioned above, you’re going to get better results from a plant based protein that you can digest properly. Put it this way – if you were to consume 25g whey protein but can only actually absorb 20g of it, versus 25g pea protein of which you can absorb all of it, which is going to give you better results? If you still don’t believe me, consider the science behind the theory. In a 2015 study by the International Society of Sports Nutrition, supplementing with pea protein was shown to promote faster muscle gains than supplementing with whey protein³. Now, imagine how these results could be even further amplified by using a plant based protein powder with an amino acid profile superior to whey. For years, whey has been considered ‘superior’ to plant based protein powders. But the game is changing fast, and it’s now struggling to keep up. #4 - It's safer There have been countless studies and investigations that have detected high levels of heavy metals in some of the leading brands of whey protein on the market. Perhaps the most alarming of all of these was the now infamous American Consumer Reports study4, which showed ‘particularly concerning’ levels of cadmium, arsenic, mercury and lead in these whey protein shakes. Arsenic exposure has been linked to various cancers; including lung, skin, kidney, liver and prostate cancer, and blood vessel damage5. Cadmium has been shown to damage DNA6, whilst mercury can destroy brain cells7. Heavy metals find their way into whey protein because of the GMO feed that the dairy cows are fed on. It’s cheap, and although it’s not a natural diet for the cows, the manufacturers couldn’t care less about their welfare. And, consequently, they couldn’t care less about your welfare either. Why would they when you’re still buying their stuff and the profit continues to roll in? If you use whey protein, it is crucial that you ask your manufacturer to show proof of their heavy metal check. Do it now. It’s that important. Alternatively, you can ditch the whey altogether, in favour of a plant based protein where every single ingredient has been rigorously tested for heavy metals and other potential contaminants. #5 - It’s better for the environment Whether you choose to bury your head in the sand or not, we’ve got a duty of care to this planet that we call home. And with the global production of livestock having a greater environmental impact than anything else in the world8, what better way to reduce your footprint than by switching to a plant based protein powder. #6 - It’s more ethical Unless you choose an organic whey protein made from the milk of free range, grass fed cows, you’re directly supporting the inhumane cattle-factories that we call ‘the dairy industry.’ Conventional whey protein is made from the milk of intensively reared, unhealthy cows kept in crowded, unsanitary conditions and fed a diet of GMOs, artificial hormones and antibiotics. Doesn’t sound like much fun, does it? Collectively, we can let our pounds do the talking. Every time you choose plant based over whey, you’re sticking a metaphorical two fingers up at the dairy industry. #7 - It’s better for your health Remember those artificial hormones and antibiotics we spoke about that are used in cattle production? Well, an unhealthy cow yields unhealthy milk, so you better believe that those hormones and antibiotics will be finding their way into your body every time you drink conventional whey protein. Which would you rather put in your body? Sources 1) http://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/lactose-intolerance 2) http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/bip.36.v12:7/issuetoc 3) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25628520 4) http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/magazine-archive/2010/july/food/protein-drinks/what-our-tests-found/index.htm 5) http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jt/2011/431287/ 6) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17366568 7) http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3395437/ 8) http://science.time.com/2013/12/16/the-triple-whopper-environmental-impact-of-global-meat-production/

item.title: Crunchy Raw Rainbow Salad
item.dc:creator: Pamela Higgins
item.content:encoded: We live in a world with more information than ever before about health and nutrition. At the click of a button we can access virtually unlimited research, articles and opinions about what we should (and shouldn't) be doing to get healthy. Whilst this definitely has it's benefits, it's also making things a hell of a lot more confusing. With so many diet plans, weight loss guides and healthy eating blueprints appearing on a daily basis, nutrition now seems almost too complicated to even bother getting started. Newsflash: it's not. Here at Vivo we're all about keeping things simple. We don't think nutrition should be any different. And of course, the simpler you make things to follow, the easier they are to stick to and maintain long term. Want to get healthier? One of the simplest things you can do for your health is to start eating more colours on a daily basis. Don't overthink it. Don't get caught up in counting all the different antioxidants and micronutrients you're eating. It doesn't need to be any more complicated than eating a rainbow of fruits and vegetables every day. For anyone that is new to healthy eating, this is one of the most fundamental pieces of advice you can give them. To help you get more colours in your diet, we asked our resident recipe writer Pamela to create the most colourful recipe she could think of! True to form, she didn't disappoint. This Crunchy Raw Rainbow Salad contains an array of brightly coloured veg, massaged with a zesty, sweet and spicy salad dressing that dances on your palette like it's doing the flamenco. You'll feel so vibrant and energised after eating it, you'll probably want to do the same yourself. Over to Pamela with the recipe! CRUNCHY RAW RAINBOW SALAD Serves 4 as a side dish, 2 as a main Ingredients 2 yellow peppers, sliced 2 carrots, grated 1 large courgette, cut into matchsticks ½ red cabbage, shredded 1 red chilli, deseeded and chopped Roasted edamame beans (optional) For the dressing: 2 tablespoons Coconut Aminos 1 tablespoon sesame oil 1 tablespoon raw honey or maple syrup Juice of ½ lemon or lime 1 teaspoon Lucy Bee turmeric powder ½ teaspoon grated ginger ½ teaspoon cumin Pinch of chilli powder (depending how hot you like it!) Get making! 1) Prepare all your vegetables and mix together in a large bowl. 2) Whisk together all of the dressing ingredients and keep in a jar. 3) An hour before you’re ready to serve, pour the dressing over the vegetables and mix well to cover. Leave to marinade in the fridge. This will allow the vegetables to absorb all the flavours and will also help to tenderise them slightly. 4) Now dish up, scatter over a handful of roasted edamame beans and enjoy! You could also scatter over cashew nuts if you prefer. Enjoy this Crunchy Raw Rainbow Salad as a side dish to some protein of your choice, or as a main meal for a lighter lunch!

item.title: TWO post workout recovery smoothie recipes!
item.dc:creator: Pamela Higgins
item.content:encoded: PERFORM is delicious on it's own mixed with water, coconut water or almond milk. But that's not the only way to use it! To take your post workout recovery to the next level, here are two delicious smoothies you can make using PERFORM. Whether you prefer Raw Cacao or Madagascan Vanilla, give these a try after your next tough workout! Still wondering whether PERFORM is right for you? Click here to claim your free sample, and see what all the fuss is about! Super Charged Raw Cacao, Banana and Cinnamon Protein Shake This super-charged protein shake delivers an excellent balance of protein and carbs to super-charge your post workout recovery. Like every protein shake made with PERFORM, it also provides the added benefits of turmeric extract to fight oxidative stress and help you get back in training faster! Ingredients: 1 banana, frozen in chunks 1 scoop PERFORM Raw Cacao 1 tsp raw cacao powder 1 tsp organic lucuma powder 1 x 30g sachet Pip & Nut Almond Butter 250ml almond milk Method: 1) Place all ingredients in a blender and whizz together until smooth 2) Top with cacao nibs, chopped almonds, buckwheat groats, flaked coconut, or anything else you fancy! Zingy Raspberry, Beetroot & Vanilla Protein Smoothie This delicious, zingy smoothie combines the anti-inflammatory benefits of beetroot, bee pollen and acai to help reduce muscle soreness after a hard training session. Combine it with a scoop of PERFORM Madagascan Vanilla and the result is pure bliss! Ingredients: 3 large chunks cooked and cooled beetroot 1 banana, frozen in chunks 1 cup frozen raspberries Zest and juice of one orange Pinch ground ginger 1 teaspoon Kaizen Living Acai Powder 200ml water 1 scoop PERFORM Madagascan Vanilla 1 tbsp Organic Bee Pollen Method: 1) Place all ingredients (except the bee pollen) in a blender and whizz together until smooth 2) Top with bee pollen and fresh raspberries, and enjoy! Show us how you PERFORM! Don't forget to tag us in your favourite recipes, pictures and videos on social media @vivolifeuk using PERFORM or any other products from our online store. We'll select one lucky winner each month to win a FREE tub of PERFORM and other treats worth up to £50.00!

item.title: Why we created PERFORM
item.dc:creator: Josh
item.content:encoded: Unless you’ve been living under a rock for the past few weeks, you’ll have noticed something very exciting has landed at Vivo HQ. After months of extensive research and product development, working with the very best producers and growers, and finally bringing it all together in a certified organic manufacturing facility; we’re delighted to have finally released our very own protein powder – PERFORM raw plant protein. Via Instagram @tommyowen_pt You’ve probably already seen the promotional video and visited the product explainer page. And whilst they’re engaging and modern and easy on the eye, in reality they are just one small part of the product. I also think it’s important to give you a stripped back view on PERFORM, straight from the people that created it. I wanted to use our blog to give you a bit of a closer insight into PERFORM: why we created it, how we did so, and what makes it different to everything else that’s out there today. Whether you already use PERFORM or are still contemplating your first purchase, I hope this short blog gives you a chance to get to know it even better. Via Instagram @Jesssriv Why we created PERFORM Salv and I have been fitness mad for as long as we can remember. We play various different sports, weight train, sprint, and enjoy pushing our body to the limit in any way that we can. In short, whatever we do, we want to perform at the highest level. And we created Vivo Life with a goal to help 1 million people around the world do the same (yes, we’re counting!). We know that a high quality protein powder is one of the most important supplements that an athlete can use. Between us, we’ve tried hundreds. We’ve shipped brands in from America, Australia, and countless other countries in between. But we’ve never been able to find one that ticks all of our boxes. We wanted a protein powder that was made with the highest quality, plant based ingredients. That was a no brainer. But we also wanted a formula that delivered serious results. After all, what good is it having great ingredients if they’re not put together in a formula that makes you run faster, lift more weight, or look better naked?   For too long there has been a huge divide between protein powders created for health, and protein powders created for performance. With PERFORM, all that changes. The Next Generation of Plant Based Protein The first thing we knew we had to do with PERFORM was to find a way to create the best amino acid profile on the market. To achieve this, we used a blend of four different plant proteins. Not only did this give us a complete amino acid profile, but it also provided a high concentration of leucine, isoleucine and valine. These are the three Branched Chain Amino Acids (BCAAs) that form the building blocks of muscle. Pea protein is commonly used in plant based proteins, and is well known for having an exceptionally high protein content. But, the heat process that is used to extract the protein from the peas can denature the amino acids and make it difficult to absorb efficiently. So, we used patented bio-fermentation technology to unlock this amazing source of protein without the use of heat, thus keeping all the precious amino acids (which our body uses for growth and repair) intact.  We complimented this with three nutrient dense, cold pressed, superfood proteins: organic hemp, organic spirulina, and organic chlorella. Not only do these improve the bio-availability and the amino acid profile of the product, but they also add valuable nutrients such as iron, calcium and B vitamins. Finally, we added additional plant derived BCAAs, scientifically proven to enhance muscular recovery. This made us the first vegan protein powder on the market with added BCAAs for performance. This unique combination of raw plant proteins and BCAA gave us a superior amino acid profile to whey, widely considered the ‘gold standard’ in protein. But we weren’t going to stop there. PERFORMance boosters Now the protein itself was complete, we wanted to add a few carefully selected ingredients to help take PERFORM to an even higher level. The first was turmeric extract, widely known as one of the world’s most powerful antioxidants. This helps fight back against oxidative stress that results from your workouts, accelerating your recovery and allowing you to get back in training again faster. The next was pure Himalayan salt. Himalayan salt contains 82 different trace minerals, helping to replenish those precious electrolytes we lose during sweat. Just a pinch is all it takes, but that pinch plays an essential part in the post workout recovery and re-hydration process. Lastly, we added an organic, plant based digestive enzyme complex to ensure optimum absorption and assimilation. This means PERFORM gets to work faster and more efficiently, allowing for a greater amino acid uptake and faster recovery. The turmeric extract used in PERFORM contains concentrated curcumin, to fight back against oxidative stress Perfecting the taste The last part of our product development journey was perfecting the taste. There was never any question of us using artificial flavours and sweeteners, so it became a question of sourcing the very best natural ingredients to create the perfect flavour profile. In total, we tested over 60 different flavour blends until we had it absolutely nailed. For most protein powders, you’re lucky if the taste is remotely palatable. We wanted to create something that was unquestionably delicious. If you’ve worked hard in the gym, the very least you deserve is a great tasting shake to follow. We went the extra mile to source the highest quality ingredients that would really give us the edge when it came to taste. Whether it was arriba cacao from Ecuador, or wild vanilla beans from Madagascar, we made no compromises and spared no expense in order to get the very best. If you’ve tasted it yourself, you’ll know exactly what we’re talking about. Creating PERFORM Now we had our formula nailed down, we had to find a way to bring it to life. Luckily for us, this was the easiest part of the process. Our good friends at Revolution Foods had recently opened a brand new, certified organic manufacturing facility with state of the art blending equipment. How about that for perfect timing? So, we got in touch with them about producing PERFORM, and shortly after, were working with them to produce our first test batch. One of the best things about our manufacturing facility is that it is only used to create health products. Most large manufacturing facilities used to make protein powders also process a whole range of other products, including those that contain potential allergens such as gluten and dairy. If you’re super sensitive to these products, there is always a risk of cross contamination if your product is being made in a facility that handles them. Our manufacturing facility is 100% gluten, dairy and sugar free – meaning there is absolutely no risk of unwanted ingredients finding their way into our product. What’s more, our manufacturing facility is also 100% vegan, giving you complete peace of mind if you choose not to eat animal products.  The final part of the process involved sourcing tubs that were BPA free and fully recyclable (easier said than done!) and finally, working out a way that we could use PERFORM to inspire a whole new generation of athletes. Partnership with StreetGames When we set up Vivo Life, we made it our mission to help 1 million people around the world get fit and healthy. It's certainly not an easy goal, but we're not going to rest until we get there. By creating PERFORM, we are extremely confident that we have created a product that can make a serious impact on the fitness and performance of anyone that uses it. But more than that, it now also gives us a vehicle to improve the lives of people that aren’t using it. More specifically, every purchase of PERFORM will help encourage children across the country to get fit, active, and outside playing sport. We are doing this by donating 20p of each sale to StreetGames, a UK based charity committed to helping kids in disadvantaged communities change their lives through the power of sport. StreetGames have over 600 projects across the UK, and we're proud to be supporting them as they transform the lives of young people through the power of sport. via @streetgamesuk Instagram Looking back at PERFORM After months of development, PERFORM is finally on the shelves. Looking back, did we reach the targets that we initially set out to achieve? When we created PERFORM, we drew up the following check list: Looking at the product now it is in our hands, we’re extremely thankful to have been able to achieve every single one. Whatever the future holds for PERFORM, we’re over the moon to have been able to create a product that we truly believe stands head and shoulders above anything else on the market. The journey is just beginning. And we’re looking forward to having you come along for the ride.
